(c)  If four (4) or more vacancies exist simultaneously in the office of councilman, the clerk shall, within ten (10) days thereafter, call for the necessary primary election and special election, to be held as soon as legally possible to fill such vacancies for the unexpired terms of the said elective officers. 
(Referendum of 11-6-79; Referendum of 11-7-00) 
Sec. 11.6. - Improper contract or use of city property. 
    No elective or appointive officer shall take any official action on any contract or other matter in which he has any financial interest other than the common public interest. No officer or employee shall devote any city property or lands to a private use. Any officer or employee violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall forfeit his office or position. 
Sec. 11.7. - Misdemeanors under Charter. 
    All offenses in this Charter declared to be misdemeanors and all violations of city ordinances shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days or both, in the discretion of the court. 
Sec. 11.8. - Notice of publication. 
    Notices of proceedings requiring publication shall unless otherwise provided by this Charter, be published at least once in the official newspaper. The council shall annually designate the official newspaper. If, at any time, the newspapers which have been designated, cease regular publication, or are not giving satisfactory service, the council shall order the publication of such notices, proceedings, ordinances or other records, as are required to be published, in some other newspapers printed and published in the city in the English language, or if there be none, then in some other newspapers printed in the English language and circulated in the city; provided, however, that the city shall not be without official newspapers more than thirty (30) days. Where no paper is available, in lieu of publication, in the official newspaper, the council, in any particular instance, may order such notice of proceedings printed and posted in at least ten (10) public places in the city, including not less than one (1) place in each precinct. 
Sec. 11.9. - Meaning of state and city. 
    Wherever used in this Charter, the word "state" shall mean "State of Michigan," and the word "City" shall mean the "City of Southfield." 
Sec. 11.10. - Gender. 
(a)  Every word used in this Charter importing the masculine gender shall extend to and be applied to females as well as males; and the words "he," "him" and "his" shall be construed to also mean "she," "her" and "hers," respectively. 
(b)  Whenever used in this Charter the words "councilman" or "councilmen" shall hereafter be changed to "councilman/councilwoman" or "councilmen/councilwomen," respectively. 
(Referendum of 11-7-89) 
Sec. 11.11. - Public records. 
    All records of the municipality shall be public. 
Sec. 11.12. - Prior township ordinances and regulations. 
    All ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulation of the Township of Southfield, which are not inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter, in force and effect at the time of the adoption of this Charter, shall continue in full force as ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the city until repealed or amended by action of the proper authorities. 
Sec. 11.13. - Effect of illegality of any part of the Charter. 
    Should any provision or section or portion thereof, of this Charter be held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, illegal, or unconstitutional, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of this Charter as a whole, or of any remaining portion of such provision or section; it being hereby declared to be the intent of this Charter commission and of the electors who voted thereon, that such unconstitutionality or illegality shall not affect the validity of any other part of this Charter except that specifically affected by such holding. 
Sec. 11.14. - Tense. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided or indicated by the context, all words used in this Charter indicating the present tense shall not be limited to the time of the adoption of this Charter, but shall extend to and include the time of the happening of any event or requirement for which provision is made therein, either as a power, immunity, requirement, or prohibition. 
Sec. 11.15. - Corporate seal. 
    The city council shall provide a corporate seal for the City of Southfield. 
Sec. 11.16. - Headings. 
    The Charter and section headings used in this Charter are for convenience only and shall not be considered to be part of this Charter. 
Sec. 11.17. - Office quarters; clerical help and supplies. 
    The council shall provide such adequate quarters, supplies, equipment and clerical services as it may determine to be reasonably necessary to the efficient operation and administration of all city offices, services, departments, boards and commission. 
Sec. 11.18. - Amendments. 
    The Charter may be amended at any time by the legislative body on a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) vote of the members-elect, or by an initiatory petition in the manner provided in Act 279 of the Public Acts of 1909, as amended; provided however, that in case of an initiatory petition, the circulator thereof shall be a registered elector residing in the City of Southfield. 
    Should two (2) or more amendments adopted at the same election have conflicting provisions, the one receiving the largest affirmative votes shall prevail as to those provisions. 
(Referendum of 11-5-85) 
Sec. 11.19. - Nepotism. 
    Except and unless relatives by blood or marriage of the mayor, city clerk, treasurer, any councilman, municipal judge, associate judge, or the city administrator, within the second degree of consanguinity or affinity, are bona fide appointive officers or employees of the city at the time of the election of such officers or appointment of such city administrator, such relatives shall be disqualified from holding any appointive office or from being employed by the city, during the tenure of office of such mayor, clerk, treasurer, councilman, municipal judge, associate municipal judge or city administrator. 
Sec. 11.20. - Discrimination prohibited. 
    Except as permitted by law, the city shall not discriminate against a person with respect to hiring, contracting, purchasing, the use of city facilities or the provision of city services on the basis of religion, race, color, national origin, age, sex, height, weight, marital status, or disability. 
(Referendum of 11-7-00) 
Sec. 11.21. - Abstention from voting. 
    A member of council may only abstain from voting on a question in which he or she either has any financial interest other than the common public interest, or if voting on such question would raise an appearance of impropriety. The basis for the abstention shall be stated on the record. 
(Referendum of 11-6-01) 
Sec. 11.22. - Employees retirement board. 
    Effective March 31, 2003, the powers and responsibilities of the civil service commission with regard to the employee retirement plan, as set forth in section 6.5(b)2 of this Charter, shall be transferred to a board, consisting of seven (7) members, to be known as the employees retirement board. The members of the board, whose terms of office shall be established by ordinance, shall be appointed as follows: 
(a)  Three (3) of the members shall be the same members that serve on the civil service commission. 
(b)  One (1) member, excluding any Southfield Employee Retirement System member, shall be appointed by the mayor with the confirmation of the city council. 
(c)  Two (2) members shall be elected by the active employee members of the Southfield Employee Retirement System from their own number. 
(d)  One (1) member shall be elected by the retired employee members of the Southfield Employee Retirement System from their own number. 
(Referendum of 11-5-02) 
CHAPTER XII. - SCHEDULE 

Sec. 12.1. - Election on adoption of Charter. 
(a)  Date: This Charter shall be submitted to a vote of the qualified and registered electors of the City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, at a special election held on Monday, April 21, 1958. 
    At the said special election, the elective officers provided for in this Charter shall also be elected, in the manner as hereinafter provided. This Charter shall be adopted as the Charter for the City of Southfield if a majority of the ballots cast thereon are in favor of the adoption thereof. 
(b)  Form of ballot: The form of ballot for the submission of this Charter shall be as follows: 
OFFICIAL BALLOT 
Special election held in the City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, on the 21st day of April, 1958, upon the Charter thereof, and for elective city officers thereunder. 
(Instructions: Place a cross "X" in the square before the word "no" if against the proposed Charter.) 
Shall the proposed Charter for the City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, drafted by the charter commission elected on the 16th day of September, 1957, be adopted? 
? YES 
? NO 
(c)  Election commission: The Charter Commission of the City of Southfield shall be the election commission for this special election. The chairman of the charter commission shall be chairman of the election commission, and the secretary of the charter commission shall be the secretary of the election commission, and shall perform such duties in connection with the work of the election commission as are prescribed by the said commission and this Charter. 
(d)  Inspectors of election: The inspectors of election for this special election shall be those persons designated by the election commission at its meeting at which the proposed Charter is adopted by the charter commission. 
(e)  Board of canvassers: The board of canvassers for this special election shall be the members of the charter commission. The chairman of the charter commission shall be the chairman of the board of canvassers and the secretary of the charter commission shall be the secretary of the board of canvassers. The board of canvassers shall meet at the Township Hall, 26080 Berg Road, Southfield Township, Oakland County, Michigan, at 8:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, on the Thursday following this special election, and such board shall thereupon canvass the results of said election and certify the same. 
(f)  Registration: The secretary of the charter commission shall be in charge of the registration of electors of the City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, in accordance with the statute in such case made and provided all residents of the territory embraced within the territorial limits of the City of Southfield, who have the qualifications of electors and who have not previously registered in order to vote in the City of Southfield, (salmon card), thereof, shall be required to register in order to vote at this special election. The secretary shall have the power and authority to select and appoint such assistants as may be required to perform the registration of the electors. Registration shall be held in each voting precinct at the polling place on such days and between such hours as the secretary of the charter commission shall designate prior to the last day for receiving registrations, which date is the twenty fourth date of March, 1958, and on which later date, registration shall be made at the Township Hall between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time. All registration records shall be delivered to the city clerk of Southfield after the holding of the special election. 
(g)  Notice of registration: The secretary of the election commission shall give notice for the board of registration of the days, hours, and places that the registration of electors will be conducted by publishing the same in the Birmingham Eccentric, The Four Corners Press and the Southfield Sun, newspapers, on the thirteenth day of March, 1958, and the twentieth day of March, 1958, said newspapers being of general circulation, in the City of Southfield, the first of said publications to be not less than ten (10) days prior to the last day for receiving registrations and by posting copies thereof in at least two (2) of the most conspicuous places in each voting precinct. 
(h)  Notice of election: The secretary of the election commission shall cause to be published, with the publication of this Charter, in the Four Corners Press, a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Southfield, on the third day of April, 1958, and on the seventeenth day of April, 1958, a notice of this election and location of the polling places, that on the date fixed therefor, the question of adopting such proposed Charter will be voted on, and that the elective officers provided for in this Charter will be elected on the same date. Copies of such notice shall be posted, in at least two (2) of the most conspicuous places in each voting precinct within the proposed City of Southfield, not less than ten (10) days prior to such election. 
(i)  Voting precincts: The voting precincts and the polling places for this election shall conform as near as may be to the polling places and voting precincts now established in that portion of the Township of Southfield included in the territorial limits of the proposed City of Southfield. 
(j)  Procedure governing election: In all respects not otherwise provided for in Chapter III of this Charter, the election procedure shall be in accordance with the provisions of the other chapters of this Charter. 
Sec. 12.2. - First election of city officers. 
(a)  The first election of city officers provided for in this Charter shall be held on Monday, the twenty first day of April, 1958, in conjunction with the election of the adoption of the Charter. At such election, the voters shall be entitled to vote for not more than one (1) candidate for mayor; seven (7) candidates for councilman; one (1) candidate for clerk; one (1) candidate for treasurer; one (1) candidate for municipal judge; and one (1) candidate for associate municipal judge. 
    Terms of elective officers: All candidates, including the seven (7) members of the council elected at this election to adopt or reject this Charter shall hold their offices for a term commencing on the first Monday following the said election to adopt this Charter and ending when their respective successors have been duly elected and qualified at the regular city election held in the year 1961. 
(b)  Councilmen elected at regular city election in year 1961: At the regular city election held in the year 1961, there shall be elected seven (7) members of the council, the three (3) candidates receiving the highest number of votes for such office shall serve and hold their offices for a term of four (4) years, and the four (4) candidates receiving the next highest number of votes for such office shall serve and hold their offices for a term of two (2) years. All other officers elected at such election shall be elected in the manner, and shall serve and hold their respective offices for such term or terms, as is provided in this Charter with respect thereto. 
    At the regular city election held in the year 1963 and at all times thereafter, all elective city officers, including members of the council, shall be nominated, elected and shall take and hold their respective offices for such term or terms as is provided in this Charter with respect thereto. 
(c)  Nomination of candidates for elective offices: Candidates for the elective offices to be voted upon at this special election shall be nominated by petition in form, manner and substance as provided for in sections 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8 of this Charter, except that the petition shall be filed with the secretary of the election commission, or such other person designated by him, who shall perform all duties in connection with such nomination petitions as are required of the city clerk by this Charter, and the nomination petitions shall be filed not later than the twenty fourth day of March, 1958, at 4:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, with the secretary of the election commission, who shall make available, a supply of official petition forms as required in chapter III of this Charter, which petitions shall be made available for distribution on the twenty fourth day of February, 1958. The secretary of the election commission shall publish, in the three above-mentioned newspapers, a notice of the days permitted for filing nomination petitions, the number of signatures required and the number of persons to be elected to each office to be voted upon at said special election; other provisions of this Charter notwithstanding, the names of those candidates who shall file valid, proper and sufficient nominating petitions, and have the qualifications required for the respective office, and who have filed the statement of candidacy heretofore required in this Charter, shall be certified to the election commission to be placed upon the official ballot for such election. 
(d)  Residential requirements: The residential requirements for elective city officials to be elected at the first election of city officers to be held on the twenty first day of April, 1958, shall be deemed to have been satisfied if the officer shall have been a resident of the portion of the Township of Southfield incorporated within the territorial limits of the City of Southfield for at least one (1) year immediately prior to the election. 
(e)  Modification of form of nomination petition and statement of candidacy: The form of the nomination petition and statement of candidacy, and the attendant matters in connection therewith, shall be modified so as to comply with the requirements of this Charter. 
(f)  Other election procedure: In all other respects not otherwise provided for in this section, the procedure for the election of officers shall be in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. 
Sec. 12.3. - Effective date of Charter. 
    For the purpose of initiating the procedure for the election on the adoption of this Charter, and for nominating and electing the first elective city officers, the Charter shall take effect on the twenty sixth day of September, 1957. For all other purposes, this Charter shall take effect on the twenty eighth day of April, 1958, at 8:00 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, at which time the officers first elected under the provisions of the Charter shall assemble in the Township Hall, 26080 Berg Road, Southfield Township, Michigan, for the inaugural ceremonies. The meeting shall be called to order by the chairman of the charter commission and each elective city officer shall take and subscribe to his oath of office, as administered by said chairman and shall thereupon be qualified for and shall assume the duties of his office. 
Sec. 12.4. - Continuation of employment of township officers and employees. 
    After the effective date of this Charter, all appointive officers and employees of the Township of Southfield, if they shall so elect, shall respectively hold similar or corresponding offices or employment in the city until their successors are appointed and qualify, and they shall in all respects be subject to the provisions of this Charter. 
Sec. 12.5. - Interim financial provisions. 
    The period from the effective date of this Charter to June 30, 1958, inclusive, shall constitute a special interim fiscal budget and tax period to accomplish the transition from the Township of Southfield administration to the city administration. The budget for such special fiscal year shall be prepared and adopted under the direction of the city council as expeditiously as possible after the effective date of this Charter. A public hearing on such budget shall be held upon five (5) days' published notice of the date of such public hearing. At the time of adoption of such budget, the council shall appropriate the money needed for municipal purposes for the interim fiscal year period, and shall provide a levy of the amount necessary to be raised by taxes upon all real and personal property for such purposes. 
    Such tax levy shall not exceed three (3) mills upon the assessed value of all real and personal property subject to taxation in the city. Such levy shall be spread on the tax roll which becomes due and payable on July 1, 1958, and the amounts of the taxes for such two (2) levies may be combined for the purpose of convenience in the spreading of the roll and preparation of the tax bills. Taxes for the interim period shall be collected in all respects as provided in this Charter for the collection of city taxes. 
Sec. 12.6. - Borrowing powers. 
    The council shall have the power to borrow money in a sum not exceeding two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) in anticipation of the collection of interim tax and the 1958 tax to provide funds from which to operate the city until tax monies shall be available thereafter. 
Sec. 12.7. - Continuation of the functions and duties of the planning commission and zoning board of the Township of Southfield. 
    Upon the effective date of this Charter, the powers provided and granted in existing ordinances and bylaws of the Township of Southfield, to the extent that such ordinances or bylaws apply to the territory embraced within the City of Southfield, are hereby adopted and shall be and remain in force and effect until the controlling ordinance or bylaws have been revised, amended or repealed by council action. The council shall appoint members to the City of Southfield Zoning Board and Planning Commission in accordance with the provisions of this Charter on or before the first Monday of May. 
Sec. 12.8. - Township assets and liabilities. 
    As soon as practicable, the council shall take all necessary and proper action to obtain the division between the City of Southfield and the Township of Southfield, of the assets and liabilities of such township. 
Sec. 12.9. - Status of schedule chapter. 
    The purpose of this schedule chapter is to inaugurate the government of the City of Southfield under this Chapter, and to accomplish the transition from the township government to the city government, and it shall constitute a part of this Charter only to the extent and for the time required to accomplish such purpose. 
RESOLUTION OF ADOPTION OF THE CHARTER OF THE CITY OF SOUTHFIELD, OAKLAND COUNTY, MICHIGAN 
    At a regularly called meeting of the Charter Commission of the City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, held on the twenty fourth day of February, 1958, at 8:00 p.m. of said day, the following action was taken:

Carried by the following vote:

Nays: None.

CHARTER APPENDIX 
1., 2. 1970 PA 239, § 1; MCLA 168.644g 
Terms of office, extension (M.S.A. 6.1644(7)) 
    Sec. 644g. (1) A term of office shall not be shortened by the provisions of sections 644a to 644l. An officer scheduled by prior law to be elected at a time other than in November of an odd-numbered year shall not be elected on the date scheduled but shall continue in office until a successor takes office pursuant to the first odd year general election following that date. 
    (2) Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, any officer required to be elected at the odd-year general election, who by law is elected for a term of an odd number of years shall be elected hereafter for a term of one (1) year longer than provided by law. 
    (3) In home rule cities where the charter provides for the election of city officers at a time other than in November of odd-numbered years and provides that members of the governing body are not all to be elected in the same year, the governing body by ordinance adopted prior to April 1, 1971, may alter the length of terms now provided by charter to provide that the city may continue to elect part of the governing body at each election. A term shall not be extended beyond January following the first odd-numbered year election at which the officer would be elected pursuant to charter. A term shall not be for more than four (4) years. 
3. 1972 PA 8, § 1; MCLA 117.5c 
Officers compensation commission; creation; powers 
    In place of a charter provision existing on December 31, 1972, establishing the salaries or the procedure for determining salaries of elected officials, the governing body, may establish by ordinance the procedure described in this section, in which case the restriction contained in a charter provision with respect to changing salaries during term shall be inapplicable. 
4. 1976 PA 267, § 5; MCLA 15.265 
Notice of public meetings 
    Sec. 5. (1) A meeting of a public body shall not be held unless public notice is given as provided in this section by a person designated by the public body. 
    (2) For regular meetings of a public body, there shall be posed within ten (10) days after the first meeting of the public body in each calendar or fiscal year a public notice stating the dates, times, and places of its regular meetings. 
    (3) If there is a change in the schedule of regular meetings of a public body, there shall be posted within three (3) days after the meeting at which the change is made, a public notice stating the new dates, times, and places of its regular meetings. 
    (4) For a rescheduled regular or a special meeting of a public body, a public notice stating the date, time, and place of the meeting shall be posted at least eighteen (18) hours before the meeting. The requirement of eighteen-hour notice shall not apply to special meetings of subcommittees. 
    (5) A meeting of a public body which is recessed for more than thirty-six (36) hours shall be reconvened only after public notice, which is equivalent to that required under subsection (4) has been posed. If either house of the state legislature is adjourned or recessed for less than eighteen (18) hours, the notice provisions of subsection (4) are not applicable. Nothing in this section shall ban a public body from meeting in emergency session in the event of a severe and imminent threat to the health, safety, or welfare of the public when two-thirds of the members serving on the body decide that delay would be detrimental to efforts to lessen or respond to the threat. 
1976 PA 267, § 8; MCLA 15.268; Closed meetings 
    A public body may meet in closed session only for the following purposes: 
(a)  To consider the dismissal, suspension or disciplining of, or to hear complaints or charges brought against a public officer, employee, staff member, or individual agent, when the named person requests a closed hearing. 
(b)  To consider the dismissal, suspension, or disciplining of a student when the public body is part of the school district, intermediate school district, or institution of higher education which the student is attending, when the student or the student's parent or guardian requests a closed hearing. 
(c)  For strategy and negotiation sessions connected with the negotiation of a collective bargaining agreement when either negotiating party requests a closed hearing. 
(d)  To consider the purchase or lease of real property up to the time an option to purchase or lease that real property is obtained. 
(e)  To consult with its attorney regarding trial or settlement strategy in connection with specific pending litigation, but only when an open meeting would have a detrimental financial effect on the litigating or settlement position of the public body. 
(f)  To review the specific contents of an application for employment or appointment to a public office when the candidate requests that the application remain confidential. However, all interviews by a public body for employment or appointment to a public office shall be held in an open meeting pursuant to this act. 
5. See item 3. 
1968 PA 236, § 992B; MCLA 600.992B 
6. Municipal courts, retention in certain cities (M.S.A. 27A.9928) 
    Sec. 9928 (1) The district court shall not function nor shall district judges be elected in any district of the third class in which one (1) or more cities which maintain municipal or police courts and which contain, individually or in the aggregate, more than fifty (50) percent of the population of the district elect to retain their municipal or police courts by resolution adopted by their respective governing bodies within seven (7) days after the effective date of this section. 
    (2) Municipal and police courts retained under the provisions of this section shall perform all duties and powers which by law may be performed by justices of the peace and the circuit court commissioners. 
    (3) The jurisdiction of such municipal or police courts is limited to their respective cities except that where the district contains one (1) or more townships such courts shall exercise the same jurisdiction and powers in such townships as they exercise in their respective cities. 
    (4) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a city shall not establish a municipal or police court after July 1, 1968. 
    (5) The city clerks of cities adopting resolutions under this section shall file copies of such resolutions with the court administrator within thirty (30) days after the adoption of such resolutions. 
    This act is ordered to take immediate effect. Approved June 17, 1968. 
7. 1968 PA 153, § 1; MCLA 46.401 
Board of supervisors; apportionment; initial plan, filing deadline; nominating petitions and litigation in 1968 
    Sec. 1. On or before May 15, 1967, and in subsequent years within sixty (60) days after the publication of the latest United States official decennial census figures, the county apportionment commission in each county of this state shall apportion the county into not less than five (5) nor more than thirty-five (35) county supervisor districts as nearly of equal population as is practicable and within the limitations of section 2. In counties under seventy-five thousand (75,000), upon the effective date of this act, the boards of supervisors of such counties shall have not to exceed thirty (30) days into which to apportion their county into supervisor districts in accordance with the provisions of this act. If at the expiration of the time as set forth in this section a board of supervisors has not so apportioned itself, the county apportionment commission shall proceed to apportion the county under the provisions of this act. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the initial plan for apportionment of the boards of supervisors shall be filed not later than 4:00 p.m. June 25, 1968. In any county in which a plan is not filed by 4:00 p.m. on June 25, 1968, seven (7) supervisors shall be elected at large in 1968 for one-year terms. In 1968 only, the deadline for filing nominating petitions or filing fees shall be 4:00 p.m. July 2, 1968. Because of the necessity of ensuring orderly election procedures for the year 1968, in no event will litigation affect, alter, change, amend or delay any apportionment plan adopted under this act insofar as 1968 supervisor elections are concerned.

Title I - ADMINISTRATION[1]

Cross reference- Utilities and services, tit. II; parks and public grounds, tit. III. 

CHAPTER 1. - ADOPTION, CONTENTS AND INTERPRETATION 
    An ordinance to provide for the exercise of certain municipal powers of the City of Southfield and for the health, safety and welfare of persons and property in the city, and to provide penalties for the violation of the provisions thereof. 
    The City of Southfield ordains: 

Sec. 1.1. - Publication and distribution of Code. 
    Publication of the within codification of the ordinances of the City of Southfield is hereby directed. One hundred (100) copies of the Code shall be published in loose-leaf form and shall be distributed as follows: 
Officer No. Copies Mayor ..... 1 Each councilman ..... 1 Clerk ..... 2 City administrator ..... 1 Director of public service ..... 1 Attorney ..... 1 Treasurer ..... 1 Assessor ..... 1 City engineer ..... 1 Health officer ..... 1 Chief of police ..... 2 Chief of fire department ..... 1 Superintendent of parks and recreation ..... 1 Director of the department of building and safety engineering ..... 1 District judges ..... 3  
The remaining copies shall be held by the city clerk for distribution or sale as directed by the city council. The clerk shall keep one (1) of the copies of the Code assigned to him available for public inspection during office hours. 
Sec. 1.2. - Amendment procedure. 
    This Code shall be amended by ordinance. The title of each amendatory ordinance, adapted to the particular circumstances and purposes of the amendment, shall be substantially as follows: 
(1)  To amend any section: 
AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND SECTION _____ (or SECTIONS _____ AND _____) OF CHAPTER _____ OF TITLE _____ OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF SOUTHFIELD. 
(2)  To insert a new section, chapter or title: 
AN ORDINANCE TO AMEND THE CODE OF THE CITY OF SOUTHFIELD BY ADDING A NEW SECTION (_____ NEW SECTIONS, A NEW CHAPTER, or A NEW TITLE, as the case may be) WHICH NEW SECTION (SECTIONS, CHAPTER or TITLE) SHALL BE DESIGNATED AS SECTION _____ (SECTIONS _____ AND _____) OF CHAPTER _____ OF TITLE _____ (or proper designation if a chapter or title is added) OF SAID CODE. 
(3)  To repeal a section, chapter or title: 
AN ORDINANCE TO REPEAL SECTION _____ (SECTIONS _____ AND _____), CHAPTER _____, TITLE _____, (as the case may be) OF THE CODE OF THE CITY OF SOUTHFIELD. 
Sec. 1.3. - Publication and distribution of amendments. 
    Amendments to the Code shall be published as required by the Charter of the City of Southfield and not less than one hundred (100) copies of each amendment shall be published in loose-leaf form suitable for insertion in the loose-leaf copies of this Code. The city clerk shall distribute such copies to the officers of the city having copies of the Code assigned to them. Each officer assigned a copy of the Code shall be responsible for maintaining the same and for the proper insertion of amendatory pages as received. Each copy of the Code shall remain the property of the city and shall be turned over by each officer having custody thereof upon expiration of his term of office to his successor or to the city clerk, in case he shall have no successor. 
Sec. 1.4. - Contents of Code. 
    This code contains all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City of Southfield and includes ordinances dealing with municipal administration, utilities and services, parks and public grounds, streets and sidewalks, zoning and planning, food and health, businesses and trades, building, electrical, heating and plumbing regulations, police regulations and traffic regulations, and excludes ordinances granting franchises and special privileges, establishing sewer and other public improvement districts, providing for the construction of particular sewers, streets or sidewalks, or for the improvement thereof, and for the construction and improvement of other public works, authorizing the borrowing of money or the issuance of bonds, and ordinances relating to the compensation to be paid particular officers and employees as distinguished from any ordinance establishing a general compensation plan. Ordinances establishing voting precincts shall not be deemed part of this Code. 
    The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as repealing or in any way affecting Ordinance 678, as amended, or as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. References in this Code to chapter 45 shall be deemed to refer to Ordinance 678 until Ordinance 678 or a zoning ordinance which supersedes Ordinance 678 is added to this Code. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature in effect on the effective date of this Code are hereby repealed except as otherwise provided herein; provided, however, that any sections or parts of any such ordinance which are not permanent and general in nature as herein defined and which are severable from the remainder of such ordinance are saved from repeal. Ordinances hereafter adopted which are not of a general or permanent nature shall be numbered consecutively, authenticated, published and recorded in the book of ordinances, but shall not be prepared for insertion in this Code, nor be deemed a part hereof. 
Sec. 1.5. - Short title. 
    This Code may be known and cited as the "Southfield City Code." 
Sec. 1.6. - Responsibility. 
    Whenever any act is prohibited by this Code, by an amendment thereof, or by any rule or regulation adopted thereunder, such prohibition shall extend to and include the causing, securing, aiding or abetting of another person to do such act. 
Sec. 1.6A. - Attempts. 
    Whenever any act is prohibited by this Code, by an amendment thereof, or by any rule or regulation adopted thereunder, such prohibition shall extend to and include the attempt to commit such act as defined and proscribed in this section. Any person who shall attempt to commit any offense prohibited by this Code, and in such attempt shall do any act towards the commission of such offense, but shall fail in the perpetration, or shall be intercepted or prevented in the execution thereof, when no other express provision is made by this Code for the punishment or sanction of such attempt, shall be subject to the following punishment or sanction: 
(1)  If the offense so attempted to be committed is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, the person convicted of such attempt shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment for not more than forty-five (45) days, or by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and costs of prosecution, or by both such fine and imprisonment; but in no case shall the fine exceed one-half of the maximum fine established for the completed offense. 
(2)  If the offense so attempted to be committed is a civil infraction or civil offense proscribable by a civil fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and costs of prosecution of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), the person found responsible for such attempt shall be responsible for a civil infraction or civil offense, proscribable by a civil fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) and costs of prosecution of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00), but in no case shall the fine exceed one-half of the maximum fine established for the completed offense. 
(Ord. No. 1066, § 1, 8-24-81) 
Sec. 1.7. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this Code and any amendment thereto, shall, for the purposes of this Code, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Charter. The word "Charter" means the Charter of the City of Southfield. 
(2)  City. The word "city" means the City of Southfield. 
(3)  Conjunctive, disjunctive. Conjunctive and disjunctive words may be interchangeable to effect the purpose of any provisions. 
(4)  Council, city council. The words "council" and "city council" mean the Council of the City of Southfield. 
(5)  County. The word "county" means the County of Oakland. 
(6)  Gender. Words importing masculine gender shall apply to females and to firms, associations, partnerships and corporations. 
(7)  Health officer shall mean the Oakland County Health Department and its officers. 
(8)  Joint authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to three (3) or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it is otherwise expressly declared in the ordinance granting the authority. 
(9)  Month. The word "month" shall be construed to mean a calendar month. 
(10)  Number. Words in either the singular or plural numbers shall include either or both numbers and may apply in any instance to a particular person or persons. 
(11)  Oath, affirmation, sworn, affirmed. The word "oath" shall be construed to include the word "affirmation" in all cases where by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath; and in like cases the word "sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed." 
(12)  Officers. The several officers' titles mean such officers of the city, or their respective deputies or agents. 
(13)  Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
(14)  Person. The word "person" includes firms, joint adventures, partnerships, corporations, clubs and all associations or organizations of natural persons, either incorporated or unincorporated, howsoever operating or named, and whether acting by themselves or by a servant, agent or fiduciary, and includes all legal representatives, heirs, successors and assigns thereof. 
(15)  Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following," when used by way of reference to any title, chapter or section of this Code shall be construed to mean the title, chapter or section next preceding or next following that in which such reference is made, unless when some other title, chapter or section is expressly designated in such reference. 
(16)  Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
(17)  Public place. The words "public place" mean any street, alley, park, cemetery, public building or any place of business or assembly open to the public or frequented by the public. 
(18)  Seal. In all cases in which the seal of any court or public office shall be required to be affixed to any paper issuing from such court or office, the word "seal" shall be construed to mean the impression of such seal on such paper alone, as well as the impression of such seal affixed thereto by means of a wafer or wax. 
(19)  Signature, subscription. The words "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write. 
(20)  State. The word "state" means the State of Michigan. 
(21)  Sundays, legal holidays. Whenever any act required to be done pursuant to the provisions of any ordinance falls on a Sunday or legal holiday, that act shall be performed on the next succeeding business day. 
(22)  Tense. Words used in the present or past tense shall be construed as including the future as well as the present or past. 
(23)  Time. Whenever time is referred to, it means Eastern Standard Time or the time officially in force in the city. 
(24)  Titles, headings and catchlines. The key words used in this Code as headings, titles or catchlines for chapters, sections and subsections are inserted for convenience and to facilitate the use of same, and such words shall not be construed to limit or affect the meaning of any of the provisions of this Code. 
(25)  Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
(26)  Written, in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" may include any form of reproduction or expression of language. 
(27)  Year. The word "year" shall be construed to mean a calendar year; and the word "year" alone shall be equivalent to the words "year of our Lord." 
Sec. 1.8. - Officers; acts required; performance, authority. 
    Whenever any act is required to be done pursuant to the provisions of this Code by any designated officer or official of the city and such officer or official has not been appointed, such act shall be performed by the city administrator. Whenever in accordance with the provisions of this Code any specific act is required to be done by any designated officer or official of the city, such act may be performed by any city employee duly authorized to perform that act by such officer or official. 
Sec. 1.9. - Computation of time. 
    Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceedings shall be had, the day on which such notice is given shall not be counted in computing the time. The last day if it is Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday shall not be counted, in which event the period of time runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
Sec. 1.10. - Repeal of repealing ordinance; effect. 
    Whenever a title, chapter or section of this Code or any part thereof is repealed by a subsequent ordinance, such title, chapter or section of this Code or part thereof so repealed shall not be revived by the repeal of such subsequent repealing ordinance. 
Sec. 1.11. - Saving clause. 
    The repeal of any title, chapter or section of this Code or part thereof shall not release or relinquish any penalty, forfeiture or liability incurred under such title, chapter or section of this Code or any part thereof, unless the repealing act shall so expressly provide, and such title, chapter or section of this Code or part thereof shall be treated as still remaining in force for the purpose of instituting or sustaining any proper action or prosecution for the enforcement of such penalty, forfeiture or liability. 
Sec. 1.12. - Title of officer to include deputy or subordinate. 
    Whenever by the provisions of this Code any officer of the city is assigned any duty or empowered to perform any act or duty, the title of such officer shall mean and include such officer or his deputy or authorized subordinate. 
Sec. 1.13. - Single lot assessments. 
(1)  When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single premises, which expense is chargeable against such premises and the owner thereof under the provisions of this Code and is not of that class required to be prorated among the several lots and parcels of land in a special assessment district, an account of the labor, material, and service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the premises upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, together with a notice of assessment proceedings, shall be given to each owner of or party in interest in property to be assessed whose name appears on the last local tax assessment roll for ad valorem tax purposes that has been reviewed by the local board of review, as supplemented by any subsequent changes in the names or the addresses of the owners or parties listed on that roll. 
(a)  The account shall specify the sum due and payable to the city in payment of the expense, without penalty, within thirty (30) days of the date of the account, and shall further specify the sum due and payable upon expiration of thirty (30) days as hereafter provided. If the account is not fully paid within the initial thirty-day period, a ten (10) percent penalty on the amount due shall be assessed by the city and paid by the property owner. 
(b)  The notice shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the individual at the city designated by the city administrator having responsibility and authority to answer questions, correct errors, and resolve disputes regarding the account within the thirty-day period. 
(2)  Should any owner or party in interest in the property to be assessed find any inaccuracy, irregularity, error, or question in the account or in the notice of assessment proceedings described in subsection one above, the owner shall be entitled to appeal to the individual designated in subsection (1)(b) above. If requested by the owner, the individual designated in subsection (1)(b) above shall schedule a hearing and provide the owner or interested party with an opportunity to be heard in regard to the account or proceedings. Action to assess the account to the single lot or parcel shall be stayed until such time as a written finding and order is issued and given to the owner or interested party initiating the appeal. The individual designated in subsection (1)(b) above may order any correction, cancellation, or modification in the account that he or she determines to be substantiated by the facts disclosed at the hearing. 
(3)  On or before December 31 of each year the individual designated in subsection (1)(b) above shall report all accounts to the city assessor that are thirty (30) or more days delinquent. 
(4)  The assessor shall prepare an assessment roll or rolls covering all such charges reported under subsection (3) above. Such roll or rolls shall be filed with the clerk who shall advise the council of the filing of the same, and the council shall thereupon schedule a hearing for the fourth Monday in the month of April for the confirmation of the assessment roll. The assessment roll shall be open to public inspection for a period of seven (7) days before the council shall meet to review the roll and hear complaints from any owner or interested party. If for any reason a quorum of council members is not present at the meeting on the fourth Monday in April, the roll shall be considered for confirmation at the next regular meeting of the council at which a quorum is present. 
(5)  Such assessments and all interest and charges thereon shall, from the date of confirmation of the roll, be and remain a lien upon the property assessed, of the same character and effect as the lien created by section 1.237 of the Code. Such assessment shall be added by the treasurer to the next general city tax roll or general county and school tax roll, as shall be convenient, and shall thereafter be collected and returned in the same manner as general city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 11-26-90; Ord. No. 1585 , §§ 1, 2, 6-19-11) 
Cross reference- Special assessments for street improvements, § 1.221 et seq. 
Sec. 1.14. - Notice. 
(1)  Unless a specific method of service is required by another statute or ordinance, notice regarding sidewalk repairs, sewer or water connections, dangerous structures, abating a nuisance or any other act, the expense of which, if performed by the city, may be assessed against the premises under the provisions of this Code, may be served: 
(a)  By serving the notice in the same manner as service of summons and complaint in a civil matter as provided by Michigan Statute or the Michigan Court Rules. 
(b)  By sending a copy of the notice to the owner at his or her last known address by enclosing the notice in a sealed envelope with first class postage fully prepaid, addressed to the owner, and depositing the envelope and its contents in the United States mail. Service in this manner is complete at the time of mailing. 
(c)  If the owner is unknown, by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the premises for five (5) days. 
(2)  Any person who shall remove, deface, mutilate, conceal or alter an official notice posted under the authority of subsection (1)(c) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1312, § 1, 11-26-90) 
Cross reference- City water utility, § 2.31 et seq.; city sewer service, § 2.101; sidewalks, § 4.61 et seq.; housing code, § 8.141 et seq.; building code, § 8.201 et seq.; nuisances, § 9.1 et seq. 
Sec. 1.15. - Penalty. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by this Code for any particular provision or section, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Code or any rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each act of violation and every day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any section of this Code whether or not such penalty is re-enacted in the amendatory ordinance. 
Sec. 1.16. - Severability. 
    It is the legislative intent of the council, in adopting this Code, that all provisions and sections of this Code be liberally construed to protect and preserve the peace, health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city and should any provision or section of this Code be held unconstitutional or invalid, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of any of the remaining provisions or sections, it being the intent that this Code shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of any provision or section thereof. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply to the amendment of any section of this Code whether or not the wording of this section is set forth in the amendatory ordinance. 
Sec. 1.17. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance Code shall take effect in accordance with the ordinance enacting it. 
Sec. 1.18. - Enforcement. 
    Except as otherwise specified in this Code, the responsibility for enforcing all provisions of this Code shall be with the city police department. 
CHAPTER 2. - VOTING PRECINCTS 

Sec. 1.31. - Precincts established. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Act 271, Public Acts of 1955, State of Michigan, as amended, and in accordance with section 3.1 of the Charter, the official precinct boundaries for the precincts for voting in elections conducted by and within the city shall be established by ordinance. Such ordinances shall be deemed special ordinances and shall not be published as a part of this Code. 
Charter reference- Duty to establish election precincts, § 3.1. 
Cross reference- Elections, § 1.381 et seq. 
Note- The city has adopted Ordinance No. 1494 which establishes new boundaries for its voting precincts and reducing the number of precincts from fifty (50) to forty-three (43). The ordinance was introduced and enacted as an emergency ordinance on March 17, 2003, and will become effective upon publication of this summary. A true copy of Ordinance No. 1494 may be inspected and obtained at the Southfield City Clerk's Office, 26000 Evergreen Road, Southfield, MI 48076. 
CHAPTER 3. - ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICE 

Sec. 1.91. - Division of administrative service. 
    The administrative service of the city shall be divided into the following offices and departments, each of which shall be the responsibility of and under the control of a head as listed opposite such office or department, under the supervision of such board, commission or other authority as may be prescribed by the Charter or this Code. 
Office or department Official head Office of clerk City clerk Office of treasurer City treasurer Office of director of public safety Director of public safety Department of police Police chief Department of fire Fire chief Department of public service Director of public service Department of building and safety engineering Director of building and safety engineering Department of parks and recreation Superintendent of parks and recreation Department of planning City planner Department of health Health officer Department of law City attorney Assessing department Director of assessments  
    The administrative officers of the city shall have the duties and responsibilities prescribed in the Charter and in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 942, § 1, 7-18-77) 
ARTICLE I. - CLERK, ASSESSOR, TREASURER AND CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 1.92. - Clerk, assessor, treasurer and city administrator. 
    The clerk, assessor, treasurer and city administrator shall have the duties and responsibilities detailed for such offices in the Charter, this Code and the statutes of the state. 
Charter reference- Powers and duties of clerk, § 5.7; city treasurer, §§ 5.8, 5.9; city administrator, § 6.1; city assessor, § 6.4. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF REVIEW[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Time for making assessment rolls, § 9.8; board of review, § 9.10; notice of meeting of board of review, § 9.11. 

Sec. 1.93. - Delivery of roll. 
    On or before the first day of the meeting of the board of review in each year the assessor shall complete and certify an assessment roll in the manner and form required by the Charter. On the date and at the time of convening the board of review in each year, the assessor shall deliver the completed assessment roll to the board of review. The roll shall not be removed from the meeting place of the board of review while the board of review is in session, and when the board of review is not in session, the roll shall be returned to the office of the assessor of the city for safekeeping. 
Sec. 1.94. - Meetings. 
    The board of review shall convene at 9:00 a.m. on the first Monday in March in each year at the city civic center. The city council may provide by resolution that further meetings for that year shall be held at another location within the city. The board of review shall continue in session for a minimum of six (6) hours during that day for a minimum of six (6) hours on each of the following three (3) days, for the purpose of examining and reviewing the assessment roll of the city. The city council may extend the period for reviewing the assessment roll, but the review of assessments by the board of review shall be completed on or before the first Monday in April. All business conducted by the board of review shall be at meetings of the board of review held in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. On the first day of its meeting in each year, the board of review shall elect one of its members chairman for the year. 
Sec. 1.95. - Terms. 
    The terms of office of the members of the board of review shall be as follows: One (1) shall terminate on June 30, 1964; one (1) shall terminate on June 30, 1965; and one (1) shall terminate on June 30, 1966. Commencing July 1, 1964, the term of office of any member thereafter appointed shall be three (3) years unless such appointment shall be to fill a portion of an unexpired term. If the appointment is to fill a portion of an unexpired term, the term of such member so appointed shall expire at the end of the unexpired term. 
Sec. 1.96. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the members of the board of review shall be as set by the council from time to time by resolution. 
Secs. 1.97-1.100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Police department, § 6.6. 
Cross reference- Police regulations, tit. IX; city constables, § 9.401 et seq.; traffic, tit. X. 

Sec. 1.101. - Department of police. 
    The department of police shall be headed by the chief of police who shall be the commanding officer of the police force. He shall direct the police work of the city and be responsible for the enforcement of law and order. 
Sec. 1.102. - Functions of police department. 
    The police work of the city shall consist of the following functions: 
(1)  The operation of motor and foot patrol units for routine investigation and the general maintenance of law and order; 
(2)  The maintenance of the central complaint desk at central police headquarters, the maintaining and supervising of police records, criminal and noncriminal identification, property identification, custody of property and the operation of detention quarters; 
(3)  The investigation of crimes, elimination of illegal liquor traffic and vice, and the preparation of evidence for the prosecution of criminal cases and offenses in violation of the ordinances of the city; 
(4)  The prevention and control of juvenile delinquency, the handling of cases in which women are involved, the removal of crime hazards and the coordination of community agencies interested in crime prevention; 
(5)  The control of traffic, traffic education programs, school patrols and coordination of traffic violation prosecutions. The maintenance and erection of traffic signs and the painting of street and crosswalk lanes shall be a joint responsibility of the police department and the department of public service; 
(6)  City parking lots and meter operation and control. 
Sec. 1.103. - Department rules. 
    The chief of police may prescribe rules for the government of police officers of the city, which shall be entered in a book of police department rules and orders and may be amended or revoked by the police chief. Such rules may establish one (1) or more divisions within the police department, each of which divisions may be charged with performing one (1) or more of the functions of the police department enumerated in section 1.102. Any such division shall be supervised by a qualified officer of the police department, who shall be responsible for the particular functions of the police department assigned to the particular division supervised by him. It shall be the duty of all members of the police force to comply with such rules and orders while effective. 
Sec. 1.104. - Acting chief. 
    The chief of police shall not leave the city without notifying the city administrator in cases of necessity arising from emergency. In case of the absence from the city of the chief of police, or his disability or inability from any cause to act as chief of police, the city administrator shall designate and appoint some other members of the police department to act as chief among such absence or disability. 
Sec. 1.105. - Monthly reports. 
    The chief of police shall report monthly to the city council all arrests made by the department, the disposition of persons arrested, and the number of persons remaining in confinement for ordinance violations, and such other information as the city council shall require. 
Secs. 1.106-1.115. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1314, § 1, adopted November 26, 1990, repealed former §§ 1.106-1.110 in their entirety. The aforesaid sections were concerned with lost property, and derived from the Code of 1976. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Fire department, § 6.7. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention regulations, § 9.181 et seq. 

Sec. 1.116. - Department of fire. 
    The department of fire shall be headed by the fire chief, who shall be charged with the prevention and extinguishment of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, the removal of fire hazards, the performance of other public services of an emergency nature assigned to it, and the conducting of an educational fire prevention program. 
Sec. 1.117. - Department rules. 
    The fire chief shall adopt rules and regulations for the government of the department which shall be entered in a book of fire department rules and which may be changed and repealed by the fire chief. Such rules and regulations shall designate the chain of command for the department so that in the absence or disability of the chief, the responsibility for the operation of the department shall immediately and automatically be vested in the next ranking officer or member of the department present. 
Sec. 1.118. - Department equipment. 
    The fire chief shall be responsible for the maintenance and care of all property and equipment used by the fire department. 
Sec. 1.119. - Enforce fire laws. 
    It shall be the duty of the fire chief to enforce all state laws and provisions of this Code governing the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires; 
(2)  The storage and use of explosives and flammables; 
(3)  The maintenance of fire alarm systems, both automatic and private, and all fire-extinguishing equipment; 
(4)  The maintenance and use of fire escapes; 
(5)  The maintenance of fire protection and the elimination of fire hazards in all buildings and structures; 
(6)  The maintenance and adequacy of fire exits from factories, schools, hotels, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters and all other places in which numbers of persons work or congregate for any purpose. 
Sec. 1.120. - Other duties. 
    The fire chief shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Investigate the origin, cause and circumstances of all fires. 
(2)  Issue all orders necessary for the enforcement of state laws and provisions of this Code. 
(3)  Require and supervise from time to time fire drills from all schools and educational institutions as required by law. 
Secs. 1.121-1.124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 1.125. - Creation of office. 
    There is hereby created the office of director of public safety who shall be in immediate charge of the police department, fire department and civil defense department of the city and who shall be directly responsible to the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 942, § 2, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 1.126. - Appointment; compensation. 
    The director of public safety shall be appointed by the city administrator with the consent of the council. His compensation shall be fixed by the council. 
(Ord. No. 942, § 2, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 1.127. - Function. 
    The director of public safety shall have full and complete administrative control over the fire, police and civil defense departments. 
(Ord. No. 942, § 2, 7-18-77) 
Secs. 1.128-1.130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICE 

Sec. 1.131. - Department of public service. 
(1)  The department of public service shall consist of the director of public service and such employees as the director of public service shall deem necessary and appoint, subject to section 6.5 of the Charter. 
(2)  The director of public service shall be appointed in accordance with section 6.1 of the Charter, and shall be responsible directly to the city administrator for the management and operation of the department. 
(3)  The director of public service shall be responsible for all matters relating to the management, maintenance and operation of the physical properties of the city which are not assigned by Charter or this Code to other city officers. 
Charter reference- Department of public works, § 6.8. 
Sec. 1.132. - Organization and functions. 
    The department of public service shall be divided into the following divisions: 
(1)  Highway division: Shall have charge of the maintenance of all improved and unimproved street surfaces, bridges, cleaning of improved streets, removal of snow, and such other problems of maintenance and service as may be required of the division by the director of public service. 
(2)  Water division: Shall have charge of the operation and maintenance of the city water distribution system including supervision of construction of water mains, service connections, installation and repair of meters and meter readings. 
(3)  Sewer division: Shall have charge of the operation and maintenance of the city sanitary sewer system, including supervision of construction of sanitary sewers, service connections, pumping stations and related appurtenances. 
(4)  Sanitation division: Shall have charge of the collection and disposal of refuse from residential units within the city. 
(5)  Public buildings and equipment division: Shall have charge of the maintenance of all public buildings and motorized equipment not assigned by the Charter or this Code to other city departments. 
(6)  Engineering division: Shall perform all engineering services for the department and for such other departments of the city as may from time to time be required. 
Cross reference- Garbage and rubbish, § 2.1 et seq.; city water utility, § 2.31 et seq.; city sewer service, § 2.101 et seq.; streets, § 4.1 et seq. 
Secs. 1.133, 1.134. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENT OF BUILDING AND SAFETY ENGINEERING 

Sec. 1.135. - Department of building and safety engineering. 
    The department of building and safety engineering shall be headed by the director of the department of building and safety engineering. He shall be responsible for the issuance of all permits and the inspection of all work done under the provisions of the heating, electrical, plumbing and building codes of the city and the safety inspection of all premises, including structures thereon, and the enforcement of zoning and housing regulations of the city. 
Charter reference- Department of building and safety engineering, § 6.12. 
Cross reference- Zoning regulations, ch. 45; housing code, § 8.141 et seq.; building code, § 8.201 et seq.; electrical code, § 8.401 et seq.; plumbing code, § 8.451 et seq. 
Secs. 1.136, 1.137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION 

Sec. 1.138. - Department of parks and recreation. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall be headed by the superintendent of parks and recreation. This department shall have charge of the control and regulation of the planting of trees and of the planting, development, maintenance, management and operation of parks, boulevards, recreation facilities and all city cemeteries. It shall also have all powers and duties expressed in the Charter. 
Charter reference- Department of parks and recreation, § 6.10. 
Cross reference- Park regulations, § 3.1 et seq.; tree regulations, § 3.21 et seq.; city cemeteries, § 3.51 et seq.; recreation, amusements and games, § 7.251 et seq. 
Secs. 1.139, 1.140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PLANNING DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 1.141. - Planning department. 
    The planning department shall be headed by the city planner who shall be responsible to the city council. He shall make the necessary studies and surveys of matters relating to city growth and development, advise the council as to the implementation of the city plan, furnish technical advice and assistance in planning and zoning matters and furnish such information and data to the city planning commission as it may require in the performance of its duties and functions. 
Charter reference- Planning department, § 6.11. 
Cross reference- Zoning and planning, tit. V. 
Sec. 1.142. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - OFFICIAL SEAL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Council to provide corporate seal, § 11.15. 

Sec. 1.143. - Custody of seal. 
    The official seal of the city shall be in the custody of the city clerk, who shall be responsible for the safeguarding of such seal. 
Sec. 1.144. - Use of seal. 
    The official seal of the city shall be used whenever authorized by the city council. Copies, facsimiles or reproductions of such seal may be used by the clerk, the mayor and the city council in connection with the exercise of the duties of their respective offices. Any other use of the seal, or a copy, facsimile or reproduction thereof, is hereby prohibited unless express permission is given for such use by the city council. 
ARTICLE XI. - DEPUTIES 

Sec. 1.145. - Appointment. 
    The mayor may appoint a deputy assessor and a deputy planner with the consent of the city council. In case of a vacancy in the office of the city assessor or city planner, or the inability to perform the duties of the office by reason of sickness, absence from the city, or other cause, such deputies shall, in each case, possess all the powers and authority of their superior officer. Such deputies shall be paid a salary as the city council may from time to time determine. 
ARTICLE XII. - DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES 

Sec. 1.146. - Organization. 
(1)  The department of human resources shall be in the immediate charge of the director of human resources, who shall be responsible directly to the city administrator. 
(2)  The department of human resources shall be administered as a regular department of the city government. The responsibility of the department of human resources shall include youth employment-manpower, Southfield-Lathrup Youth Services and the parent-youth guidance commission, all of which shall operate as divisions under the department of human resources. 
(3)  The department of human resources through the above-mentioned divisions and the Special Help Program shall be responsible for upgrading the human condition of city residents of every age. Services provided through this department include, but are not limited to: employment counseling and aid in job placement; individual and group counseling for persons or families; counseling and short-term aid for people with financial difficulties; home visits to shut-ins, senior citizens and others with particular problems requiring special care; and a referral source to departments and agencies which can provide needed services for clients. 
(4)  The parent-youth guidance commission shall be governed by a commission of citizens appointed by the city council under chapter 4 of this Code. It is the duty of this commission to promote programs designed to prevent delinquency and neglect among the youth of the community (See chapter 4). 
(5)  An advisory board known as the Southfield-Lathrup Youth Services Advisory Board is constituted for the purpose of giving professional and community direction and input to the Youth Services and Youth Employment-Manpower Divisions. This board is made up of representatives of sponsoring agencies, namely the city council, the Southfield-Lathrup School Board and the Lathrup Village City Council, as well as citizens representing the various helping professions and the community at large. 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 1.151 et seq. 
CHAPTER 4. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Southfield-Lathrup Youth Services Advisory Board, § 1.146; unemployment compensation appeal board, § 1.264 et seq.; administrative civil service commission, § 1.338; City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board, § 3.75 et seq.; historic designation advisory board, § 5.603; historic district commission, § 5.604; mechanical code board of appeals, § 8.258; board of electrical examiners, § 8.423; plumbing code board of appeals, § 8.458; cable communications commission, § 12.10 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1.151. - General provisions. 
    All boards and commissions existing at the time of the adoption of this Code shall be continued and the members serving thereon shall remain in office for the duration of the term for which they were appointed. 
Sec. 1.152. - Vacancies. 
    Unless otherwise provided, any vacancy occurring in the membership of any board or commission shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in the manner provided for original appointment. 
Sec. 1.153. - Compensation. 
    Unless otherwise provided, all members of boards and commissions shall serve without compensation as members thereof. 
Sec. 1.154. - Residency requirements. 
(1)  All persons who are appointed or reappointed to any board or commission, now existing or hereafter created, with the exception of the parent-youth guidance commission as provided for in sections 1.165 through 1.168 of this Code, shall be a bona fide resident of the city or must establish such residency in the city within six (6) months after receiving such appointment. A "bona fide resident" shall be deemed to be a person having actual and physical domicile within the city; where such person normally eats, sleeps, and maintains his/her normal and customary personal and household effects. 
(2)  Upon any member of a board or commission failing to establish and/or maintain bona fide residency within the city as provided herein, such member's office shall thereby be deemed vacant and shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in the manner provided for original appointment. 
(3)  Persons appointed or reappointed to a board or commission which is formed jointly between Southfield and another public entity may be residents of either the city or such other public entity. 
(4)  Upon a specific finding by the city council that a nonresident person proposed to be appointed or reappointed to a board or commission possesses certain expertise, experience or technical skill which would promote or enhance the best interests of the city, the city council may, by an affirmative vote of at least five (5) members, waive or modify the condition of residency with respect to such person. 
(5)  All members serving on any board or commission on the date this section shall become effective, who are not bona fide residents of the city, may remain in office for the duration of the term for which they were appointed, but may not be reappointed unless they establish and maintain residency within the city as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1233, § 1, 8-24-87; Ord. No. 1259, § 1, 1-23-69) 
Secs. 1.155-1.160. - Reserved.

    The civil service commission, the board of appeals, the parks and recreation board, the planning commission, the fire and police department retirement board, and the library board shall be organized and have the powers and duties as prescribed by law and the Charter.

ARTICLE IV. - SOUTHFIELD HOUSING COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Housing code, § 8.141 et seq.; fair neighborhood practices, § 9.381 et seq. 

Sec. 1.171. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to Public Act No. 18 of the Extra Session of 1933, as amended, there is hereby created in and for the city a commission to be known as the Southfield Housing Commission. 
Sec. 1.172. - Membership; appointment; terms; compensation. 
    The housing commission shall consist of five (5) members to be appointed by the city administrator. The term of office of the members of the commission shall be five (5) years. Members of the first commission existing under this article shall be appointed for the terms of one (1) year, two (2) years, three (3) years, four (4) years and five (5) years respectively, and annually thereafter one (1) member shall be appointed for the term of five (5) years. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation and may be removed from office by the appointing authority. Any vacancy in office shall be filled by the appointing authority for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
Sec. 1.173. - Powers and duties. 
    The housing commission shall have all the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in housing commissions by Public Act No. 18 of the Extra Session of 1933, as heretofore or hereafter amended, and any laws heretofore or hereafter enacted which are supplemental thereto, it being the intention of this article to vest in the housing commission all powers and duties permitted by law. 
Sec. 1.174. - Meetings; rules; record; quorum; officers and employees. 
    The housing commission shall meet at regular intervals, such meetings to be public. It shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of the proceedings. Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A president and vice-president shall be elected by the commission. The commission may appoint a director who may also serve as secretary, and such other employees or officers as shall be necessary. The commission shall prescribe the duties of all its officers and employees and may, with the approval of the appointing authority, fix their compensation. The commission may from time to time as necessary employ engineers, architects and consultants. 
Sec. 1.175. - Funds for operation. 
    Funds for the operation of the housing commission may be provided by the city council, but the commission shall as soon as possible reimburse the city for all monies expended by it for the commission from revenue received from the sale of bonds. 
ARTICLE V. - SOUTHFIELD LOCAL OFFICERS COMPENSATION COMMISSION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) ---
