(2)  The grantee shall obtain such permits and pay such fees as set forth in chapter 33 of this Code, when in the opinion of the city engineer the scope of the work to be performed necessitates such permits and fees. 
(3)  No street, highway, alley or other public place shall be allowed to remain open or encumbered by construction work of the grantee for a period longer than is necessary to execute such work; grantee shall provide suitable barricades and signs in such numbers and at such locations as are necessary to protect the safety and welfare of the public. 
(4)  In those operations affecting public trees or shrubs, trimming shall be limited to the extent necessary to make lines safe and accessible; no public tree or shrub shall be removed without the written approval of the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
(5)  Before starting construction in any public space in which underground utilities may be located, the grantee shall ascertain the nature and location of such utilities, if any exist, to prevent disruption or inconvenience to users thereof. 
(6)  The grantee shall indemnify and save the city harmless from any loss, including all defense costs, from all actions, proceedings, claims, liabilities and damages arising from or in connection with construction undertaken by grantee in any public place. 
(7)  The grantee shall make due provision upon five (5) days' notice, in writing, by raising its wires or otherwise, for the passage of any structure or buildings on or over any street, highway or public place occupied by wires, poles or other apparatus of the grantee. 
(8)  The grantee shall reimburse the city for the cost of inspections as are required by this Code or other regulatory agencies. 
(Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 2.203. - Consideration. 
    In consideration of the granting of this franchise, grantee agrees that its rates and charges for electric service in the city shall not exceed its rates and charges for like service elsewhere in its service area, as evidenced by its uniform rate schedule at the time on file with and approved by the Michigan Public Service Commission. It is understood that the grantee is subject to regulation by the Michigan Public Service Commission and that any order, rule or regulation by that commission, or its successor, will prevail over any regulation contained in this chapter or provided for in case of conflict. 
(Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 2.204. - Effective date. 
    This grant shall take effect if the grantee shall, within fifteen (15) days from October 15, 1979, file with the city clerk its written acceptance of the terms of the same, and upon the confirmation of this grant, by the affirmative vote of a three-fifths majority of the electors of the city voting thereon at a regular election to be held on Tuesday, November 6, 1979, as provided for by the statutes and the state constitution. If not confirmed by the electors voting at such election, this franchise grant shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 10-15-79) 
Sec. 2.205. - Franchise term. 
    This franchise ordinance shall be and remain in force for thirty (30) years from and after the date of its confirmation by the electors of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 10-15-79) 
CHAPTER 23. - STREET LIGHTING SERVICE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1167, § 1, enacted March 11, 1985, deleted ch. 23 in its entirety and enacted a new ch. 23 in lieu thereof. Formerly, ch. 23, §§ 2.301-2.307, pertained to similar subject matter, and was derived from Ord. No. 997, § 1, enacted June 18, 1979, as amended by Ord. No. 1041, § 1, enacted August 18, 1980. 
Charter reference- Public utilities, § 10.12. 
Cross reference- Streets generally, § 4.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2.301. - Jurisdiction. 
    All street lighting facilities in the city shall be under the jurisdiction of the department of public services, transportation division. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Sec. 2.302. - Payment of service costs. 
    The owner of any improved premises abutting a street which is served with street lighting or is located within any special assessment lighting district shall pay for such services the rate as charged to the city by the utility company furnishing such service plus a five-percent administrative cost which is to include the anticipated annual cost of maintenance and/or replacement of the equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Sec. 2.303. - Rates. 
    Rates charged for street lighting services furnished in the city shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Charter reference- Utility charges to be fixed by council, § 10.13. 
Sec. 2.304. - Billing. 
    The charges for street lighting services shall be rendered at the same time as the city water bill is rendered and shall represent charges due for the period immediately preceding the date of the bill. All bills shall be due and payable within twenty (20) days from the date thereof. A penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount billed shall be assessed by the city on all bills not paid within twenty (20) days from date thereof. If the owner of the premises does not receive a water bill from the city, a statement for the charges for street lighting services shall be forwarded to the owner or his duly designated representative at the address as shown on the city assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Sec. 2.305. - Vacant premises. 
    Vacant premises shall be considered as improved within the meaning of this chapter as soon as a building permit is issued for any construction on the premises by the department of building and safety engineering. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Sec. 2.306. - Amendment of rates. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of the department of public services or his designated representatives to periodically review the rates the city is being charged for the furnishing of electricity to the city for street lighting and shall report any increase or decrease in such rates to the city council at least once per year. Council may, by resolution, adopt new rates based upon the annual review. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
Sec. 2.307. - Enforcement. 
    The charges for street lighting services shall be considered a lien on the premises obligated to pay for such services and shall be enforced in the same manner as provided for the enforcement of payment of water bills under section 2.155 of chapter 20 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1167, § 1, 3-11-85) 
CHAPTER 24. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCE AUTHORITY[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Charter reference- Taxation, § 9.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Taxes, tit. XI. 

Sec. 2.400. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this chapter shall have the following meaning unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
(a)  Base year assessment roll means the base year assessment roll prepared by the city assessor in accordance with section 2.403 of this chapter. 
(b)  Captured assessed value means the amount in any one (1) year by which the current assessed value as finally equalized of all taxable property in the city development area exceeds the initial assessed value. 
(c)  Development area shall mean the area described on the map in the development plan marked "Map #2-Development Area Boundaries." 
(d)  Development plan means the "Tax Increment and Development Plan-City of Southfield Development Area" dated December 1981, as amended and transmitted to the city council by the city tax increment finance authority for public hearing, and confirmed by this chapter, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(e)  Tax increment finance authority means the City of Southfield Tax Increment Finance Authority. 
(f)  Initial assessed value means the most recently assessed value as finally equalized of all the taxable property within the boundaries of the development area at the time of adoption of Ordinance No. 1081. 
(g)  Project fund means the tax increment finance authority project fund established pursuant to section 2.405 of this chapter. 
(h)  Taxing jurisdiction shall mean each unit of government levying an ad valorem property tax on property in the development area. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 2.401. - Approval and adoption of development plan. 
    The development plan is hereby approved and adopted. The duration of the plan shall be for a period of six (6) years except as it may be extended by subsequent amendment of the plan and this chapter. A copy of the plan and all amendments thereto shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office and cross-indexed to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.402. - Boundaries of development area. 
    The boundaries of the city development area as set forth in the development plan are hereby adopted and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.403. - Preparation of base year assessment roll. 
(a)  Within sixty (60) days of the effective date of Ordinance No. 1081, the city assessor shall prepare the initial base year assessment roll. The initial base year agreement roll shall list each taxing jurisdiction in which the city development area is located, the initial assessed value of the city development area on the effective date of Ordinance No. 1081 and the amount of tax revenue derived by each taxing jurisdiction from ad valorem taxes on the property in the development area. 
(b)  The assessor shall transmit copies of the initial base year assessment roll to the city treasurer, county treasurer, tax increment finance authority and each taxing jurisdiction, together with a notice that the assessment roll has been prepared in accordance with this chapter and the tax increment financing plan in the development plan approved by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.404. - Preparation of annual base year assessment roll. 
    Each year within fifteen (15) days following the final equalization of property in the city development area, the assessor shall prepare an updated base year assessment roll. The updated base year assessment roll shall show the information required in the initial base year assessment roll and, in addition, the captured assessed value for that year. Copies of the annual base year assessment roll shall be transmitted by the assessor to the same persons as the initial base year assessment roll, together with a notice that it has been prepared in accordance with this chapter and the development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.405. - Establishment of project fund; approval of depositary. 
    The treasurer of the tax increment finance authority shall establish a separate fund which shall be kept in a depositary bank account or accounts in a bank or banks approved by the director of finance of the city, to be designated the tax increment finance authority project. All monies received by the tax increment finance authority pursuant to the development plan shall be deposited in the project fund. All monies in that fund and earnings thereon shall be used in accordance with the development plan and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.406. - Payment of tax increments to tax increment finance authority. 
    The city and county treasurer shall, as ad valorem taxes are collected on the property in the development area, pay that proportion of the taxes, except for penalties and collection fees, that have captured assessed value bears to the initial assessed value to the treasurer of the tax increment finance authority for deposit in the project fund. The payments shall be made on the date or dates on which the city and county treasurers are required to remit taxes to each of the taxing jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.407. - Use of monies in the project fund. 
    The money credited to the project fund and on hand therein from time to time shall annually be used in the following manner and following order of priority: 
    First, to pay into the debt retirement fund, or funds, for all outstanding series of bonds issued pursuant to this plan, an amount equal to the interest and principal coming due (in the case of principal whether by maturity or mandatory redemption) prior to the next collection of taxes, less any credit for sums on hand in the debt retirement fund. 
    Second, to establish a reserve account for payment of principal and interest on bonds issued or which may be issued pursuant to this plan, an amount equal to one-fifth of the largest combined annual principal and interest payments due on bonds issued pursuant to this plan until the amount to the credit of the reserve account is equal to the largest combined annual principal and interest requirements on bonds issued pursuant to this plan. Any amounts to the credit of the reserve account at the beginning of a fiscal year in excess of the requirements of the preceding sentence shall be considered tax increment revenue for that year. 
    Third, to pay the administrative and operating costs of the tax increment finance authority and city for the development area, including planning and promotion, to the extent provided in the annual budget of the tax increment finance authority. 
    Fourth, to pay, to the extent determined desirable by the tax increment finance authority and approved by the city, the cost of improvements as set forth in the development plan to the extent those costs are not financed from the proceeds of bonds. 
    Fifth, to pay the cost of any additional improvements to the development that are determined necessary the tax increment finance authority and approved by the city council. 
    Sixth, to reimburse the city with interest for funds advanced to acquire property, clear land, make preliminary plans and improvements necessary for the development of the development area in accordance with this plan. Interest reimbursement for funds advanced by the city shall be equivalent to the percentage return on other general fund investments. 
    Seventh, to provide a pool of funds which may be necessary to finance the relocation plan as specified in the development plan. 
Any tax increment receipts in excess of those needed under the preceding paragraphs would revert to the taxing jurisdictions or would be used for future development activities within the development area, as defined in the development plan pursuant to amendment or modification of the development plan and this tax increment financing plan pursuant to applicable provisions of Act No. 450 of 1980 and other laws. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.408. - Public hearing. 
    Prior to any construction plans being developed and following preliminary design plan preparations for (a) the bridge replacement, (b) the drainage system and/or (c) Civic Drive expansion, the city council shall conduct public hearings to obtain citizen input on the details relative to the design elements of each improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.409. - Development area citizens council. 
    The appointment of the development area citizens council shall be expanded to a total membership of thirteen (13) from the development area and shall remain in effect during the duration of the tax increment finance development plan and any vacancies will be replaced by appointments by the city council. The development area citizens council shall be advisory to the tax increment finance authority and city council during each stage of the development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.410. - Annual report. 
    Within ninety (90) days after the end of each fiscal year, the tax increment finance authority shall submit to the city council, with copies to each taxing jurisdiction, a report on the status of the project fund. The report shall include the amount and source of revenue in the account, the amount and purpose of expenditures from the account, the initial assessed value of the city development area, the captured assessed value of the city development area, the tax increments received and the amount of any surplus from the prior year, and any additional information requested by the city council or deemed appropriate by the tax increment finance authority. The secretary of the tax increment finance authority shall cause a copy of the report to be published once in full in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.411. - Refund of surplus tax increments. 
    Any surplus money in the project fund at the end of a year, as shown by the annual report of the tax increment finance authority, shall be paid by the authority to the city or county treasurer, as the case may be, and rebated by them to the appropriate taxing jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 2.412. - Revenue bonds. 
    The tax increment finance authority may not issue revenue bonds or tax increment finance bonds without first receiving the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1, 12-17-81) 
CHAPTER 25. - CONSUMERS POWER COMPANY GAS FRANCHISE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Charter reference- Utilities, franchises, permits, § 10.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, § 4.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2.501. - Grant. 
    The city hereby grants to the Consumers Power Company, a Michigan corporation, its successors and assigns, hereinafter called the "grantee," the right, power, and authority to lay, maintain, and operate gas mains, pipes, and services on, along, across and under the highways, streets, alleys, bridges, and other public places, and to do a local gas business in the city for a period of thirty (30) years. The city hereby grants an extension of the right, power, and authority given to Consumers Power Company, a Michigan Corporation, its successors and assigns, to lay, maintain, and operate gas mains, pipes, and services on, along, across and under the highways, streets, alleys, bridges, and other public places, and to do a local gas business in the city for a period of an additional thirty (30) years. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86; Ord. No. 1668 , § 1, 2-9-17) 
Sec. 2.502. - Consideration. 
    In consideration of the rights, power and authority hereby granted, said grantee shall faithfully perform all things required by the terms hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.503. - Interference with right-of-way, notice. 
    No highway, street, alley, bridge or other public place used by said grantee shall be obstructed longer than necessary during work, construction or repair, and shall be restored to the same order and condition, or better, as when said work was commenced. All of grantee's pipes and mains shall be so placed in the highways and other public places as not to unnecessarily interfere with the use thereof for highway purposes, and that Consumers Power Company will provide the city director of public services, or his authorized representative, with fourteen (14) days' written notice of any blockage or partial blockage of a public right-of-way except in cases of emergency, and in that case as soon as is practical. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.504. - Hold harmless. 
    Said grantee shall at all times keep and save the city free and harmless from all loss, costs and expense to which it may be subject by reason of the negligent construction, maintenance, repair or replacement of the structure and equipment hereby authorized. In case any action is commenced against the city on account of the permission herein given, said grantee shall, upon notice, defend the city and save it free and harmless from all loss, cost and damage arising out of such construction, maintenance or repair, including damages or actions arising from construction, repair, or replacement of the highways, streets, alleys, bridges, and other public places. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.505. - Restoration and maintenance of right-of-way, notice. 
    In the event the city is not satisfied with the restoration of the right-of-way following the construction or maintenance of facilities by the company, the city shall provide the company with written notice of any alleged deficiencies. In the event the company fails to correct such deficiencies within the time provided in the notice, the city shall have the right to enter the right-of-way and perform work it may determine necessary to such restoration and to assess reasonable costs for said work to the company. Failure of the company to correct alleged deficiencies in the restoration of the right-of-way claimed by the city within a reasonable time provided in the notice may be taken by the city as an authorization for the city to perform the work and as an agreement by the company to pay the reasonable cost of the same. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.506. - Applicable laws, construction. 
    Said grantee shall construct and extend its gas distribution system within said city, and shall furnish gas to applicants residing therein in accordance with applicable laws, rules and regulations as set forth by the City Code of Ordinances, administrative rules and state and federal laws, and any amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.507. - [Grant] nonexclusive. 
    The rights, power and authority herein granted are not exclusive. Either manufactured or natural gas may be furnished hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.508. - Service. 
    [It shall be the responsibility of the grantee] to provide continuous and uninterrupted service to the public in accordance with the terms of the franchise throughout the entire period thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.509. - Joint use of right-of-way. 
    [It shall be the responsibility of the grantee] to permit joint use of its property and appurtenances located in the streets, alleys, bridges and other public places by the city, and by other utilities, insofar as such joint use may be reasonably practicable, and upon payment of reasonable rental therefor to Consumers Power Company and in the absence of agreement, upon application by Consumers Power Company, provide for arbitration of the terms and conditions of such joint use and the compensation to be paid. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.510. - Rates. 
    Said grantee shall be entitled to charge the inhabitants of said city for gas furnished therein, the rates as approved by the Michigan Public Service Commission, to which commission or its successors authority and jurisdiction to fix and regulate gas rates and rules regulating such service in said city, are hereby granted for the term of this franchise. Such rates and rules shall be subject to review and change at any time upon petition therefor being made by either said city, acting by its city council, or by said grantee. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.511. - Termination. 
    The franchise granted by this chapter is subject to revocation upon sixty (60) days' written notice by the party desiring such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.512. - Service, public service commission. 
    Said grantee shall, as to all other conditions and elements of service not herein fixed, be and remain subject to the reasonable rules and regulations of the Michigan Public Service Commission or its successors, applicable to gas service in said city. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.513. - Condemnation, costs. 
    Consumers Power Company will be liable for any condemnation costs necessary in obtaining any necessary easements for Consumers Power Company including actual attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.514. - Plans. 
    All plans for construction will be submitted to the city engineer fifteen (15) days prior to the commencement of any nonemergency work by Consumers Power Company and [said company shall] obtain any such permits and pay any fees set forth in chapter 33 of this Code when in the opinion of the city engineer the scope of the work performed requires such permits and fees. Any costs or fees involved with review of these plans will be paid by Consumers Power Company. No nonemergency work may be commenced prior to the approval of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.515. - Signing, lighting, barricading. 
    All lighting, barricading, fencing and signing as provided in the Michigan Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as amended, which is necessary to protect the public health and welfare from any work done under this agreement will be provided by Consumers Power Company. Consumers Power Company will reimburse the city for the costs including labor for providing any of these items not provided by Consumers Power Company and which the city deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.516. - New facilities. 
    Any installation of new equipment or facilities, or the replacement of any existing equipment or facilities within the public right-of-way, shall be placed underground unless a written waiver is obtained from the city engineer prior to installation or replacement. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
Sec. 2.517. - Annual report. 
    Consumers Power will provide the city clerk with an annual report as they become available. 
(Ord. No. 1208, § 1, 8-25-86) 
CHAPTER 26. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2.601. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and cited as the "City of Southfield Downtown Development Authority Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2.602. - Establishment. 
    In recognition of the fact that it is in the best interest of the public to halt property value deterioration in the downtown business district of the city, to eliminate the causes of such deterioration and to promote economic growth in the downtown business district, a downtown development authority is hereby established pursuant to Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2.603. - Organization. 
    The city downtown development authority shall be under the supervision and control of a board consisting of the mayor of the city and twelve (12) members appointed by the mayor of the city subject to the approval of the city council. At least seven (7) of the members shall be persons having an interest in property located in the downtown district. At least one (1) of the members shall be a resident of the downtown district, if the downtown district has one hundred (100) or more persons residing within it. Of the members first appointed, three (3) shall be appointed for one (1) year, three (3) for two (2) years, three (3) for three (3) years, and three (3) for four (4) years. A member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. Thereafter, members shall serve for a term of four (4) years. An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be made by the mayor of the city for the unexpired term only. Members of the board shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. A chairperson of the board shall be elected by the board. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2.604. - Powers and duties. 
    The city downtown development authority shall have all the powers and duties prescribed by Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2.605. - Financing. 
    The activities of the authority shall be financed from one or more of the following sources: 
(a)  Donations to the authority for the performance of its functions. 
(b)  Proceeds of a tax pursuant to section 12 of Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(c)  Money borrowed and to be repaid as authorized by section 13 of Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(d)  Revenues from any property, building or facility owned, leased, licensed, or operated by the authority or under its control, subject to the limitations imposed upon the authority by trusts or other agreements. 
(e)  Proceeds of a tax increment financing plan, established under sections 14 to 16 of Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. 
(f)  Proceeds from a special assessment district created as provided by law. 
(g)  Money obtained from other sources approved by the city council. 
(h)  Money received by the authority and not covered under subsections (a) through (g) shall immediately be deposited to the credit of the authority, subject to disbursement pursuant to Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975. Except as provided in Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of 1975, the city shall not obligate itself, nor shall it ever be obligated to pay any sums from public funds, other than money received by the city pursuant to this section, for or on account of the activities of the authority. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 2.606. - Boundaries. 
    The authority shall exercise its powers within the following described area: 
Bounded on the north by the north right-of-way line of Nine Mile Road, on the east by the centerline of Greenfield Road, on the south by the centerline of Eight Mile Road and on the west by the centerline of Southfield Road then north to the rear of the properties fronting on the north side of Northland Park Drive then easterly to Northwestern Highway then northwesterly along the west right-of-way line of Northwestern Highway to Nine Mile Road. The proposed authority district shall also include the north Nine Mile Road frontage between Providence Drive and Greenfield Road and the west Greenfield Road and the west Greenfield Road frontage between Nine Mile Road and Providence Drive. (As depicted in Exhibit "A" and incorporating those properties described in Exhibit "B" which exhibits are attached to Ordinance No. 1246 and made a part hereof.) 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 6-13-88) 
CHAPTER 26A. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND TAX INCREMENT FINANCE PLAN 
ARTICLE I. - DEVELOPMENT PLAN 

Sec. 2.607. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this chapter shall have the following meaning unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Base year assessment roll means the base year assessment roll prepared by the city assessor in accordance with section 2.611 of this chapter. 
    Captured assessed value means the amount in any one (1) year by which the current assessed value as finally equalized of all taxable property in the development area exceeds the initial assessed value. 
    Development area shall mean the area described on the map in the development plan marked "Development Area Boundaries." 
    Development plan means the development plan of the SDDA development area dated March 1996, transmitted to the city council by the SDDA for public hearing, and confirmed by this chapter, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
    Initial assessed value means the assessed value as finally equalized of all the taxable property within the boundaries of the development area on December 31, 1994. 
    Project fund means the SDDA project fund established pursuant to section 2.612 of this chapter. 
    Southfield Downtown Development Authority (SDDA) means the City of Southfield Downtown Development Authority. 
    Tax increment finance plan means the tax increment finance plan of the SDDA development area dated March 1996, transmitted to the city council by the SDDA for public hearing, and confirmed by this chapter, copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
    Taxing jurisdiction shall mean each unit of government levying an ad valorem property tax on property in the development area. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.608. - Duration of development plan. 
    The duration of the development plan shall be for a period of twenty (20) years except as it may be extended by subsequent amendment of this Ordinance No. 1390. A copy of the Development Plan and all amendments thereto shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office and cross-indexed to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.609. - Boundaries of development area. 
    The boundaries of the Southfield downtown development authority development area as set forth in the development plan are hereby adopted and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.610. - Preparation of the base year assessment roll. 
(a)  After the effective date of this chapter, the city assessor shall prepare the initial base year assessment roll of the development area. The initial base year assessment roll shall list each taxing jurisdiction in which the development area is located, the initial assessed value of the development area on the effective date of this chapter and the amount of tax revenue derived by each taxing jurisdiction from ad valorem taxes on the property in the development area. 
(b)  The assessor shall transmit copies of the initial base year assessment roll of the development area to the city treasurer, county treasurer, SDDA and each taxing jurisdiction, together with a notice that the assessment roll has been prepared in accordance with this chapter and the tax increment finance plan approved by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.611. - Preparation of annual assessment roll of the development area. 
    Each year following the final equalization of the assessed value of all taxable property in the development area, the assessor shall prepare an updated assessment roll of the development area. The annual assessment roll of the development area shall show the information required in the base year assessment roll of the development area and the current assessed value and the captured assessed value of the development area for that year. Copies of the annual assessment roll shall be transmitted by the assessor to the same persons as the initial base year assessment roll, together with a notice that it has been prepared in accordance with this chapter and the development plan. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.612. - Establishment of project fund; approval of depositary. 
    The treasurer of the SDDA shall establish a separate fund which shall be kept in a depositary bank account or accounts in a bank or banks approved by the director of finance of the city, to be designated "project fund." All monies received by the SDDA pursuant to the tax increment finance plan shall be deposited in the project fund. All monies in that fund and earnings thereon shall be used in accordance with the development plan and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.613. - Payment of tax increment revenues to the SDDA. 
    The city and county treasurer shall transfer all tax increment revenues (as defined in the Act) collected from the development area to the treasurer of the SDDA for deposit in the project fund. The payments shall be made on the date or dates on which the city and county treasurers are required to remit taxes to each of the taxing jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.614. - Use of monies in the project fund. 
    The money credited to the project fund and on hand therein from time to time shall annually be used in accordance with annual budgets approved as required by the Act in the following manner and following order of priority: 
First, to pay into the debt retirement fund, or funds, for all outstanding dollars loaned pursuant to this plan, an amount equal to the interest and principal coming due (in the case of principal whether by maturity or mandatory redemption) prior to the next collection of taxes, less any credit for sums on hand in the debt retirement fund. 
Second, to reimburse the city with interest for funds advanced to acquire property, clear land, make preliminary plans and improvements and other activities deemed necessary to achieve the purposes of the development plan. Interest reimbursement for funds advanced by the city shall be equivalent to the percentage return on other general fund investments. 
Third, to pay the administrative and operating costs of the SDDA and the development area, including planning and promotion, to the extent provided in the annual budget of the SDDA. 
Fourth, to pay, to the extent determined desirable by the SDDA and approved by the city council, the cost of improvements as set forth in the development plan to the extent those costs are not financed from the proceeds of bonds. 
Fifth, to pay the cost of any additional improvements to the development that are determined necessary by the SDDA and approved by the city council as described in the plans. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.615. - Annual report. 
    Within ninety (90) days after the end of the fiscal year, the SDDA shall submit to the city council, with copies to each taxing jurisdiction, a report on the status of the project fund as required by section 15(3) of the Act. The secretary of the SDDA shall cause a copy of the report to be published once in full in a newspaper of general circulation in the city as required by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
Sec. 2.616. - Refund of surplus tax increment revenues. 
    Any surplus tax increment revenues in the project fund at the end of a year, as shown by the annual report of the SDDA, shall be paid by the authority to the city or county treasurer, as the case may be, and rebated by them to the appropriate taxing jurisdiction in accordance with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 1390, § 1, 4-8-96) 
ARTICLE II. - RESTATED DEVELOPMENT PLAN 

Sec. 2.617. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "2017 Restated Development Plan and Tax Increment Financing Plan Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.618. - Definitions. 
    The terms used herein shall have the same meaning given them in Act 197 (defined below), unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary. As used in this article: 
    2017 restated plan shall mean the 2017 development plan and tax increment financing plan, submitted by the authority to the city council pursuant to Act 197 and approved by the ordinance from which this article derives as it may be hereafter amended. 
    Act 197 shall mean Act 197, Public Acts of Michigan, 1975, as amended, as now in effect or hereinafter amended, being known as the Michigan Downtown Development Authority Act. 
    Authority shall mean the Southfield Downtown Development Authority. 
    Authority board shall mean the board of the authority, its governing body. 
    City council shall mean the city council of City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, a municipal corporation of the state of Michigan. 
    Development area shall mean the development area designated in the development plan as amended by the 2017 restated plan. 
    Development plan shall mean the development plan portion of the plan. 
    Plan shall mean the authority's development plan and tax increment financing plan, as amended by the 2017 restated plan. 
    Tax increment financing plan shall mean the tax increment financing plan portion of the plan for the collection of tax increments. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.619. - Public purpose. 
    The city council finds and confirms the continued necessity to halt property value deterioration, to eliminate the causes of such deterioration and to promote economic growth, and hereby determines that the 2017 restated plan adopted by the authority board on November 17, 2017 and presented to and revised by the city council constitutes a public purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.620. - Considerations. 
    In accordance with section 19 of Act 197, the city council has considered the factors enumerated in that section and herein stated, making the following determinations: 
(a)  The city council has received and considered the findings of the development area citizens council. 
(b)  The development plan meets the requirements set forth in section 17(2) of Act 197. 
(c)  The proposed method of financing the development is feasible and the Authority has the ability to arrange the financing. 
(d)  The development is reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Act 197. 
(e)  The land included within the development area which may be acquired is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of the development plan and of Act 197 in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner. 
(f)  The development plan is in reasonable accord with the city's master plan. 
(g)  Public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the project area. 
(h)  Changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections and utilities are reasonably necessary for the project and for the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.621. - Meetings. 
    Representatives of all taxing jurisdictions within which all or a portion of the development area lies have had reasonable opportunity to present their opinions and comments regarding the 2017 restated plan to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.622. - Public hearing. 
    The city council has held a public hearing on the 2017 restated plan with notice properly given in accordance with section 18 of Act 197, and the city council has provided an opportunity for all interested persons to be heard regarding the 2017 restated plan. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.623. - Approval. 
    The 2017 restated plan as revised by the city council is hereby approved in the form attached hereto as exhibit A (a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk). 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.624. - Development area. 
    The development area designated in the development plan as amended by the 2017 restated plan is hereby ratified and confirmed. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Sec. 2.625. - Transmittal of revenues. 
    The city treasurer shall transmit to the authority that portion of the tax levy of all taxing bodies paid each year on real and personal property in the development area on the captured assessed value as set forth in the tax increment financing plan. 
(Ord. No. 1694 , § 1, 5-17-18) 
Title III - PARKS AND PUBLIC GROUNDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to establish and maintain parks and recreational facilities, § 4.12. 
Cross reference- Administration, tit. I; special assessments for public improvements, § 1.221 et seq. 

CHAPTER 27. - PARKS, GENERAL REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Responsibilities of department of parks and recreation, § 1.138. 

Sec. 3.1. - Injury to park property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any walk or drive in any public park or playground on injure, mar or damage in any manner any building, monument, ornament, fence, bridge, seat, tree, fountain, shrub, flower, playground equipment, fireplace or other public property within or pertaining to any park or playground. 
Sec. 3.2. - Waste containers. 
    No person shall place or deposit any garbage, glass, tin cans, papers or miscellaneous waste in any park or playground except in containers provided for that purpose. 
Cross reference- Proper placement of litter in public receptacles, § 2.9. 
Sec. 3.3. - Ball games. 
    No baseball, football or softball throwing, or other violent or rough exercises or play shall be engaged in any public park or other public place except in such areas or spaces designated for such purposes or play by the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
Sec. 3.4. - Picnics. 
    Picnics may be held in such places of any park as shall be designated for that purpose by the superintendent of parks and recreation subject to any rules or regulations pertaining thereto. 
Sec. 3.5. - Open fires. 
    It shall be unlawful to kindle or build fires in any park or playground except in fireplaces or stoves in any park provided for that purpose. Upon leaving such fire, it shall be the duty of the person using it to see that the fire is extinguished. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention regulations, § 9.181 et seq. 
Sec. 3.6. - Vehicles in parks. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive or park any vehicle in any park or playground except in places and areas designated therefor by the superintendent of parks and recreation. Driving and parking on all street and public ways within any park or bordering on the same shall be subject to all the provisions of chapter 126 of this Code regulating traffic generally and to such additional rules and regulations as the city shall adopt pursuant to this chapter. 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations, § 10.1 et seq. 
Sec. 3.7. - Intoxicating liquors. 
    It shall be unlawful to consume, possess, or bring any alcoholic beverage into any public park or grounds except as provided in section 3.9, chapter 27, title III, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 6-9-86) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquor regulations, § 9.151 et seq. 
Sec. 3.8. - Additional rules. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation is hereby empowered to make such additional rules and regulations, subject to the approval of the parks and recreation commission, pertaining to the conduct and use of the parks and public grounds as are necessary to administer the same and to protect property and the safety, health, morals and welfare of the public, and no person shall fail to comply with such rules and regulations. 
Sec. 3.9. - Application for liquor permits. 
    Any person, group, organization, society or corporation wishing to consume, possess, or bring any alcoholic beverage into any public park or grounds must meet each of the following criteria: 
(1)  Make written application to the superintendent of parks and recreation, said application stating: 
a.  The name, address and phone number of the person, group, organization, society, or corporation making application. 
b.  The date(s) for which the permits are being sought. 
c.  The event for which the permit is being sought, and the sponsors if different than those making application. 
(2)  File with the superintendent of parks and recreation, and the city clerk, a liability insurance policy in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) indemnifying the city for any damages or causes of action arising out of the event for which a permit is being sought. 
(3)  A copy of the liquor control commission liquor license for the event for which said permit is being sought. 
(4)  That all of the requirements in subsection (1) above be met within ten (10) days prior to the date(s) for which the permit is being sought. 
(Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 6-9-86) 
Cross reference- Liquor licenses and related permits, § 7.190 et seq. 
Sec. 3.10. - Issuance of permits. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation may issue a liquor permit to any person, organization, society, or corporation who has met the criteria set forth in section 3.9, chapter 27, of title III. 
(Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 6-9-86) 
Sec. 3.11. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and imprisonment of not more than ninety (90) days in jail, or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 6-9-86) 
CHAPTER 28. - TREE REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Responsibilities of department of parks and recreation, § 1.138; tree requirements in subdivisions, § 5.347. 

Sec. 3.21. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation of this chapter: 
(1)  The word "highway" shall include all the land lying between the property lines on either side of all public streets, boulevards and alleys. 
(2)  The words "superintendent of parks and recreation" shall include his duly authorized agents. 
(3)  The word "park" shall include all public parks, and all areas owned by the city or to which the public has free access as a park. 
(4)  The words "public place" shall include all other grounds owned by the city. 
(5)  The words "trees and shrubs" shall include all woody vegetation. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 3.22. - Administrator and duties. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation, or such other authority as may be hereinafter set forth by the city council, shall direct, regulate and control the planting, insect and disease control, fertilizing, mulching and removal of all trees and shrubs growing now or hereafter in any public highway, parkway, park or other public areas of the city. He shall also direct the maintenance and culture of turf areas, both established and newly seeded, that belong to the city. The department of parks and recreation shall be charged with the routine maintenance and care of the trees, shrubs and turf areas under the provisions of this chapter. The superintendent of parks and recreation shall cause the provisions of this chapter to be enforced. He shall discharge any and all duties that may be required of him by the city council. 
Sec. 3.23. - Planting and control of trees. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation shall have the exclusive power to plant, maintain and remove trees, shrubs and herbaceous material, both living and dead, in any highway, park or public place of the city. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation shall assume complete responsibility for the selection, planting, maintenance and removal of all trees and shrubs growing now or hereafter in any highway, park or public place of the city, as promptly as financial and labor conditions will permit. 
    Permits for planting, maintenance and removal of trees and shrubs may be granted as specified in sections 3.26 and 3.27. 
Sec. 3.24. - Varieties of trees. 
    No willow (salix, all varieties except horticultural varieties), Poplar (populus sp.), Soft (silver) Maple (Acer saccharinum), Box elder (Acer negundo), Tree of Heaven (silanthus altissimus), Wild chestnut (castanea sp.), Chinese Elm (ulmus parvifolia), American Elm (ulmus americanna) or other trees, shrubs and vines determined to be undesirable by the superintendent of parks and recreation shall hereafter be planted in the public highways, parks or public places in the city. 
Sec. 3.25. - Location of planting, height of branches. 
    There shall be a minimum distance of forty (40) feet between trees planted in the parkway. No tree shall be planted in the parkway between the sidewalk and the curb less than three (3) feet from the curb or sidewalk lines. However, where the parkway is less than six (6) feet but not less than four (4) feet in width, a tree may be planted midway between the curb and the sidewalk. Any exceptions to these requirements will be determined by the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
    No trees shall be planted which are less than one and one-half (11/2) inches in diameter six (6) inches above the ground. 
    A branch of any tree or shrub located on private property which overhangs a sidewalk or bike path shall have an under-clearance of at least eight (8) feet, and if under eight (8) feet in height, a side-clearance of at least six (6) inches. A branch of any tree or shrub located on private property which overhangs a street shall have an under-clearance of at least fourteen (14) feet; and if under fourteen (14) feet in height, a side-clearance of at least six (6) inches. In the event of a violation of the above under-clearance or side-clearance requirements, the superintendent of parks and recreation shall notify the owner or occupant of the property on which the tree or shrub is located in writing, of the existence of such violation with instructions for its correction within such time as the superintendent of parks and recreation shall deem reasonable; and if the owner or occupant fails to comply with such notice, the superintendent of parks and recreation shall cause such violation to be removed or corrected and the expense of such correction shall be collected in the manner set forth in section 3.34. 
    All trees, plants, and shrubs located on the triangle formed by two (2) property lines at the intersection of two (2) streets, and extending for a distance of twenty-five (25) feet each way from the intersection of the rights-of-way lines on any corner lot within the city, shall not be permitted to grow to a height of more than three (3) feet above the surface of the roadway, in order that the view of the driver of the vehicle approaching a street intersection shall not be obstructed. Trees may be planted and maintained in this area provided that all branches are trimmed to maintain a clear vision for a vertical height of eight (8) feet above the roadway surface. A violation of the above intersection requirements may be corrected by the superintendent of parks and recreation in the same manner as described in this section for under-clearance and side-clearance violations. 
(Ord. No. 1557, § 1, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 3.26. - Permit to plant, treat or remove. 
    No person shall hereafter plant, move, spray, fertilize, brace, trim, do surgery work, cut aboveground or below ground, cut any branch or root therefrom or otherwise disturb any tree or shrub in any highway, park or public place of the city, nor cause such acts to be done by others, without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent of parks and recreation, who shall issue the permit if in his judgment the desired work is necessary, and the proposed method of workmanship thereof is of a satisfactory nature. The person receiving such permit shall abide by the specifications and standards of practice adopted by the city. 
Sec. 3.27. - Conditional permit for removal of trees and shrubs. 
(1)  As a condition to any permit to remove any tree or shrub, the superintendent of parks and recreation may require that the permittee plant a tree or shrub in place of the one removed. Whenever any such tree has been destroyed or removed, it shall be a misdemeanor for the permittee to fail, refuse or neglect to plant another tree or shrub of the type and size, and at the location specified in the permit, within six (6) months or within the next planting season from the date of the issuance of the permit. 
(2)  Every permit granted by the superintendent of parks and recreation shall describe the work to be done, specify the species or variety, size, grade, location, briefly specify the method of planting, method of support and trimming of all trees or shrubs concerned, and contain a definite date of expiration. Any permit may be declared void if its terms are violated. 
Sec. 3.28. - Obstructions; fences. 
    No person shall take down, climb over, interfere with, disturb nor displace any rails, posts, boards, chains or fences enclosing or protecting any park, highway or public place. 
Sec. 3.29. - Fastening materials to trees. 
    No person shall fasten any sign, wire, rope or other material to or around, or run any wire or rope through, any trees or shrub in any highway, park or public place of the city, except by written permit granted by the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
Sec. 3.30. - Protection of trees and shrubs. 
    No person shall break, injure, climb, peel, cut, mutilate, kill or destroy any tree or shrub, or set fire or permit any fire to burn where such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree or shrub in any highway, park or public place of the city; no person shall pluck, break, trample upon or interfere with any flower or shrub on any highway, park or public place; nor shall any person dig, remove or carry away any sward, gravel, sand, turf or earth in any such park or highway; no person shall knowingly permit any leak to exist in any gas pipe or main within the root zone of any such tree or shrub; no person shall lead, ride or drive any animal, nor operate any automobile or other vehicle in any manner so as to injure or deface any such park, highway or public place; no person shall permit any toxic chemical, either solid or liquid, to seep, drain or be emptied on or about any tree or shrub; no person shall knowingly permit any wire designed to carry electric current to come in contact with any such tree or shrub unless protected by approved methods; and, no person shall attach any electric insulation to any tree or shall excavate any ditches, tunnels or trenches, or lay any drive within a radius of five (5) feet from any tree or shrub without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent of parks and recreation. Whenever the superintendent of parks and recreation determines it to be necessary, in order to prune or remove any tree or shrub in any highway, park or public place of the city, or for any other reason temporarily to protect, move or cut off the electricity from any service wire, he shall serve written notice on the owner of such wire to protect, move or cut off the electricity from such wire and the owner shall comply with such order within twenty-four (24) hours after the service of such notice. 
    In the erection, alteration, repair or removal of any building or structure, the owner or owners thereof shall place or cause to be placed such guards around all nearby trees on the public property as will effectually prevent injury to such trees. 
Sec. 3.31. - Regulation to govern diseased trees. 
    Regulation No. 613 of the Michigan Department of Agriculture, adopted in accordance with section 6, Act 72 of the Public Acts of 1945, declares elm trees and wood infected by Dutch Elm Disease to be a public menace. In connection with other public acts of the state, this regulation provides the framework for municipal control of diseased trees on private as well as public property. 
(1)  Trees of all species and varieties of elm and planera affected with the fungus Ceratostomella ulmi, as determined by laboratory analysis, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and shall be removed and properly disposed of within ten (10) days following notification of the discovery of such infection. It shall be unlawful for any person, being the owner of property whereon such a tree is situated, to possess or keep such a tree after the expiration of thirty (30) days following notification of the discovery of such infection. 
(2)  Trees or parts thereof of elm or planera in a dead or dying condition that may serve as a breeding place for the European Elm Bark Beetle, Scolytue multistriatus, or the American Elm Bark Beetle, Hylurgopinus rufipes, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for the person owning property whereon the same is situated to possess or keep the same. 
(3)  The director of parks and recreation, or his designee, is charged with enforcement of this chapter, and to that end may enter upon private property at all daylight hours for purposes of inspecting trees thereon, and may remove such specimens as are required for purposes of analysis to determine whether or not the same are infected. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the director of parks and recreation, or his designee, entering on private property for purposes of carrying out his duties under this chapter, or to interfere with such director of parks and recreation, or his designee, in the lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  If trees on private property are found to be infected, the director of parks and recreation, or his designee, shall give to the owner of the premises where such tree or trees are situated written notice of the existence of such disease, and requiring the removal and disposal of such trees within a period of thirty (30) days following such notice, such removal and disposal to be under the direction and supervision of the director of parks and recreation, or his designee. Such notice shall notify the owner of the premises that unless such tree is removed and disposed of in compliance with the terms thereof within such thirty-day period, the city will proceed with the removal and disposal of such trees, and the collection of the expense thereof. 
(5)  Service of such notice shall be made on the owner and occupant of the premises in the manner prescribed in chapter 1, section 1.14 of this Code. 
(6)  It shall thereupon become the duty of the owner of such premises to cause such tree to be removed and properly disposed of under the direction and supervision of the director of parks and recreation or his authorized deputy or employee. In lieu thereof, the person charged with such removal and disposal may request that the same be done by the director of parks and recreation, or his designee. If the city shall remove and dispose of any trees, all expenses in connection therewith shall be collected in the manner set forth in section 3.34. 
(7)  Trees on public lands within the city shall be removed at the expense of the city. 
(8)  Proper disposal of infected trees shall mean cutting down the infected tree and burying it in a sanitary landfill or cutting down the infected tree and chipping it or any other manner of disposal prescribed by the director of parks and recreation, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 1179, § 1, 7-8-85) 
Sec. 3.32. - Permits to public utilities. 
    All permits issued for the installation of public utilities shall be certified by the city engineer. When a permit is given by the superintendent of parks and recreation to a telephone, telegraph, electric power or other public service corporation or utility to trim trees, or perform other operations affecting public trees or shrubs, the amount of such trimming or extent of the other operations shall be limited by the actual necessities of the service of the company and such work shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner and according to specifications outlined by the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
Sec. 3.33. - No interference with the superintendent of parks and recreation. 
    No person shall prevent, delay or interfere with the superintendent of parks and recreation or any of his assistants in the execution of enforcement of this chapter; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit a public hearing on any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction for the protection of property rights by the owner of any property within the city. 
Sec. 3.34. - Collection of expenses. 
    Any expenses due to the city in connection with the enforcement of this chapter shall be certified by the superintendent of parks and recreation to the city council on or before April 1 of each year. Such expenses shall be certified by the council to the city assessor and assessed against the premises on whose behalf the expenses were incurred and shall be collected or returned in the same manner as municipal taxes are assessed, collected and returned. 
Sec. 3.35. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, or any lawful order issued in pursuance of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1 of this Code. Imposition of any penalty for a violation of this chapter shall not be construed as a waiver of the right of the city to collect the costs of removal of such tree in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the provisions of the Charter in such case made and provided, where it is necessary for the city to remove such tree in accordance with provisions of this chapter. 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of Code, § 1.15. 
CHAPTER 29. - CITY CEMETERIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Power to establish cemetery regulations, § 4.13. 
Cross reference- Responsibilities of department of parks and recreation, § 1.138. 

Sec. 3.51. - City cemeteries. 
    The cemeteries which have been or may be hereafter established or maintained by the city either within or without the city, of which plats have been or shall be filed in the office of the superintendent of parks and recreation, shall be known as the city cemeteries. 
Sec. 3.52. - Management. 
    The superintendent of parks and recreation, in this chapter called the superintendent, subject to the direction of the parks and recreation board, shall manage, supervise, maintain and improve such cemeteries. He shall cause the city cemetery grounds to be laid out in lots and walks, the lots to be numbered, and the avenues and walks therein to be named and plats thereof to be made and, when approved by the parks and recreation board, to be filed in his office together with a plan for perpetual care of the lots platted. The city council shall from time to time by resolution determine the price of lots. The superintendent shall sell such lots and all deeds thereof shall be executed on behalf of the city by the mayor and the city clerk. It shall be the duty of the superintendent to enforce this chapter and the rules and regulations of the parks and recreation board relative to the city cemeteries. 
Sec. 3.53. - Lot purchases. 
    Any person desiring to purchase a lot in any city cemetery shall make application to the superintendent and, if the same be granted, the applicant shall pay the required amount for such lot to the treasurer, and upon filing a receipt therefor with the superintendent the deed to such lot shall be duly executed and delivered on behalf of the city. All lots shall be held subject to the provisions of this chapter and such rules and regulations as may be from time to time adopted by the parks and recreation commission under this chapter. 
Sec. 3.54. - Records. 
    The superintendent shall keep proper records in which any deed to any such lot shall be recorded at length. The superintendent shall certify upon every such instrument the time when it was recorded and the liber and page where it was recorded. 
Sec. 3.55. - Index. 
    The superintendent shall keep a general index to each of such libers, in which he shall note alphabetically the name of each party to every instrument recorded by him with reference to the liber and page where it is recorded. He shall also keep a register, showing all deed issued, the date, to whom issued and the description of the property conveyed. 
Sec. 3.56. - Recording fee. 
    Every person offering any conveyance for record shall pay to the superintendent a recording fee of one dollar ($1.00) which sum shall be credited to the cemetery fund. 
Sec. 3.57. - Interments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to inter or cause to be interred the corpse of any person anywhere in this city except within a cemetery. 
Sec. 3.58. - Permits. 
    No corpse shall be interred in any cemetery or disinterred or removed from the city until a permit for such interment, disinterment or removal shall have been obtained from the health officer. Such permit shall be issued upon application made by the undertaker or other interested person, and the application shall state such information in regard to the deceased as may be required by the board of health. The superintendent shall cause to be kept a register of all interments and disinterments made in any city cemetery, in which shall appear the name of the deceased, the date and place of interment or disinterment, and such other information as may be required in the application for the permit. 
Sec. 3.59. - Fees. 
    The superintendent shall charge and cause to be collected on behalf of the city such fees for work performed in the cemeteries as may from time to time be determined by resolution of the city council. All such fees shall be credited to the cemetery fund. 
Sec. 3.60. - Opening graves. 
    No person other than an employee of the city acting under the direction of the superintendent shall dig or open any grave, nor shall any person grade or fill in any lot in any city cemetery unless such work shall be done under the supervision of the employee in charge of such cemetery. 
Sec. 3.61. - Trespass. 
    No person shall commit trespass or do any act upon the grounds of any such cemetery prohibited by state law or this Code. No person shall desecrate or in any manner violate the sanctity of any cemetery or the appurtenances thereof. No person shall pick or cut flowers or shrubs except on his own lot. No person shall cut down any tree within any such cemetery without first procuring a permit to do so. 
Sec. 3.62. - Cemetery funds. 
    All sums of money which may hereafter be paid into the city treasury for the perpetual care and preservation of cemetery lots or any monuments, tombs, headstones, markers, urns or other property used in connection therewith shall be held in a special fund, in trust, to be used solely for cemetery purposes and for no other purpose whatever. 
Sec. 3.63. - Regulations. 
    The parks and recreation board shall from time to time make such rules and regulations for the burial of the dead, for the care, management and protection of the grounds, monuments and appurtenances of the city cemeteries and for public use and orderly conduct of persons visiting the same as it may deem necessary. 
CHAPTER 30. - CITY OF SOUTHFIELD/SOUTHFIELD PUBLIC SCHOOLS JOHN GRACE COMMUNITY CENTER BOARD[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 1.151 et seq. 

Sec. 3.75. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.76. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this chapter is to create a community recreation center and a board in cooperation with the Southfield Public Schools, a Michigan municipal corporation, as permitted by Public Act 156 of 1917 (MCL 123.51 et seq.), Public Act 451 of 1976 (MCL 380.1 et seq.), and Section 6.10(d) of the Charter of the city and to delegate the operation of the facility of the City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.77. - Conduct of programs. 
    The city council does hereby join with the Southfield Public Schools for the conduct of community recreational programs as permitted by law, and in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.78. - Joint recreation board created. 
    The City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.79. - Membership. 
    The City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board shall consist of five (5) members. The chairman shall be selected by the John Grace Citizens Advisory Committee. One (1) member shall be selected by the Southfield Optimists Club. One (1) member shall be selected by the mayor of the city with the confirmation of the city council. One (1) member shall be selected by the Southfield Chamber of Commerce. One (1) member shall be selected by the Superintendent of the Southfield Public Schools. Each member shall serve for a term of three (3) years, which term shall commence on the effective date of Ordinance No. 1074. Each member shall serve until his or her successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.80. - Duties. 
    The City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board shall be responsible for: 
(a)  Approving an operating budget for programs, and approving a budget for building and grounds maintenance at the John Grace Elementary School, being Lots 7, 9, and the north 140 feet of Lot 11 of Thomas Hitchman's Subdivision, in the city; 
(b)  Appointing a program director who shall serve at the pleasure of the City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board, and whose duties shall be determined by the board; 
(c)  Establishing a policy for the utilization of the John Grace Elementary School, including the nature and extent of programs and other services conducted; 
(d)  Meeting regularly to review all phases of the community recreation center's operation and development, and ensuring that the city and school district representatives meet at least annually for the purpose of making a review and accommodation to their respective governing bodies regarding continuation of the programs. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Sec. 3.81. - Conduct of meetings. 
    Meetings of the City of Southfield/Southfield Public Schools John Grace Community Center Board shall be conducted in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, PA 267 of 1976, as may be amended. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 10-26-81) 
Title IV - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Special assessments for public improvements, § 1.221 et seq.; utility franchise, § 2.201 et seq.; zoning and planning, tit. V; design standards in subdivisions, § 5.325 et seq.; building regulations, tit. VIII. 

CHAPTER 33. - STREETS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Powers of council re streets, § 4.10. 
Cross reference- Duties of department of public service, § 1.132; street lighting service, § 2.301 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4.1. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Street shall mean all of the land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, alleys and boulevards in the city, and includes lawn extensions and sidewalks and the area reserved therefor where the same are not yet constructed. 
(2)  Department shall be deemed to refer to the department of public service of the city. 
(3)  Director shall mean the director of public service of the city. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 4.2. - Damage and obstruction prohibited. 
    No person shall make any excavation in or cause any damage to any street in the city, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this chapter. No person shall place any article, thing or obstruction in any street, except under the conditions and in the manner permitted in this chapter, but this provision shall not be deemed to prohibit such temporary obstructions as may be incidental to the expeditious movement of articles and things to and from abutting premises, nor to the lawful parking of vehicles within the part of the street reserved for vehicular traffic. 
Sec. 4.3. - Permits and bonds. 
    Where permits are authorized in this chapter, they shall be obtained upon application to the director, upon such forms as he shall prescribe, and there shall be a charge of one dollar ($1.00) for each such permit, except as otherwise provided by resolution of the city council. Such permit shall be revocable by the director for failure to comply with this chapter, rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this chapter, and the lawful orders of the director or his duly authorized representative, and shall be valid only for the period of time endorsed thereon. Application for a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed an agreement by the applicant to promptly complete the work permitted, observe all pertinent laws and regulations of the city in connection therewith, repair all damage done to the street surface and installations on, over or within such street, including trees, and protect and save harmless the city from all damages or actions at law that may arise or may be brought on account of injury to persons or property resulting from the work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Where liability insurance policies are required to be filed in making application for a permit, they shall be in not less than the following amounts, except as otherwise specified in this chapter: 
(1)  On account of injury to, or death of, any person in any one (1) accident ..... $100,000.00 
(2)  On account of any one (1) accident resulting in injury to, or death of, more than one (1) person ..... 300,000.00 
(3)  On account of damage to property in any one (1) accident ..... 5,000.00 
A duplicate executed copy or photostatic copy of the original of such insurance policy, approved as to form by the city attorney, shall be filed with the city clerk. Where cash deposits are required with the application for any permit under this chapter, such deposit shall be in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), except as otherwise specified in this chapter, and such deposit shall be used to defray all expenses to the city arising out of the granting of the permit and work done under the permit or in connection therewith. Six (6) months after the completion of the work done under the permit, any balance of such cash deposit unexpended shall be refunded. In any case where the deposit does not cover all costs and expenses of the city, the deficit shall be paid by the applicant. 
Sec. 4.4. - Street openings. 
    No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street without first obtaining a written permit from the director. No permit shall be granted until the applicant shall post a cash deposit and file a liability insurance policy as required by section 4.3. 
Sec. 4.5. - Emergency openings. 
    The director may, if the public safety requires immediate action, grant permission to make a necessary street opening in an emergency, provided that a permit shall be obtained on the following business day and the provisions of this chapter shall be complied with. 
Sec. 4.6. - Backfilling. 
    All trenches in a public street or other public place, except by special permission, shall be backfilled in accordance with regulations adopted pursuant to this chapter. Any settlement shall be corrected within eight (8) hours after notification to do so. 
Sec. 4.7. - Rubbish receptacles. 
    Rubbish receptacles conforming to the requirements of chapter 17 may be placed in a public alley or public place providing such rubbish receptacle or receptacles do not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
Cross reference- Container specifications, § 2.4; location of dumpsters, § 2.12; screening dumpsters from public view, § 2.13. 
Sec. 4.8. - Utility poles. 
    Utility poles may be placed in such streets as the director shall prescribe and shall be located thereon in accordance with the directions of the director. Such poles shall be removed or relocated as the director shall from time to time direct. 
Sec. 4.9. - Maintenance of installations in street. 
    Every owner of, and every person in control of, any estate hereafter maintaining a sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole or any other excavation, or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, pipe, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon any street which is adjacent to or a part of his estate shall do so only on condition that such maintenance shall be considered as an agreement on his part with the city to keep the same and the covers thereof, and any gas and electric boxes and tubes thereon, in good repair and condition at all times during his ownership or control thereof, and to indemnify and save harmless the city against all damages or actions at law that may arise or be brought by reason of such excavation or structure being under, over, in or upon the street, or being unfastened, out of repair or defective during such ownership or control. 
Sec. 4.10. - New paving.
