(3)  Residential lots abutting major thoroughfares or secondary thoroughfares, where marginal access streets are not desirable or possible to attain, shall be platted with reverse frontage lots with an approved screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line having a minimum width of fifteen (15) feet, or such other treatment as may be adequate for protection of residential properties, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets, or shall be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between building and such trafficway. 
(4)  Lots shall have a front-to-front relationship across all streets. Any deviation shall require the review and approval of the planning commission. 
Sec. 5.346. - Natural features. 
    The natural features and character of lands must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property, if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the proprietor and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers and easements, where appropriate, shall be required. 
Sec. 5.347. - Required improvements. 
    It is the purpose of this section to establish and define the public improvements which will be required to be constructed by the proprietor as conditions for final plat approval. All construction shall be in accordance with chapter 48 and in a manner approved by the city engineer. 
(1)  Sanitary sewers. When a proposed subdivision is located within, adjacent to or reasonably near the service area of a public sanitary sewerage system, sanitary sewers and other required appurtenances thereto shall be installed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots. 
(2)  Storm drainage. An adequate storm drainage system including necessary storm sewers, drain inlets, manholes, culverts, bridges and other appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions. Where surface drainage is required, easement provisions shall ensure unrestricted flow of storm drainage. 
(3)  Water supply. When a proposed subdivision is located within, adjacent to or reasonably near the service area of a public water supply system, fire hydrants and other required water systems appurtenances shall be constructed in such manner as to adequately serve all lots shown on the subdivision plat, both for domestic use and fire protection. If a public water supply system does not exist or is not available, a subdivision water supply system, if feasible, as determined by the city engineer, shall be installed by the proprietor. 
(4)  Streets. All streets and appurtenances thereto shall be constructed in accordance with chapter 48. 
(5)  Trees. Existing trees near street rights-of-way should be preserved by the proprietor. At least one (1) tree per lot shall be provided within the street right-of-way. Such trees shall have at least one and one-half-inch caliper measured one (1) foot above the ground. The type of tree and planting location shall be approved by the department of parks and recreation. The following trees shall not be permitted: 
a.  Box Elder; 
b.  Soft Maples (Red, Silver); 
c.  Elms; 
d.  Poplars; 
e.  Willows; 
f.  Horse Chestnut (nut bearing); 
g.  Tree of Heaven; 
h.  Catalpa. 
(6)  Sidewalk. Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of streets throughout any subdivision except in zoning districts having a minimum lot size of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or more. Sidewalks shall be required along all major and secondary thoroughfares, regardless of lot size. 
(7)  Drain for sump pump discharge. Lots not served by storm sewers constructed on the near side of the street shall be served by a sump pump drain line system located and constructed according to the requirements of chapter 48. 
Cross reference- City water utility, § 2.31 et seq.; city sewer service, § 2.101 et seq.; sewage disposal utility, § 2.168 et seq.; tree regulations, § 3.21 et seq.; subdivision and project improvements, § 5.361 et seq. 
Secs. 5.348-5.350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 5.351. - Standard details, standard specifications and general supplementary conditions. 
    The city standard details, standard specifications and general supplementary conditions as adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council shall be complied with. 
Sec. 5.352. - Compliance required. 
    The approvals required under the provisions of this chapter shall be obtained prior to the installation of any subdivision or project improvements within the city in public streets, public alleys, public rights-of-way and public easements, and/or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the city. All subdivision or project improvements within the city installed in public streets, public alleys, public rights-of-way or public easements, and/or under the ultimate jurisdiction of the city shall comply with all of the provisions and requirements of this chapter. 
Sec. 5.353. - Review fees. 
    Preliminary and final plat review fees, planning fees, engineering fees, attorney fees, inspection fees, water and sewer connection charges and other applicable development charges shall be paid by the proprietor as may be provided for by resolution of the city council. 
Sec. 5.354. - Planning review fees. 
    Fees shall be charged for the planning review of preliminary plats (stage 1) by the city on the basis of the schedule from time to time established by resolution of the city council. There shall be no additional planning review fee charged for preliminary plats (stage 2) or final plats which are in substantial conformance to a previously approved preliminary plat (stage 1). 
Secs. 5.355, 5.356. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - VARIANCES 

Sec. 5.357. - General. 
    The city council may authorize a variance from this chapter when, in its opinion, undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In granting any variance, the council shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest. In making its findings, as required in this section, the council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity, the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the council finds: 
(1)  That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land; 
(2)  That the variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner; 
(3)  That the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated. 
CHAPTER 48. - SUBDIVISION AND PROJECT IMPROVEMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities and services, tit. II; required improvements in subdivisions, § 5.347. 

Sec. 5.361. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a reasonable and proper basis for the design and construction of subdivision and project improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.362. - Compliance required. 
    All subdivision or project improvements within the city installed in public streets, public alleys, public rights-of-way or public easements, which are or will come under the ultimate jurisdiction of the city shall comply with all of the provisions and requirements of this chapter. No water supply system, public sanitary sewer, or public storm sewer designed to serve more than one (1) premises shall be constructed, reconstructed or altered in the city unless the request for construction, reconstruction or alteration is approved by the city engineer and appropriate permits are obtained from the city, county, state and other governmental agency that may be involved. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.363. - Permits required. 
    Permit to construct. Application shall be made to the city engineer on forms prescribed by the city engineer and shall be accompanied by plans and other information required by this chapter. At the time of application, the review fee, cash deposit, and testing fee deposit shall be paid and a cost opinion shall be provided as required further within this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1505, 7-26-04; Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.364. - Fees and deposits. 
(1)  Review fee. At the time of an application for a permit, there shall be paid a fee of two (2) percent of the cost of the proposed improvements as estimated by the registered professional engineer or land surveyor who prepared the plans for the improvements. The city engineer shall, from time to time, review this fee and make a report and recommendation to the council concerning the reasonableness of such fee. The city council, upon receiving such report and recommendation from the city engineer may, by resolution, change such fee or prescribe such additional fees as may be deemed reasonable and necessary. 
(2)  Inspection deposit. At the time of application for a permit, the applicant shall deposit with the engineering department to cover the cost of inspection, a percentage of the total contract price as follows: 
Contract amount Deposit required $0.00 to $5,000.00 $1,000.00 $5,000.00 to $50,000.00 20%, not less than $1,000.00 $50,000.00 to $100,000.00 18%, not less than $10,000.00 Over $100,000.00 15%, not less than $18,000.00  
A signed and sealed engineers cost opinion or a copy of the contract for the improvements shall be submitted with the application. The amount of the money remaining in the deposit shall be reviewed by the office of the city engineer from time to time during construction of the project and at completion of construction. If the funds are insufficient to cover the inspection costs, the city engineer shall require that the contractor or owner make an additional deposit. If at the completion of the project it is ascertained that the total inspection cost to the city was less than the amount deposited, the surplus shall, upon written request, be returned to the contractor or owner after the final acceptance of the project. The amount deposited shall be used to pay the cost of on-site inspection, inspection supervision, and an administration fee. Soils, compaction and materials inspection as found necessary by the city engineer shall be paid for by a separate deposit as stated in subsection (4) below. 
(3)  Cash deposit. At the time of application for a permit, the applicant shall place with the city a cash deposit in an amount to be set by the city engineer, but not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The purpose of this deposit is for the protection and restoration of public and/or private property other than the property owned or controlled by the landowner or developer. It will be used in case the contractor fails to repair or restore such properties. The cash deposit or any unused portion thereof will be returned to the contractor upon final acceptance of the project or subdivision improvements. 
(4)  Testing fee deposit. The city engineer shall estimate the amount and cost of testing of materials, workmanship and completed facility required on the project and shall require that a deposit be made by the owner or developer to cover the estimated costs. The city engineer shall order necessary testing from an approved testing company and the testing company shall be paid from the money deposited. The owner or developer may, at their option, hire a testing company acceptable to the city and pay for the service directly. In this case the owner or developer shall not deposit monies to cover the costs but shall instruct the testing company to provide testing at the direction of the city engineer. A "testing company" as used herein shall be a professional engineering firm established to and experienced in providing materials and field testing services. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 8-6-79; Ord. No. 1505, 7-26-04; Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.365. - Bonds and insurance. 
(1)  Performance guarantee and utility dedication surety. At the time of the issuance of a permit, the owner shall deposit a performance guarantee in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the estimated construction cost for such improvement in the form of cash, certified check, or irrevocable bank letter of credit. It is the intent of the performance guarantee to ensure that a permitted improvement, once undertaken, is completed or is, at the owner's option, terminated in a manner which leaves the city's existing utility system undamaged or restored and intact. At the time of issuance of a permit the owner shall also furnish a utility dedication surety. It is the intent of the utility dedication surety to ensure that all or the completed part of a permitted improvement can be accepted by the city without encumbrance. The utility dedication surety shall be in the form of cash escrow or an irrevocable bank letter of credit and shall be deposited with the city treasurer. Release of utility dedication surety shall be made after public improvements of the project have been installed properly in accordance with the approved plans, city standards, and have been accepted by the city council. The utility dedication surety shall be established in accordance with the schedule below: 
Cost Of Construction Surety Escrows Up to $10,000.00 $1,000.00 $10,000.01 to $50,000.00 10% but not less than $3,000.00 $50,000.01 to $100,000.00 10% $100,000.01 or more $10,000.00  
(2)  Insurance. At the time of issuance of a permit for subdivision and project improvements under the ultimate jurisdiction of the engineering department of the city the contractor shall procure and maintain, during the life of any contract or agreement for such construction, insurance meeting the requirements of the general supplementary conditions as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(3)  Maintenance and guarantee bond. Prior to acceptance of any project or subdivision improvements by the city, the owner or contractor who has installed such improvements shall furnish to the city a bond on the form provided and with sureties acceptable to the city, guaranteeing to maintain the improvements and to repair any defects therein for a period of two (2) years from and after the date of acceptance by the city council of the improvements. Such bond shall be in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the contract price for the improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.366. - Submittal and review. 
    For city approval of plans for improvements the applicant shall furnish to the engineering department, along with the application for a permit, five (5) sets of the project plans and specifications, including the general plan, for the system on which he desires approval. The city engineer shall review the plans for conformity to the standards set forth in this chapter, and certify that they are consistent with the overall utility plans of the city. The applicant, after making any changes requested, shall then submit the appropriate number of plans to the city engineer for final approval. The city engineer shall then review these revised plans for conformity to the comments mentioned above, and if they have been properly made, will request additional plans as necessary for ultimate approval and construction permit by the state and/or county departments. No construction shall be started until such permit(s) have been issued and all fees have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.367. - Plan requirements. 
(1)  All plans, easements, descriptions and design computations, maps and sketches shall be prepared by a registered engineer or registered land surveyor as is appropriate to the project or subdivision. All such documents shall bear the seal of the person who prepared them. 
(2)  Plans submitted shall be on twenty-four-inch by thirty-six-inch white prints having blue or black lines, and shall be neatly and accurately prepared. Judgment should be exercised in the design, layout and presentation of proposed improvements. 
(3)  For projects or subdivisions having more than one (1) sheet of plans, a cover sheet displaying a general plan having a scale of one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet shall be provided showing the overall project or subdivision and indicating the location of all improvements shown in the detailed plans. Superimposed on this general plan shall be one-foot contours of the area including the area at least one hundred (100) feet outside of the subdivision or project site. Street names, street and easement width, lot lines, lot dimensions and lot numbers shall be shown in all plans. Where possible the utilities shall be located in accordance with the city standards as established by the city engineer. Easements shall have a minimum width of twelve (12) feet. Sewers in easements shall be kept at least two (2) feet away from side or rear lot lines. 
(4)  City standard details and specifications as adopted by resolution of the city council shall be incorporated as part of the plans by reference. 
(5)  The standard notes as adopted by the city council shall be placed on the plans. 
(6)  The requirements of chapter 19, which relates to the site grading and drainage, and of chapter 49, soil erosion and sedimentation control of this City Code, may be combined on the plans with the requirements of this chapter. 
(7)  Easements shall be shown on the plans. 
(8)  Note on the plans other permits, such as county road, state highway, and drain commissioner, which are required. 
(9)  Note on the plans the testing required for acceptance of the improvements. 
(10)  Prior to starting any improvement design, the applicant may make use of maps and information available on the city's website under the engineering department. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to verify utility locations provided by the city. 
(11)  All sewers shall be shown in plan and profile. Profiles of sewers shall indicate the size, class of pipe, invert and slope of the sewer and type of bedding and shall indicate the existing ground along the route of the sewer and the proposed or existing top of curb or edge of pavement grade. The locations of compacted porous backfill required shall be indicated on the profile together with other existing or proposed utilities. 
(12)  Elevations shall be on city datum. Bench marks for the work shall be indicated on the plan. 
(13)  Finished grades of structures and hydrants shall be indicated on the plan or profile for all structures. 
(14)  Water main fittings. The plan shall indicate only such fittings, such as bends and reducers, which are not obviously otherwise identified. Indicate the locations, by proper dimensions, of such fittings. 
(15)  Curve data for all street and property line curves shall be indicated. 
(16)  The top of curb grade and elevation shall be indicated on the plan or profile for proposed paving project. 
(17)  A positive (white) photostat of the plat for subdivisions accurately reduced to a scale of one (1) inch equals two hundred (200) feet shall be furnished to the city for the purpose of obtaining addresses for lots in subdivisions. 
(18)  A copy of the computed plat for subdivisions shall be submitted with the engineering plans. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.368. - Design standards. 
    The following design standards shall be complied with in addition to the engineering design standards that shall be promulgated from time to time by the public works department: 
(1)  Sanitary sewers. 
(a)  Minimum slopes. The following table of minimum slopes for sanitary sewers shall be adhered to: 
Size and minimum slope 
10" at 0.30% 
12" at 0.22% 
15" at 0.15% 
18" at 0.12% 
21" at 0.10% 
24" at 0.08% 
Note: In the city, the minimum allowable size of a sanitary sewer is ten (10) inches in diameter. 
(b)  Bedding. A note or detail shall show that all sewer pipe shall be installed on a class B, or better, bedding. 
(c)  Manholes. Sanitary sewer manholes shall be spaced an average of three hundred (300) feet apart with an absolute maximum spacing of three hundred thirty (330) feet. Manholes shall be placed in the street right-of-way. In general, sanitary sewers will not be approved in the rear lot easement. 
(d)  Profile. The sewer profile shall indicate the length of run between each manhole, the size, class of pipe, etc., and slope of sewer between each manhole, and the class of bedding if class A bedding is required. Top elevations of all manholes shall be indicated. 
(e)  Depth. A minimum depth from top of curb (or road center line) to the top of any sanitary sewer of eight and one-half (81/2) feet at local control points, or a minimum of nine (9) feet at locations where the sewer grade is parallel to the road grade shall be provided. 
(f)  Design. Design data to support the pipe sizes used shall be submitted with the plans. The sewer shall be designed to meet the requirements of the county drain commission and the state department of environmental quality. 
(2)  Storm sewers. 
(a)  Design. Drainage systems shall be designed for a ten-year storm. The rational methods for arriving at stormwater runoff shall be used. The formula for rainfall intensity shall be equivalent to I = 175/T + 25 in which T is the time of concentration. The consulting engineer shall use judgment in arriving at proper impervious factors. The consulting engineer shall submit a map outlining the various areas which drain to the point of inlet used for design together with the storm sewer design computations and shall place his professional engineer seal thereon. 
In general, sufficient capacity shall be provided in the storm sewer system to take fully developed (fully paved and sewered) upstream drainage into the system. 
(b)  Design elevation. Where the hydraulic gradient is above the top of the sewer pipe the design elevation of the hydraulic gradient shall be indicated on the profile. 
(c)  Manholes. Manhole spacing for storm sewers shall be as follows: 
Diameter of sewer (inches) Absolute maximum manhole spacing 12-15 330' 18-30 350' 36 and 42 400' 48 450' 54 and 60 500' 66 and larger 600'  
Note: Minimum size of storm sewer is twelve (12) inches in diameter. 
Note: Height of horizontal elliptical pipe shall be used as the criteria for manhole spacing. Catch basins shall not be constructed over a sewer line to replace manholes. 
(d)  Profile. The profile for the storm sewer shall indicate: The length of run between each manhole, the size, type (such as C-76 Class IV, etc.) and slope of sewer between each manhole, and the class of bedding if Class A bedding is required. Show top elevations of all manholes. Where possible, the slope of the sewers shall provide a minimum velocity of two and five-tenths (2.5) feet per second for the sewer running full. Limits of required power compacted granular backfill shall be shown on the profile. 
(e)  Bedding. A note or detail shall show that all sewer pipe shall be installed on a class B except where better bedding is required by a note on the plans. 
(f)  Depth. Where possible provide a minimum of three (3) feet of cover from the top of curb (or road center line) to the top of any storm sewer. If the depth of cover to the top of pipe is less than one (1) foot, ASTM Specification C-76, class IV pipe shall be used. If the cover is between one (1) foot and three (3) feet from the top of curb to top of pipe, use C-76 class IV pipe. All catch basin leads within a street shall be C-76, class IV pipe, including the leads to the manhole. 
(g)  Catch basins. In general catch basins shall be located as follows: 
(i)  Five (5) feet back of the radius return of street intersections. One hundred (100) feet maximum distance along the street between a high point and a corner catch basin is allowed when drainage is required to go around the corner. Carrying drainage around the corner should be avoided insofar as is possible. 
(ii)  At all low points in streets. 
(iii)  On residential streets and residential collector streets at intermediate points along the street such that there is a maximum of six hundred (600) feet of drainage draining from a high point to a catch basin or from a previous intercepting catch basin to this catch basin. A maximum of nine hundred (900) feet of drainage is allowed from two (2) directions. On secondary and principal thoroughfares the spacing shall be designed for the paved area served. 
(iv)  Field catch basins shall be provided at all low points in easements. Locate intercepting field catch basins such that not more than six hundred (600) feet of drainage runs into any one (1) catch basin other than a low point catch basin. Twelve hundred (1,200) feet of drainage is allowed to run into a low point catch basin. Locate field catch basins in rear lot easement swale when such swale changes direction by more than forty-five (45) degrees. 
(h)  Easement grades. Finished easement grades shall be indicated on the plans. 
(i)  Open drains. Improved open drains may be permitted under special circumstances in accordance with section 5.374 of this chapter on variances. 
(j)  Headwalls. Headwalls and inlet structures shall be placed as required. 
(k)  Joints. All pipes shall have modified grooved tongue with rubber gasket joints. Sizes twenty-seven-inch and larger shall have inside of joints cement pointed. 
(3)  Water mains. 
(a)  Piping arrangement. Any water main in excess of sixteen hundred (1,600) feet in length between interconnections may be required by the engineer to be oversized. On dead ends where there is no possibility of a future extension a main installed not exceeding four hundred (400) feet in length. Where a dead end exceeds four hundred (400) feet in length, the developer will be required to extend the main to provide a loop or oversize the main, as directed by the engineer. No dead-end main shall connect to a looping main of smaller size. Water mains shall be designed and constructed with five (5) feet of earth cover from finished grade. Hydrants or blow-offs shall be installed at the end of all dead-end water mains. 
(b)  Minimum pipe sizes. 
(i)  Detached single-family and two-family residential buildings. The minimum size of water mains in these developments shall be eight (8) inches. 
(ii)  Attached single-family buildings of three or more dwelling units and low-rise multiple-family buildings. The standard size of water mains in these areas shall be twelve (12) inches and eight (8) inches. Eight-inch mains may be used only where it completes a good looped system and where the distance used between intersecting or looping water mains is one thousand (1,000) feet or less. 
(iii)  All other developments. The standard size of mains in these areas shall be twelve (12) inches. Eight-inch mains may be used only where it completes a good looped system and where the project designer can present design calculations which demonstrate that the required fire flow as established by the city engineer can be delivered by the mains in the project or subdivision with the minimum pressure loss stated in subsection (f) below. 
(c)  Valving. Gate valve spacing in general will be regulated by the requirement that in any single case of accident, breakage or repair not more than one (1) fire hydrant will be removed from service by the resultant main isolation and that no more than one thousand (1,000) feet of water main must be removed from service. This one thousand (1,000) feet is to be considered an absolute maximum. An average of six hundred (600) to eight hundred (800) feet between valves must be maintained. Gate valves shall be located in the system such that not more than four (4) valves need be turned off to isolate any section of water main. Where possible, gate valves shall be located at street intersections five (5) feet from the intersecting street right-of-way line. Sufficient valves shall be placed in single-family and low-rise multiple-family building areas such that not more than thirty (30) lots or dwelling units shall be serviced within such section of water main which can be so isolated. 
(d)  Hydrants. 
(i)  Street rights-of-way. In streets serving detached single-family and two-family dwelling unit buildings, maximum hydrant spacing shall be six hundred (600) feet. In streets serving all other land uses the maximum spacing shall be five hundred (500) feet. Where hydrants are placed within the block they shall be located approximately twenty-five (25) feet from the side lot line. Where near a street intersection, they shall be located fifteen (15) feet from the intersecting street right-of-way. Hydrants shall be placed within fifteen (15) feet of the curb line or shoulder to allow access by fire department equipment. Where a ditch lies between the hydrant and curb or shoulder, a culvert, minimum length twenty (20) feet, shall be installed in the ditch and fill placed to allow access to the hydrant. In all cases hydrants will be located in highly visible and accessible locations. Where street rights-of-way are one hundred (100) feet or wider, and buildings or residences are facing this right-of-way, hydrants shall be located alternately on both sides of the street. 
(ii)  Detached single-family and two-family dwelling unit buildings. Hydrants shall be placed in the street right-of-way so that no building is more than three hundred fifty (350) feet from a hydrant. 
(iii)  All other developments, buildings and structures. No part of any building or structure shall be more than two hundred fifty (250) feet from a hydrant. This distance shall be measured along the shortest feasible exterior route for laying hose. If the two-hundred-fifty-foot limit cannot be met from existing hydrants, additional water mains shall be installed with hydrants spaced no more than five hundred (500) feet apart to provide the required coverage. Such water mains shall be constructed in easements and the easements and water mains, with appurtenances, shall be dedicated to the city. Hydrants shall be located at least fifty (50) feet from the exterior wall of the building unless a closer location is allowed by the fire department. Driveways capable of accepting fire department equipment shall be provided adjacent to the hydrants. Plans for such additional water mains and appurtenances shall be reviewed and approved by the fire department prior to start of construction. Hydrants shall be placed no closer than five (5) feet to walls, earth mounds, berms, and other such obstructions. Four-inch diameter steel pipes filled with concrete shall be provided in parking lot and drive areas to protect hydrants from damage by vehicular traffic. The arrangement of the pipes is subject to approval by the fire department. The fire department may allow curbing in lieu of the pipes. 
(iv)  Hydrant leads. All hydrant leads shall be not less than six (6) inches, and six-inch leads shall be not more than forty (40) feet in length. Eight-inch leads will generally be required on rights-of-way wider than sixty-six (66) feet when the hydrant is located on the side opposite of the main. No hydrant leads may be connected to six-inch dead-end mains. All hydrant leads shall be valved. 
(v)  Hydrant pattern. Hydrants shall be approved Southfield Standard. All hydrants shall have two (2) four-inch steamer connections. 
(e)  Materials. All materials for pipes, fittings and appurtenances shall comply with the requirements of the standard specifications. 
(f)  Design. Pipe shall be sized to carry maximum day flow plus fire flow with pressure losses no greater than two (2) feet per one thousand (1,000) feet of pipe. 
(4)  Paving. 
(a)  Cross section. The paving section shall conform to the city's standard details and standard specifications as to width, thickness, minimum radius, jointing and other details of design and construction. All pavement shall be concrete with integral curb. Widening lanes on existing roads with shoulder and ditch may be constructed without curb if allowed by the city engineer. 
(b)  Grades. The minimum longitudinal grade shall be four-tenths (0.4) percent and the maximum shall be six (6) percent. Variations from these values may be allowed by the city engineer if the conditions of the project warrant such variations. The minimum slope around intersection returns shall be five-tenths (0.5) percent. 
(c)  Subbase and underdrain systems. A six-inch compacted granular subbase and underdrain system may be required if ground conditions are such as to make its use necessary. The consulting engineer shall make his own determination as to ground conditions and if requested shall furnish the city engineer with a statement of his determination and recommendation. If ground conditions are encountered during construction which warrant such subbase and underdrain system in the opinion of the city engineer he shall require that they be installed. 
(d)  Street and traffic signs. The developer or owner of the project shall have signing installed as required by the city traffic engineer. 
(5)  Sidewalks. 
(a)  Standard section, slope, location. Sidewalks, if included on project plans, shall be built on the specified line and grade. Width of walk is to be five (5) feet minimum. All sidewalks shall have a minimum thickness of four (4) inches, except at driveways where it shall be six (6) inches thick. All drive approaches shall be six (6) inches thick. The sidewalk shall pitch toward the street at the rate of one-quarter (1/4) inch per foot of width. The street edge of the sidewalks shall be set above the top of curb at a rate of not less than one-quarter (1/4) inch per foot of width of parkway or berm area. All residential sidewalk shall be one (1) foot off the property line. This standard location may be varied to respect natural features or amenities located in or near the right-of-way. Such variation is subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(b)  Ramps. At curbed street intersections and drive crossings, sidewalk ramps conforming to the standard details shall be installed with detectable warnings in accordance with the American with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990. 
(c)  Materials and workmanship. All materials and workmanship shall conform to the city's standard specifications. 
(d)  Joints. In all sidewalks, an expansion joint shall be placed at not more than fifty (50) feet. At street, driveway or crosswalk intersections, an expansion joint shall be placed between the new walk and the existing walk, driveway or curb. A contraction joint shall be placed at intervals of five (5) feet and at right angles to forms and walk surface. 
(6)  Drain for sump pump discharge. 
(a)  Materials and workmanship. All materials and workmanship shall conform to the city's standard specifications. 
(b)  Location. In single-family detached developments the drain may be placed along the rear lot line with wyes placed to serve each house backing on the line. In existing single-family detached developments the drain may be placed in the street right-of-way between the curb and sidewalk with leads to the property line on the near side only. In this case the drain shall be placed no deeper than three and one-half (31/2) feet, shall be laid at a grade paralleling the pavement grade, and shall be constructed after water and gas services have been installed. In two-family, attached single-family, townhouse and low-rise multiple developments which have separated basements serving individual units, the drain shall be placed in a manner consistent with other utilities in the project development plans. 
(c)  Application. Drains constructed under requirements of this section shall be used solely to accept sump pump discharge. They shall not be used to accept roof or yard drainage. 
(d)  Design. The drain shall be sized to accept simultaneously the discharge from all connected sump pumps pumping at their rated capacity. Minimum pipe size shall be eight (8) inches in diameter. The pipe shall be laid at a grade to produce a minimum velocity of two and one-half (21/2) feet per second when the pipe is running full. Cleanouts shall be placed at one-hundred-foot intervals along the drain and at the upper end of the line. The drain may discharge to a storm sewer wye connection, manhole, or catch basin. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.369. - Standard details, standard specifications, standard plan notes, general conditions and general supplementary conditions. 
    The city standard details, standard specifications, standard plan notes, general conditions and general supplementary conditions as adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council shall be complied with during preparation of plans and during construction of the improvements. The standard plan notes shall be placed on the plans. These specifications, details, notes and conditions are available on the city's website under the engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.370. - Compliance with other laws, codes and ordinances. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner, developer and contractor to meet the requirements of other parts of this Code applicable to the subdivision or projects as well as laws and rules administered by other governmental agencies. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.371. - Easements. 
    Easements must be prepared on city forms and submitted to the city engineer for review before he recommends issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.372. - Preconstruction meeting, inspection, testing and acceptance. 
(1)  After the requirements for issuance of the permit have been met and it has been recommended for issuance by the city engineer and before construction is started the contractor shall request a preconstruction meeting. The city engineer shall arrange the meeting and at the meeting shall review with the contractor the plans for the improvements, city requirements, other utilities and any other items pertinent to the improvements. 
(2)  Subdivision and project improvements shall be inspected during construction by an inspector assigned by the city engineer and/or the department of public services to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The contractor shall notify the city engineer at least forty-eight (48) hours before commencing work so that inspections may be scheduled. 
(3)  The inspector will inform the city engineer as to the progress of the work, the manner in which it is being done, and the quality of the materials being used. The inspector will call to the attention of the contractor any failure to follow the approved plans and city standard details and specifications that he may observe. The inspector shall have the authority to reject materials or suspend the work until any questions on the performance of the work can be referred to and decided by the city engineer. The inspector shall have no authority to direct the contractor's operations or to change the plans or specifications. 
(4)  In no instance shall any action or omission on the part of the inspector release the contractor of the responsibility of completing the work in accordance with the plans and specifications. 
(5)  The city engineer shall have authority to ensure that the finished work will be in accordance with the plans and specifications. He shall also have authority to reject all work and material which does not conform to the plans and specifications. 
(6)  The city engineer shall require such testing of materials and workmanship as is in his opinion necessary to ensure proper completion of the work. This testing shall include but not be limited to testing of density of material used to backfill excavations. 
(7)  Upon satisfactory completion of the improvements and upon receipt of the following items the city engineer shall recommend to the city administrator that the improvements be accepted by the city council. 
(a)  A quitclaim deed or bill of sale from the developer for these improvements; 
(b)  A letter from the engineers who designed the improvements indicating that the construction of these improvements has been completed in accordance with the approved plans; 
(c)  A letter from the engineers who designed the improvements indicating the final construction cost of these improvements; 
(d)  Three (3) sets of as-built drawings; 
(e)  Sworn statements from the contractors, indicating that all labor and materials have been paid in full; 
(f)  Maintenance and guarantee bond on the city form in favor of the city in the amount of one hundred (100) percent of the final construction cost of these improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.373. - Restoration. 
    The contractor shall restore, at his own expense, any public and/or private property damaged as a result of any act or omission on his part or on the part of his employees, agents or subcontractors to a condition equal to that existing before such damage or injury was done. If the contractor fails to begin to repair or restore such damage or injury within forty-eight (48) hours after ordered to do so by the engineering department the city engineer may order city forces to do so or may hire another contractor to make required repair and restoration and deduct the cost thereof from the cash deposit required under section 5.364 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
Sec. 5.374. - Variances. 
    The city council may authorize a variance from these engineering design standards and other requirements of this chapter when it determines that undue hardship may result from strict compliance. In granting any variance, the council shall prescribe other conditions that it deems necessary or desirable for the public interest. No variance shall be granted unless the city council finds: 
(1)  That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the subdivision or project improvement such that a strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of reasonable use of his property; and 
(2)  That the variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of substantial property right of the applicant; and 
(3)  That the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the area in which the property is situated. 
(Ord. No. 1547, § 1, 4-30-07) 
CHAPTER 49. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1564, adopted November 27, 2008, as amended by Ord. No. 1567, adopted February 17, 2009, amended ch. 49 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 49 consisted of §§ 5.501-5.573, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the original codification of this Code. 
Cross reference- Soil removal and landfills, § 5.251 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - PURPOSE AND AUTHORITY 

Sec. 5.501. - Purpose. 
    The city soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance (this chapter) is intended to protect the health, safety and welfare of the city residents and the public health, safety and welfare of the community by regulating earth change activities, which can harm the environment through erosion and the unnatural accumulation of sediment. The city council adopts this chapter pursuant to the provisions of part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, as amended (part 91), being MCL 324.9101 et seq. and the administrative rules promulgated by the state department of environmental quality. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 5.502. - Definitions. 
    The city adopts by reference the definitions in part 91 and the rules unless expressly given a different meaning in this chapter. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
(1)  Accelerated soil erosion means the increased loss of the land surface that occurs as a result of human activities. 
(2)  Agricultural practices means all land farming operations except plowing or tilling of land for the purpose of crop production or the harvesting of crops. 
(3)  Authorized local official means any person or persons appointed by city council who are authorized as ordinance enforcement officers responsible with the enforcement of chapter 49 of the City Code. 
(4)  Authorized public agency means a state agency or an agency of a local unit of government authorized by MDEQ under section 9110 of part 91 to implement soil erosion and sedimentation control procedures with regard to earth changes undertaken by it. 
(5)  Certificate of completion means a signed, written statement by the soil erosion engineer that the specific construction and inspections have been performed and that such work complies with the applicable requirements of part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(6)  City means the City of Southfield, Michigan. 
(7)  Designated agent means a person who has written authorization from the landowner to sign the application and secure a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit in the landowner's name. 
(8)  Earth change means a human-made change in the natural cover or topography of land, including cut and fill activities, which may result in or contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation of the waters of the state. Earth change does not include the practice of plowing and tilling soil for the purpose of crop production. 
(9)  Engineering department means the city engineering department. 
(10)  Grading means any leveling, stripping, excavating, filling, stockpiling, or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
(11)  Lake means the Great Lakes and all natural and artificial inland lakes or impounds that have definite banks, a bed, visible evidence of continued occurrence of water, and a surface area of water that is equal to, or greater than one (1) acre. "Lake" does not include sediment basins and basins constructed for the sole purpose of stormwater retention, cooling water, or treating polluted water. 
(12)  Landowner means the person who owns property in the city or who holds a recorded easement on the property or who is engaged in construction in a public right-of-way in accordance with sections 13, 14, 15, and 16 of Highway Obstructions and Encroachments; use of Highway by Public Utilities, 1925 PA 368, as amended, being 247.183, 247.184, 247.185 and 247.186 of the Michigan Complied Laws. 
(13)  MDEQ means the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality. 
(14)  Municipal enforcing agency means the engineering department, as designated by the city council under section 9106 of part 91. 
(15)  Municipality means any of the following: 
a.  A city. 
b.  A village. 
c.  A charter township. 
d.  A general law township that is located in a county with a population of two hundred thousand (200,000) or more. 
(16)  Non-erosive velocity means a speed of water movement that is not conducive to the development of accelerated soil erosion. 
(17)  On-site authorized agent means the person identified on the permit application by the landowner or the designated agent to be authorized and responsible for making decisions on behalf of the landowner. 
(18)  Part 91 means part 91, soil erosion and sedimentation control, of the Michigan Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, as amended, being MCL 324.9101 et seq. 
(19)  Permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means those control measures which are installed or constructed to control soil erosion and sedimentation and which are maintained after project completion. 
(20)  Rules means the rules promulgated pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, 1969 PA 306, being MCL 24.201 to 24.328 for the administration of part 91. 
(21)  Sediment means solid particulate matter, including both mineral and organic matter that is in suspension in water, is being transported, or has been removed from its site of origin by the actions of wind, water, or gravity and has been deposited elsewhere. 
(22)  Sediment basin means a naturally occurring or constructed depression used for the sole purpose of capturing sediment during and after an earth change activity. 
(23)  Soil erosion means the wearing away of land by the action of wind, water, or gravity; or a combination of wind, water, or gravity. 
(24)  Soil erosion and sedimentation control permit or permit means a permit issued by the soil erosion engineer to authorize work to be performed under the provisions of part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(25)  Soil erosion engineer means a person and/or other designees who has/have a certificate of training in soil erosion and sedimentation control from MDEQ and that is appointed by the engineering department to perform the responsibilities for administering and enforcing part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(26)  Stabilization means the establishment of vegetation or the proper placement, grading, or covering of soil to ensure its resistance to soil erosion, sliding, or other earth movement. 
(27)  State agency means a principal state department or a state public university. 
(28)  Stop work order means an order that stops all work on a project until any and all violations of part 91, the rules and this chapter are corrected, except for remedial measures to correct the violation. 
(29)  Stormwater retention basin means an area which is constructed to capture surface water runoff and which does not discharge directly to a lake or stream through an outlet. Water leaves the basin by infiltration and evaporation. 
(30)  Stream means a river, creek, or other surface watercourse which may or may not be serving as a drain as defined in the Drain Code of 1956, 1956 PA 40, as amended, being MCL 280.1 et seq., and which has definite banks, a bed, and visible evidence of the continued flow or continued occurrence of water, including the connecting waters of the Great Lakes. 
(31)  Temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures means interim control measures which are installed or constructed to control soil erosion and sedimentation and which are not maintained after project completion. 
(32)  Violation of part 91 or violates part 91 means a violation of part 91, the rules, or this chapter, or a permit issued under part 91 or this chapter. 
(33)  Waters of the state means the Great Lakes and their connecting waters, inland lakes and streams, as defined in the rules, and wetlands regulated under part 303, wetlands protection, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, being MCL 324.30301 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5.503. - Municipal enforcing agency. 
    The engineering department is hereby designated as the municipal enforcing agency responsible for administering and enforcing part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.504. - Jurisdiction. 
    The engineering department shall administer and enforce this chapter throughout the city except within the territorial boundaries of a governmental unit that has been designated by MDEQ as an authorized public agency pursuant to section 9110 of part 91. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.505. - Rules adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference and incorporates into this chapter as if fully set forth herein, the rules adopted by MDEQ pursuant to part 91 and duly filed with the Secretary of State. Said rules shall be available for public distribution at a reasonable charge and will be available for public inspection at the engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.506. - Fee schedule. 
    All fees for administering and enforcing this chapter shall be paid to the city in accordance with a fee schedule determined by resolution of the city council. The city council may revise the fee schedule by adopting a written amendment to the fee schedule from time to time. All fees shall be doubled if work starts without a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.507. - More restrictive provisions. 
    To the extent that any provisions or requirements of this chapter are more restrictive than, or are in addition to, the provisions or requirements of part 91 or the rules, this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING PERMITS 

Sec. 5.508. - Permits. 
    No building permit shall be issued by the department of building and safety engineering until the permit required under this chapter has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE V. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL PERMIT REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 5.509. - Activities requiring a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit. 
(a)  A landowner or designated agent who contracts for, allows, or engages in an earth change in this city shall obtain a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit in the landowner's name from the engineering department, unless exempted in section 5.510 of this chapter, before commencing an earth change which: 
1.  Disturbs one (1) or more acres of land; or 
2.  Is located within five hundred (500) feet of the waters of the state regardless of the amount of land disturbed; or 
3.  Is located within five hundred (500) feet of a storm drain inlet regardless of the amount of land disturbed. 
(b)  If an earth change is under the jurisdiction of two (2) or more municipal or county enforcing agencies, a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit from the engineering department is required for the activities under the jurisdiction of this chapter. 
(c)  If a soil erosion engineer serves a notice of violation in person or by certified mail, with return receipt requested, to a person who owns land on which an earth change has been made that may result in or contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation or adjacent properties or waters of the state, the landowner shall obtain a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit and implement and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures that will effectively reduce soil erosion or sedimentation from the land on which the earth change has been made (see section 324.9116). 
(d)  An earth change activity that does not require a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit under part 91, the rules or this chapter is not exempt from enforcement procedures under part 91, the rules or this chapter, if the activity exempted results in soil erosion and off-site sedimentation of adjacent properties or the waters of the state (see R323.1704(2)). 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9116; R323.1704. 
Sec. 5.510. - Permit exemptions and waivers. 
(a)  A soil erosion and sedimentation control permit is not required for the following: 
1.  Normal road and driveway maintenance, such as grading or leveling, that does not increase the width or length of the road or driveway and that will not contribute sediment to lakes, streams, drains, or regulated wetlands. 
2.  An earth change of a minor nature that is stabilized within twenty-four (24) hours of the initial disturbance and that will not contribute sediment to lakes, streams, drains or regulated wetlands. 
3.  Plowing or tilling of land for the purpose of crop production or the harvesting of crops. 
4.  Earth change associated with well locations, surface facilities, flow lines, or access roads relating to oil or gas exploration and development activities regulated under part 615, supervisor of wells, of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act, 1994 PA 451, being MCL 324.61501 et seq., provided the permit application to drill and operate contains a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan that is approved by MDEQ under part 615. However, those earth changes shall conform to the same standards as required for a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit under part 91, the rules and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9115; R323.1705. 
Sec. 5.511. - Permit application; designated agent; meeting with soil erosion engineer. 
(a)  A landowner or designated agent shall submit a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application to the engineering department. Copies of the permit application containing state prescribed information are available from the engineering department or the city website. 
(b)  The permit application shall be signed and dated by the landowner or designated agent. If the landowner is a corporation, include the name and title of the authorized corporate representative. 
(c)  If a designated agent is signing the application for the landowner, the landowner shall either also sign the application or provide a letter authorizing the designated agent to act on his/her behalf including authority for the designated agent to designate an on-site authorized agent. 
(d)  The soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application shall be accompanied by a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan, the required fees and any other documents that the soil erosion engineer may require. 
(e)  The landowner or designated agent shall meet with the soil erosion engineer, if requested, to ensure that the soil erosion and sedimentation control plan meets the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R323.1706. 
Sec. 5.512. - Soil erosion and sedimentation control plan; contents. 
    A soil erosion and sedimentation control plan shall be designed to effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and sedimentation, and shall identify factors that may contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation, or both. The plan shall be drawn to a standard engineering scale on sheets not exceeding twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches in size and include, but is not limited to, all of the following: 
(a)  A site location sketch showing the landowner's property boundaries and all waters of the state and major roads within five hundred (500) feet of the property boundary. 
(b)  A boundary surveyor legal description of the site. 
(c)  Name, address, and telephone number of the landowner and also the designated agent if the landowner is not completing the application. 
(d)  A map or maps at a scale of not more than two hundred (200) feet to the inch or as otherwise determined by the engineering department. The maps shall include: property boundaries; proximity of proposed earth change activities to waters of the state; predominate land features including structures and vegetation on-site and extending fifty (50) feet beyond property boundaries; and existing and proposed topographical contour intervals or slope descriptions. The engineering department shall determine the required contour information necessary to effectuate the provision of this chapter. Single-family home construction projects, or similar projects in size, may submit written information concerning the slope of the project area instead of a topographical sketch or map unless the engineering department determines, in writing, that a topographical sketch or map is needed. 
(e)  A soils survey or a detailed written description of the soil types of the exposed land area contemplated for the earth change. 
(f)  Details for the proposed earth changes including all of the following: 
1.  A description and the location of the physical limits of each proposed earth change. 
2.  A description and the location of all existing and proposed on-site drainage and dewatering facilities including downspouts from eaves troughs and storm and sump leads or discharge points for single-family residential sites, if applicable. 
3.  The timing and sequence of each proposed earth change. 
4.  A description, the location, and estimated costs of all proposed temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures along with a schedule for installing and removing each temporary control measure. 
5.  The location, a description, and the estimated costs of all proposed permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures and facilities along with the schedule for the installation and maintenance of all control measures and facilities. 
(g)  Any other information required by the soil erosion engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R323.1703. 
Sec. 5.513. - Earth change requirements; time; sediment removal; design installation, and removal of temporary or permanent control measures; standards and specifications. 
(a)  A person shall design, construct, and complete an earth change in a manner that limits the exposed area of any disturbed land for the shortest possible period of time as determined by the soil erosion engineer. 
(b)  A person shall remove sediments caused by accelerated soil erosion from runoff waters before it leaves the site of the earth change. 
(c)  A person shall design a temporary or permanent control measure that is designed and constructed for the conveyance of water around, through or from, the earth change area to limit the water flow to a non-erosive velocity. 
(d)  A person shall install temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures before or upon commencement of the earth change activity and shall maintain the measures on a daily basis. Temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be removed after permanent soil erosion measures are in place and the area is stabilized. A person shall stabilize the area with permanent soil erosion control measures pursuant to approved plans and under approved standards and specifications as prescribed by subsection 5.513(f) below. 
(e)  A person shall complete permanent soil erosion control measures for all slopes, channels, ditches or any disturbed land area as approved in the timing sequence schedule but no later than five (5) calendar days after final grading or the final earth change has been completed. If it is not possible to permanently stabilize a disturbed area after an earth change has been completed or if significant earth change activity ceases, then a person shall maintain temporary soil erosion and sedimentation control measures until permanent soil erosion measures are in place and the area is stabilized. 
(f)  A person shall install and maintain temporary and permanent control measures in accordance with the standards and specifications of all of the following: 
1.  The product manufacturer; 
2.  MDEQ; 
3.  County drain commission; and 
4.  Standards formally adopted by the city engineering department. 
(g)  If a conflict exists between standards and specifications referenced in this section, then the soil erosion engineer shall determine which specifications are appropriate for the project. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R323.1708, 323.1709, and 323.1710. 
Sec. 5.514. - Application review and permit procedures. 
(a)  The soil erosion engineer shall approve, disapprove, or require modification to an application for a permit within thirty (30) calendar days after the filing of a complete application for permit. A complete application includes the completed application, plans and required fees. The soil erosion engineer shall notify an applicant of approval by first class mail. If an application is disapproved, then the soil erosion engineer shall advise the applicant by mail of its reasons for disapproval and conditions required for approval. The soil erosion engineer need not notify an applicant of approval or disapproval by mail if the applicant is given written approval or disapproval of the application in person. A permit given to the applicant either in person or by first class mail constitutes approval. 
(b)  Upon determination that a permit applicant has met all the requirements of part 91, the rules, and this chapter, the soil erosion engineer shall issue a permit for the proposed earth change on a form that contains state prescribed information as well as that prescribed by the engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9112, R323.1707. 
Sec. 5.515. - Permit application disapproval. 
    The soil erosion engineer shall disapprove a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application where: 
(a)  The proposed work would cause uncontrolled soil erosion and/or off-site sedimentation; or 
(b)  The work proposed by the applicant will interfere with an existing drainage course in such a manner as to cause damage to any adjacent property; or 
(c)  The land area for which the work is proposed is subject to geological hazard to the extent that no reasonable amount of corrective work can eliminate or sufficiently reduce settlement, slope instability or any other such hazard to persons or property; or 
(d)  The soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application is incomplete or does not comply with the provisions of part 91, the rules or this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.516. - Permit modification; permit revocation or suspension. 
(a)  The soil erosion engineer may provide written authorization for modifications to a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit or the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan upon receiving a request from the landowner or on-site authorized agent. No work in connection with any proposed modification shall take place without the written approval of the soil erosion engineer. The soil erosion engineer may require new fees if the scope of the earth change activity has changed. 
(b)  Any permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended for any of the following reasons: 
1.  A violation of the condition of the permit. 
2.  Misrepresentation or failure to fully disclose relevant facts in the application or in the soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. 
3.  A change in a condition that requires a temporary or permanent change in the activity. 
4.  Authorized work is abandoned or suspended for a period of six (6) months. 
5.  Notice will be given to the permit holder of revocation or suspension of the permit in person or by certified mail and posting. If the permit has been revoked for any reason, a new soil erosion and sedimentation control permit application accompanied by new plans and fees would be required for any earth change activities. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.517. - Permit expiration; extension of time. 
(a)  Soil erosion and sedimentation control permits shall expire automatically upon the project completion date specified in the permit. If a project completion date is not specified then the permit shall expire one (1) year from the permit issuance date. The duration of a soil erosion and sedimentation control permit shall not exceed a period of two (2) years. Permits shall automatically expire if construction has not commenced within one (1) year of the date of issuance. 
(b)  If the landowner is unable to complete the earth change activities prior to the permit expiration date, the landowner or designated agent may request an extension of time provided the request is made in writing at least ten (10) days prior to the permit expiration date. The request shall include all relevant necessary sustaining reports, supporting documentation, and fees. 
(c)  If an extension of time is granted, the soil erosion engineer shall issue a written extension, which specifies a revised permit expiration date, not to exceed one (1) year. 
(d)  An extension does not release the owner, or the person furnishing an irrevocable letter of credit, or a person furnishing a cash bond, or a person furnishing a certificate of self-insurance from their responsibilities and/or liabilities thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.518. - Earth change requirements generally. 
    A person, the landowner, and the on-site authorized agent engaged in an earth change shall: 
(a)  Conduct the earth change in a manner that will effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and resulting sedimentation. 
(b)  Plan, implement, and maintain acceptable soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with part 91, the rules, and this chapter, which effectively reduce accelerated soil erosion and off-site sedimentation. 
(c)  Carry out the earth change activities in accordance with an approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan and in compliance with all the requirements of the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit, part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(d)  The soil and erosion sedimentation control permit must be posted on-site and clearly visible from the road. The soil erosion and sedimentation control plan must be available for inspection to the site of the earth change at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R323.1702; R323.1704(4). 
ARTICLE VI. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL PERMIT; BOND REQUIREMENTS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9108. 

Sec. 5.519. - Cash bond, irrevocable letter of credit. 
(a)  The soil erosion engineer may, as a condition for the issuance of a permit, require the landowner to post a cash bond or an irrevocable letter of credit with the engineering department in an amount sufficient to assure the installation and completion of such protective or corrective measures as may be required by the engineering department. 
(b)  A cash bond or irrevocable letter of credit shall include and be made on the conditions that the landowner shall comply with all of the provisions of part 91, the rules, and this chapter; all terms and conditions of the permit; and that the landowner shall complete all work contemplated under the permit within the time limit specified in the permit. 
(c)  In the event that the landowner fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the soil erosion and sedimentation control permit; or fails to comply with the provisions of part 91, the rules, or this chapter; or fails to implement the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan, the soil erosion engineer may order such work as necessary to provide for effective soil erosion and sediment control. The landowner or person issuing the irrevocable letter of credit or making the cash deposit shall continue to be firmly bound under a continuing obligation for the payment of all necessary costs and expenses, including legal, that the engineering department incurs in causing any and all work to be done to comply with the provisions of part 91, the rules or this chapter. In the case of a cash bond, the soil erosion engineer shall authorize the engineering department to refund any unused portion to the person who posted the bond. 
(d)  The engineering department may establish a list of pre-qualified contractors for use in ordering work required under subsection 5.519(c). 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE VII. - NOTICE OF COMPLETION; CERTIFICATE OF COMPLETION 

Sec. 5.520. - Completion. 
    Upon satisfactory execution of the approved plans and permit conditions and other requirements imposed under this chapter, the landowner shall file a written notice of completion with the soil erosion engineer. The soil erosion engineer shall make a final inspection within thirty (30) days of receiving the notice of completion and shall issue a certificate or letter of completion and release of bond if the landowner has satisfactorily complied with the plan, permit conditions and this chapter. If the project is to be completed in different phases, the landowner may submit a written notice of completion for a project phase and the soil erosion engineer may issue separate certificates of completion and authorize a proportionate release of a cash bond for each completed project phase. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
ARTICLE VIII. - ENFORCEMENT; NOTICE OF VIOLATION; COMPLIANCE TIME; VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 5.521. - Enforcement. 
    The city engineer or soil erosion engineer, in cooperation with the building department, may issue a stop work order, or revoke a permit upon its findings that there is a violation of part 91, the rules, or this chapter, or a finding that there is a violation of a permit or an approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R323.1712. 
Sec. 5.522. - Notice of violation. 
    If a soil erosion engineer determines that soil erosion or sedimentation of adjacent properties or the waters of the state has or will reasonably occur from land in violation of part 91, the rules, or this chapter, the engineering department may seek to enforce a violation by notifying the landowner through a notice of violation served in the following manner: 
(a)  In person; 
(b)  By certified mail, with return receipt requested. If a notification is served on a person by certified mail, a copy of the notice shall also be posted upon a conspicuous part of the land or upon the building or structure. 
    The notice shall contain a description of the violation and what must be done to remedy the violation and shall specify a time limit to comply with part 91, the rules, and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9117. 
Sec. 5.523. - Compliance; time. 
    Within five (5) calendar days after a notice of violation has been served under section 5.522 of this chapter, a person who owns land subject to part 91, the rules, or this chapter, shall implement and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with part 91, the rules, or this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9118. 
Sec. 5.524. - Entry upon land; construction; implementation, and maintenance of soil erosion and sedimentation control measures; cost. 
    Not sooner than five (5) calendar days after notice of violation has been served in person or mailed under section 5.522 of this chapter, if the condition of the land, in the opinion of the engineering department, may result in or contribute to soil erosion or sedimentation of adjacent properties or to the waters of the state, and if soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with part 91, the rules, and this chapter are not in place, the engineering department, or its designee, may enter upon the land and construct, implement, and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures in conformance with part 91, the rules, and this chapter. However, the engineering department shall not expend more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for the cost of the work, materials, labor, and administration without prior written notice in accordance with the notice of violation provided in section 5.522 of this chapter to the landowner that the expenditure of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) may be made. If more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) is to be expended under this section, then the work shall not begin until at least ten (10) days after the notice of violation has been mailed by certified mail with return receipt requested and posted, or served in person. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9119. 
Sec. 5.525. - Reimbursement of engineering department expenses; lien for expenses. 
    All expenses incurred by the engineering department under section 5.524 of this chapter to construct, implement, and maintain soil erosion and sedimentation control measures to bring land into compliance with part 91, the rules, and this chapter shall be reimbursed to the engineering department by the landowner. All persons that receive notice of expenditures incurred shall have thirty (30) days to pay the fines/costs to the city's engineering department. 
    If the fines/costs are not paid, the engineering department shall have a lien on the property for the expenses incurred under section 5.524 of this chapter for bringing the land into conformance with part 91, the rules, or this chapter. However, with respect to single-family or multifamily residential property, the lien for such expenses shall have priority over all liens and encumbrances filed or recorded after the date of such expenditure. The city shall collect such fines/costs through the procedures prescribed at section 1.13 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9120. 
Sec. 5.526. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  A person who violates part 91, the rules or this chapter is responsible for a municipal civil infraction issued by an authorized local official and may be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(b)  A person who knowingly violates part 91, the rules or this chapter or knowingly makes a false statement in an application for a permit or in a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan is responsible for the payment of a civil fine of not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each day of violation. 
(c)  A person who knowingly violates part 91, the rules or this chapter after receiving a notice of violation under section 5.521 or 5.522 is responsible for payment of a civil fine of not less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), or more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each day of the violation. 
(d)  Civil fines collected under subsection (a), (b) and (c) that are payable to the city shall be deposited into the city's general fund. 
(e)  A municipal civil infraction citation shall be filed with the 46th Judicial District Court for resolution pursuant to chapter 87 of the revised Judicature Act, MCL 600.8701 et seq. 
(f)  A default in payment of a civil fine or costs ordered under this section or an installment of the fine or costs may be remedied by any means authorized under the revised Judicature Act of 1961, 1961 PA 236, as amended, being MCL 600.101 et seq. 
(g)  In addition to a fine assessed under this section, a person who violates part 91, the rules, or this chapter, is liable to the state and/or the city for damages for injury to, destruction of, or loss of natural resources resulting from the violation. The court may order a person who violates this part to restore the area or areas affected by the violation to their condition as existing immediately prior to the violation. 
(h)  Lessees, contractors, or other individuals undertaking an earth change, as well as the landowner and on-site authorized agent, are liable for civil penalties prescribed in section 5.526. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 324.9121. 
ARTICLE IX. - INJUNCTION; INSPECTION AND INVESTIGATION; INTERFERENCE WITH ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 5.527. - Injunction.
