    Notwithstanding the existence or pursuit of any other remedy, MDEQ or the city may maintain an action in its own name in a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain or prevent violations of part 91, the rules or this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.528. - Right of entry and inspection. 
    An agent appointed by MDEQ or the city engineering department may enter at all reasonable times in or upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions or practices that may be in violation of part 91, the rules, or this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
Sec. 5.529. - Interference with administration and enforcement. 
    No person shall unlawfully hinder, oppose or resist the soil erosion engineer in the discharge of the administration and enforcement of part 91, the rules or this chapter. No person shall remove, mutilate or conceal any notice or placard posted by the soil erosion engineer except by written permission of the soil erosion engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 11-27-08) 
CHAPTER 50. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1394, adopted July 22, 1996, deleted ch. 50, historic preservation, and enacted similar provisions as herein set out in §§ 5.601-5.609. Former ch. 50 derived from Ord. No. 1150, § 1, adopted October 9, 1984. 
Cross reference- Burg Historic District, § 5.701 et seq.; Brooks School Historic District, § 5.725 et seq.; general building regulations, § 8.201 et seq. 

Sec. 5.601. - Purposes of chapter. 
    Historic preservation is declared to be a public purpose, and the city may regulate the construction, reconstruction, addition, alteration, repair, moving, excavation, and demolition of resources in historic districts within the limits of the city as provided in this chapter. The purposes of this chapter are to: 
(a)  Safeguard the heritage of the city by preserving areas in the city which reflect elements of its cultural, social, spiritual, economic, political engineering or architectural history or its archaeology; 
(b)  Stabilize and improve property values in each historic district and the surrounding areas; 
(c)  Foster civic beauty and community pride; 
(d)  Strengthen the local economy; 
(e)  Promote the use of historic districts for the education, pleasure and welfare of the citizens of the city, the state and of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.602. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
(1)  Advisory board means the historic designation advisory board which shall be considered a standing committee as defined by the Michigan Local Historic Districts Act (MCL 399.201 et seq.) and created by section 5.603. 
(2)  Commission means the historic district commission created by section 5.604. 
(3)  Demolition means the razing or destruction, whether entirely or in part, of a resource and includes but is not limited to, demolition by neglect. 
(4)  Demolition by neglect means neglect in maintaining, repairing, or securing a resource that results in deterioration of an exterior feature of the resource or the loss of structural integrity of the resource or any of the following conditions: 
(a)  The deterioration of exterior walls or other vertical supports; 
(b)  The deterioration of roofs or other horizontal members; 
(c)  The deterioration of exterior chimneys; 
(d)  The deterioration of exterior plaster or mortar; 
(e)  The ineffective weatherproofing of exterior walls, roofs and foundations, including broken windows and doors; or 
(f)  The serious deterioration of any documented exterior architectural feature or significant landscape feature which, in the judgment of the commission, produces a detrimental effect upon the character of the district. 
(5)  Department means the building department. 
(6)  Design treatment levels means categories of standards used by the historic district commission as general guides in the determination of appropriateness of proposed work within a historic district. One (1) or more of these categories shall be selected for each historic district at the time of designation by the process as described in this chapter. The design treatment levels are as follows: 
(a)  Restoration: Bringing back into a former or unimpaired state or condition which existed at a date prescribed by the ordinance establishing the district. Authenticity of a restoration would require the removal of incompatible exterior elements and the replacement of all damaged or deteriorated elements with replicas of the same design and materials. A restoration design treatment level shall not be assigned without the written consent of the owner of the affected property at the time of designation. An appellant seeking a permit shall be responsible for documenting the authenticity of proposed work to the satisfaction of the commission. 
(b)  Rehabilitation: Putting back in good condition. This would not require the removal of all nonoriginal materials, but would encourage the removal of nonoriginal materials which are incompatible with the defined elements of design for the particular structure and district. The design of new construction or alteration would not require a duplication of the original design and construction, but must be compatible with the existing structures and the district's defined elements of design. The use of original materials or construction techniques would be encouraged but contemporary methods and materials would also be acceptable when compatible with the defined elements of design for the district. 
(c)  Conservation: Giving new life and making vital by cleaning, repairing and replacing of worn, cracked or broken parts with compatible materials and/or protecting from blight or deterioration through normal maintenance. The use of contemporary building methods or materials would be acceptable if they are compatible with the defined elements of design for the district. 
(7)  Elements of design are the characteristic relationships of the various features within a historic district which are significant to the appearance of the district. Elements of design to be defined for each historic district are: 
(a)  Height; 
(b)  Proportion of buildings front facades; 
(c)  Proportion of openings within the facade; 
(d)  Rhythm of solids to voids in front facades; 
(e)  Rhythm of spacing of buildings on streets; 
(f)  Rhythm of entrance and/or porch projections; 
(g)  Relationship of materials; 
(h)  Relationship of textures; 
(i)  Relationship of colors; 
(j)  Relationship of architectural details; 
(k)  Relationship of roof shapes; 
(l)  Walls of continuity; 
(m)  Relationship of significant landscape features and surface treatments; 
(n)  Relationship of open space to structures; 
(o)  Scale of facades and facade elements; 
(p)  Directional expression of front elevations; 
(q)  Rhythm of building setbacks; 
(r)  Relationship of lot coverages; 
(s)  Degree of complexity within the facades; 
(t)  Orientation, vistas, overviews; 
(u)  Symmetric or asymmetric appearance; 
(v)  General environmental character. 
(8)  Historic district means a district designated by the city council for the purposes of this chapter. An historic district shall include an area or group of areas, not necessarily having contiguous boundaries, that contains one (1) resource or a group of resources that are related by history, architecture, archeology, engineering, or culture of particular significance to the city, the state or to the United States of America. Historic districts may be either publicly or privately owned in whole or in part. These districts include significant landscape features, surface textures, and street furniture located therein. 
(9)  Historic preservation means the identification, evaluation, establishment, and protection of resources significant in the history of architecture, archeology, engineering or culture. 
(10)  Proposed historic district means an area or a group of areas not necessarily having contiguous boundaries having defined boundaries and which is or are under review by the advisory board for recommendation to the city council for designation under this chapter. 
(11)  Work means any demolition, alteration, moving, repair, excavation, new construction or erection of any resource including a building, fence, wall or other structure or significant landscape feature, including pavements. The term also includes any removal of an architectural or significant landscape feature, as well as reconstruction, alteration, a change of surface treatment, a change of color by painting or other means or any demolition of a structure, a portion thereof or significant landscape feature. 
(12)  Alteration means work that changes the detail of a resource but does not change its size or shape. 
(13)  Bureau means The Bureau of History of the Michigan Department of State. 
(14)  Certificate of appropriateness means the written approval of a permit application for work that is appropriate and does not adversely affect a resource. 
(15)  Denial means the written rejection of a permit application for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource. 
(16)  Historic resource means a publicly or privately owned building, structure, site, object, feature, or open space that is significant in the history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, or culture of the city, state or nation. 
(17)  Notice to proceed means the written permission to issue a permit for work that is inappropriate and that adversely affects a resource, pursuant to a finding under section 5.605. 
(18)  Open space means undeveloped land, a naturally landscaped area, or a formal or man-made landscaped area that provides a connective link or a buffer between other resources. 
(19)  Ordinary maintenance means keeping a resource unimpaired and in good condition through ongoing minor intervention, undertaken from time to time, in its exterior condition. Ordinary maintenance does not change the exterior appearance of the resource except through the elimination of the usual and expected effects of weathering. Ordinary maintenance does not constitute work for purposes of this chapter. 
(20)  Repair means to restore a decayed or damaged resource to a good or sound condition by any process. A repair that changes the external appearance of a resource constitutes work for purposes of this chapter. 
(21)  Resource means one (1) or more publicly or privately owned historic or nonhistoric buildings, structures, sites, objects, features, or open spaces located within a historic district. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.603. - Historic designation advisory board. 
(a)  The city council shall establish an historic designation advisory board which shall be a standing committee as defined in the Michigan Local Historic Districts Act (MCL 399.201 et seq.). The board shall have a majority of persons who have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. Seven (7) members of the advisory board shall be permanent members with full voting privileges. Four (4) of the permanent members shall be the city planner (ex officio), the chairman of the planning commission (ex officio), the building official (ex officio), and a member of the parks and recreation board. An ex officio member may designate another member of his or her staff to fill his or her position. The remaining three (3) permanent members of the advisory board shall be appointed by the city council and shall include at least one (1) representative from a duly organized local historic preservation organization. In addition, two (2) ad hoc members shall be appointed to the advisory board to represent each proposed historic district under consideration. Ad hoc members shall have voting privileges only on matters concerning the area they represent. Ad hoc members shall be property owners, residents or other persons having a demonstrated special affiliation with the area under consideration. When only a single resource constitutes the proposed historic district, at least one (1) of the ad hoc members shall be an owner, or part owner, of the resource, and the owner or part owner so appointed may designate a person to represent the owner or part owner on the board. Ad hoc members must be residents of the city except in a case where no resident is available to represent the ownership interest as required herein, in which case a nonresident may serve. The ad hoc members shall be appointed within twenty-one (21) days from the date of city council action authorizing the advisory board to conduct a study of the proposed district. 
(b)  Appointments of permanent members shall be for three (3) years on a staggered-term basis. Terms of ad hoc members shall terminate at the time of designation or the termination of consideration of their area for designation as an historic district. Permanent members shall be eligible for reappointment. Vacancies for the unexpired term of an appointed position may be filled by appointment by the city council. 
(c)  The advisory board shall conduct regularly scheduled meetings. All meetings of the advisory board shall be open to the public. A majority of members serving and eligible to vote shall constitute a quorum with respect to matters before the advisory board. The vote of the majority of members present at a meeting at which a quorum is present constitute the action of the advisory board. Notices of meetings, including an agenda of matters to be considered, shall be mailed to all known property owner organizations, community organizations and citizens' district councils in any area to be considered for designation at such meetings. Notices of all meetings, including an agenda of matters to be considered, shall be mailed to any existing historical preservation societies in the city, including but not limited to any historical district associations, the mayor, the city council, the city administrator, the city planning commission, the planning department, the building department, and the parks and recreation department. Interested persons shall be given reasonable opportunity to be heard on any matter before the advisory board before it reaches a decision. The advisory board shall keep a record, which shall be open to public view, of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions. 
(d)  The advisory board will be provided with reasonable staff assistance within the determination of the city administrator upon the request therefor by the advisory board. 
(e)  The advisory board shall conduct studies for each proposed historic district, including: 
(1)  A photographic inventory of resources; 
(2)  Basic research for each proposed historic district and the resources within that district; 
(3)  Determination of the total number of historic and nonhistoric resources and the percentage of historic resources located within each district; in determining the significance of resources the board shall be guided by the criteria for inclusion in the national register of historic places as set forth in 36 C.F.R. part 60, and criteria established or approved by the bureau, if any. 
The advisory board's preliminary report shall address at a minimum the charge to the board, the composition of the board membership, the historic district(s) being considered, the boundaries of the proposed historic district(s) in both writing and on map(s), the history of each proposed district, and the significance of each district as a whole as well as a sufficient number of its individual resources to fully represent the variety of resources found within the district relative to the evaluation criteria. 
A copy of the advisory board's preliminary report shall be sent to the city planning commission, the Bureau, the Michigan Historical Commission, and to the State Historic Preservation Review Board, and shall be made available to the public as provided by state law. Not less than sixty (60) calendar days from transmittal of the advisory board preliminary report, the advisory board shall conduct a public hearing on a proposed historic district designation at which time the requirements, procedures, standards and responsibilities of historic district designation shall be generally explained. Public notice of the time, date and place of the hearing shall be given in the manner provided by state law. Written notice shall be mailed by first-class not less than fourteen (14) calendar days before the hearing to the owners of properties within the proposed historic district, as listed on the city's tax rolls. 
(f)  The advisory board's final report to the city council shall contain the recommendation of the advisory board and a draft of the proposed ordinance establishing the new historic district, including the design treatment levels and the definitions of the elements of the design. 
(g)  The advisory board shall also maintain a current listing of potential historic districts and a brief statement of significance for each. Such listing shall be made available to the city planning commission and the planning department for consideration relative to the city master plan. Such listing also shall be made available to the building department. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.604. - Historic district commission. 
(a)  An historic district commission is hereby established. It shall be composed of seven (7) members. Members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the city council. Members shall reside in the city. A majority of the members shall have a clearly demonstrated interest in or knowledge of historic preservation. The membership shall include, if available, a graduate of an accredited school of architecture who has two (2) years of architectural experience or who is an architect registered in this state, and at least two (2) members selected from lists of citizens submitted by one (1) or more duly organized historical preservation organizations. 
(b)  Appointments shall be for three (3) years on a staggered term basis; initial terms may be for less than three (3) years to satisfy the staggered term. Members shall be eligible for reappointment. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of the position in the same manner as the original appointment. All vacancies, whether from expiration of terms or from resignation, removal, or other cause shall be filled within sixty (60) calendar days. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, the commission shall be responsible for the implementation and administration of this chapter; this responsibility shall include the following powers and duties: 
(1)  As provided by section 5.603(e), the review of advisory board reports and recommendations concerning proposed historic districts in relation to the city's officially adopted master plan; the practical budgetary effects on city resources; legal implications for the owners, residents and the city; and the historical and architectural values of the district. Upon completion of any such review, the commission may submit its recommendation to the city council regarding the proposed historic district designation, design treatment levels and elements of design. A copy of any such recommendation also shall be transmitted by the commission to the advisory board. 
(2)  The review of building permit applications, as provided in this chapter, for designated historic districts, interim historic districts, and proposed historic districts. 
(3)  To request that the building department require the correction of defects or repairs on buildings in designated historic districts as provided in this chapter. 
(4)  To review all city-licensed or city-funded physical development projects affecting designated or proposed historic districts or which may have demonstrable effects on designated or proposed historic districts as provided in this chapter; 
(5)  To conduct regularly scheduled meetings. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public and notices shall be sent by first-class mail not less than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days before a meeting. A majority of members serving shall constitute a quorum. Notices of meetings, including an agenda of matters to be considered, shall be mailed to all known property owner organizations, community organizations and citizens district councils in any proposed historic district or in any designated district where a permit application is to be considered at such meetings. Notices of all meetings, including an agenda of matters to be considered, shall be mailed to any existing historical preservation societies in the city, including but not limited to any historic district associations, the mayor, the city council, the city administrator, the advisory board, the city planning commission, the planning department the building department, and the parks and recreation department. Interested persons shall be given reasonable opportunity to be heard on any matter before the commission before it reaches a decision. The commission shall keep a record of its resolutions, proceedings and actions, which shall be made available to the public consistent with state law; 
(6)  To advise the city council and other city agencies in the administration of any gifts, purchase or sale of property, administration of a loan and grant program or tax incentive program or any other program concerning historic preservation; 
(7)  To promulgate guidelines defining documentation requirements for work in designated districts; 
(8)  To make periodic inspections of all designated historic districts for violations of this chapter; 
(9)  To make available copies of the designation, design treatment level assignment and defined elements of design for any designated district. 
(d)  Staff assistance for the commission will be provided within the determination of the city administrator. 
(e)  The commission may delegate to its staff such responsibility and authority as it determines will be appropriate to carry out routine enforcement activities. The commission may also delegate the issuance of certificates of appropriateness for specified minor classes of work to its staff or to another delegated authority. The commission shall provide to the delegated authority specific written standards for issuing certificates of appropriateness under this subsection. On at least a quarterly basis, the commission shall review the certificates of appropriateness, if any, issued for work by its staff or other delegated authority to determine whether or not the delegation of such authority should be continued. 
(f)  The directors (or designees thereof) of the planning department and the building department shall have the right to participate in meetings of the commission on the same basis as members, except that these officers (or their designees) shall not have voting rights on any matter taken up by the commission, including matters of procedure, and shall not be counted as members for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.605. - Establishment of designation by ordinance. 
(a)  Upon the receipt of a request to city council from any person residing, doing business or owning property in the city to designate a resource or resources as an historic district, or on its own initiative, the city council, after making a determination that there are reasonable grounds for such a request, may adopt a resolution directing that the advisory board make a study to determine whether the proposed district meets the criteria under the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  After the adoption of a resolution directing the advisory board to study a proposed historic district, the commission shall, for a period of up to one (1) year from the date of the public hearing before the advisory board, review all building permit applications for informational purposes only and shall inform the applicant of the existence of the request to have the resource or resources designated an historic district. This review period shall be extended by a resolution of the city council extending the period of consideration of the proposed historic district. 
(2)  Upon receipt of substantial evidence showing the presence of historical, architectural, archaeological, engineering or cultural significance of a proposed historic district, the city council may, at its discretion, adopt a resolution of interim historic district designation, requiring that all applications for permits for work within the proposed historic district, be referred to the commission. For a period of one (1) year after the adoption of such a resolution, the commission shall review permit applications for work within such proposed historic districts with the same powers which would apply if the proposed historic district were a designated district, notwithstanding provisions to the contrary elsewhere in this chapter. After the expiration of the one (1) year period following adoption of such a resolution, the commission review shall be for informational purposes only, as provided in subsection (a)(1) of this section. In reviewing permits for work in proposed historic districts, the commission shall consider the following: 
a.  The architectural or historical value and significance of the structure or feature and its relationship to the historical value of the proposed historic district; 
b.  The relationship of the exterior architectural features or landscape features to the remainder of the structure, site or area forming the proposed historic district; 
c.  Any other factor, including aesthetic, which the commission deems to be pertinent; 
d.  The provisions of subsection 5.605(d)(5). 
(b)  The city council shall establish historic districts by ordinance and may establish districts previously considered and rejected; modify boundaries of an existing historic district; or eliminate an existing historic district in accordance with the requirements and procedures of the Michigan Local Historic Districts Act (MCL 399.201 et seq.). City zoning maps shall reflect established historic designations. In all historic district designations, the boundaries, elements of design, and design treatment levels shall be specified in the designation ordinance. An ordinance establishing an historic district, modifying the boundaries of an existing historic district, or eliminating an historic district shall also be filed with the register of deeds by the city clerk. 
(c)  In evaluating the significance of resources to be included in historic districts, the historic designation advisory board and the city council shall be guided by the criteria for inclusion in the National Register of Historic Places, as published at 36 C.F.R. part 60, and criteria established or approved by the bureau, if any. The historic designation advisory board shall make available to the public a document stating the criteria for historic designation. 
(d)  Permit applications are required as follows: 
(1)  Before work, as defined in this chapter, commences within an historic district, an interim historic district, or proposed historic district, the person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government proposing to do that work shall file an application for a building permit with the building department, and no work shall begin before the issuance of a building permit. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a complete building permit application, the building department shall, within seven (7) calendar days, forward the same, together with all plans, specifications, and supporting materials which make it complete, to the commission. All plans, elevations, construction documents, and any other information deemed necessary by the commission to make the application complete and to determine the appropriateness of the proposed work shall be submitted to the commission by the applicant before the application will be considered to have been received by the department or by the commission. 
(3)  The commission shall approve a building permit application for work which it determines to be appropriate in a designated or interim historic district through the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness. In reviewing plans for the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall follow the U.S. Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings as set forth in 36 C.F.R. part 67, using those standards in relation to the design treatment levels and the defined elements of design for a designated historic district to give consideration to the permit application. Design review standards and guidelines that address special design characteristics of historic districts administered by the commission may be followed if they are equivalent in guidance to the Secretary of Interior's Standards and are established or approved by the bureau. The commission shall also consider the following: 
a.  The historical or architectural value and significance of the resource structure and its relationship to the historical value of the surrounding area; 
b.  The relationship of any exterior architectural features of the resource to the remainder of the resource and to the surrounding area; 
c.  The general compatibility of the exterior design, arrangement, texture and materials proposed to be used; 
d.  Any other factor, including aesthetic, which the commission finds to be relevant. 
(4)  If it is determined by the director of the building department that work is immediately necessary for the protection of the public health and safety, the department may issue a building permit for the necessary work and shall immediately notify the commission of that action. 
(5)  Pursuant to the Michigan Local Historic Districts Act (MCL 399.201 et al.) as amended, an application for inappropriate work adversely affecting the exterior appearance of a resource which cannot be granted a certificate of appropriateness shall be permitted by the commission through the issuance of a notice to proceed if any of the following conditions prevail and the commission finds that the work is necessary to substantially improve or correct any of these conditions: 
a.  The resource constitutes a hazard to the safety of the public or the occupants; 
b.  The resource is a deterrent to a major improvement program which is of substantial benefit to the community. Substantial benefit shall be found only if the applicant proposing the work has obtained all necessary planning and zoning approvals, financing, and environmental clearances and the improvement program is otherwise feasible; 
c.  Retention of the resource would cause undue financial hardship to the owner. Undue financial hardship shall be found only when a governmental action, an act of God, or other events beyond the owner's control created the hardship, and all feasible alternatives to eliminate the financial hardship, which may include offering the resource for sale at its fair market value or moving the resource to an appropriate vacant site within the historic district have been attempted and exhausted by the owner, for a minimum period of one (1) year; 
d.  Retention of the resource would not be in the interest of the majority of the community. 
(6)  In cases of resource additions, demolitions or new construction in a designated historic district, the commission shall conduct a public hearing. The commission may also conduct a public hearing on other historic preservation matters for informational purposes. All notices of public hearings shall be mailed to the applicant, all persons to whom any real property within five hundred (500) feet of any part of the premises in question is assessed and the occupants or building managers within five hundred (500) feet of the premises. All known property owner organizations, community organizations, and citizens district councils in the historic district or proposed historic district within which the premises is located, historic preservation societies in the city including, but not limited to, any historic district associations, the mayor, the city council, the historic designation advisory board, the building department, and the city planning commission. The commission shall conduct a public hearing no sooner than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) calendar days from the time the notice is mailed. Such notice shall include the time and place of the hearing and a general description of the nature of the work proposed. 
(7)  For work in designated or interim historic districts, within sixty (60) calendar days after receipt of a complete application by the commission or within such further time as the applicant and the commission agree upon in writing, the commission shall determine: 
a.  Whether the proposed work will be appropriate according to the design treatment levels and defined elements of design for the historic district and the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings (36 C.F.R. part 67), in which case the commission will issue a certificate of appropriateness; or 
b.  Whether the proposed work will be inappropriate according to the secretary's standards and the design treatment levels and defined elements of design for the historic district, but is without substantial detriment to the public welfare and without substantial derogation from the intent and purposes of this chapter, and where, one or more of the conditions of section 5.605(d)(5) have been met, in which case the commission may, in lieu of a certificate of appropriateness, issue a notice to proceed; or 
c.  Whether the proposed work will be inappropriate according to the secretary's standards and the design treatment levels and defined elements of design for the historic district, in which case the commission will issue a denial. A denial shall be issued to the permit applicant in writing, accompanied by a written explanation by the commission of the reasons for the denial and, if appropriate, a notice that the application may be resubmitted for the commission's review when suggested changes have been made. The written notice of denial shall also include notification of the applicant's right of appeal as provided for in section 5.608(b); 
d.  If the commission fails to act on a permit application within sixty (60) calendar days after the date a complete application is filed with the commission, or to act within such extended period of time as has been agreed to in writing by the commission and the applicant, the building department shall issue to the applicant a building permit for the proposed work as if the commission had issued a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed. 
(8)  If the commission issues a certificate of appropriateness or a notice to proceed, or a denial for proposed work in a designated or interim historical district, the commission shall immediately forward its decision, together with the building permit application, plans and specifications to the building department. 
(9)  If the commission decides to issue a denial for work in a designated or interim historic district, it shall forthwith state on the record the reasons for such decision, and may include an appropriate alternative proposal. Thereupon, the commission shall notify the applicant and the building department of such decision, transmitting to each a copy of the reasons and any alternatives suggested by the commission. The building department, upon receipt of the commission's report, shall be bound by the commission's decision and shall deny the applicant a building permit for the proposed work. 
(10)  The commission's review of permit applications for work in proposed historic districts shall be for informational purposes only unless the proposed historic district has been designated an interim historic district by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.606. - Consideration of interior features. 
    The commission may review and act upon interior features only if specifically authorized to do so in the ordinance designating the district or unless interior work will cause visible change to the exterior of the resource. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.607. - Ordinary maintenance or repair. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent ordinary maintenance of any structure within any historic district. Ordinary maintenance includes any repair which does not change the external appearance of the resource and is not defined as work in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.608. - Powers and duties of commission; enforcement. 
(a)  If it is determined by the commission that a resource in an historic district is being demolished by neglect, the commission, on its own initiative, and to ensure that the resource shall be preserved and protected in consonance with the purposes of this chapter, may: 
(1)  Require the owner of the resource to repair all conditions contributing to demolition by neglect; the commission may also file a petition with the building department requesting that the building department require the correction of defects or necessary repairs of the resource; or 
(2)  If the owner does not make the necessary repairs within a reasonable time, the commission may then file a petition with the building department requesting that the building department, as the agent of the commission and pursuant to an order from the Circuit Court, enter the property and cause the necessary corrections or repairs to be made and the cost, if not paid promptly by the property owner to be reported to the city assessor for levy as a special assessment against the property. 
(b)  In addition to other enforcement rights created by this chapter, the requirements of an historic district may be enforced upon the complaint of any property owner or association of property owners within the district. Any citizen or duly organized historic preservation organization in the city, as well as resource property owners, jointly or severally aggrieved by a decision of the historic district commission may appeal the decision to the circuit court, except that a permit applicant aggrieved by a decision rendered under section 5.605(d)(1) through (10) of this chapter may not appeal to the court without first exhausting the right to appeal provided in MCL 399.205(2). 
(c)  Any person or organization, individuals partnership, firm, corporation, institution, or agency of government performing work within a designated historic district, prior to the issuance of the required building permit or contrary to conditions specified in any permit issued for work within a district shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  In cases where there is imminent danger of the loss of a designated historic resource, the commission may request the law department to seek such injunctive relief as it deems necessary and appropriate to preserve the resource. 
(e)  A person, individual, partnership, firm, corporation, organization, institution, or agency of government that violates this chapter may be ordered by the commission and/or by the court to pay the costs to restore or replicate a resource unlawfully constructed, added to, altered, repaired, moved, excavated, or demolished. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
Sec. 5.609. - Effect of proposed projects on designated or proposed historic districts. 
    The head of any city agency having direct or indirect jurisdiction over a proposed city or city-assisted physical development project and the head of any city agency or authority or corporation established by the city having power to finance, license, permit, authorize or contract for any physical development project shall, prior to authorization or approval, take into account the effect of the proposed project on any designated or proposed historic district. If the proposed district is within or immediately adjacent to a designated or proposed historic district, the responsible agency or authority or corporation shall so advise the commission and shall comply with all reasonable requests of the commission for information on the proposed project. The commission shall determine the demonstrable effects of the proposed project and report same to the mayor, city council and city administrator within sixty (60) days of being advised of the proposed project by the responsible agency, authority or corporation. Nothing in this section shall be construed to require a delay or interruption in project activities pending completion of the commission's review and report. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to diminish the rights and powers held by the city council with respect to such project activities. 
    A city-financed, licensed, permitted, authorized or contracted physical development project shall be considered to have a demonstrable effect on a designated or proposed historical district when any condition of the project creates a change, beneficial or adverse, in the quality of the historical, architectural, archaeological, engineering, social or cultural significance that qualified the property for designation as an historic district or may qualify the property for designation as an historic district. Generally, adverse effects occur under conditions which include: 
(a)  Destruction or alteration of all or part of a resource; 
(b)  Isolation from or alteration of the surrounding environment of a resource; 
(c)  Introduction of visual, audible or atmospheric elements that are out of character with the resource and its setting; 
(d)  Transfer or sale of a city-owned resource without adequate conditions or restrictions regarding preservation, maintenance or use; and 
(e)  Neglect of a resource resulting in its deterioration or destruction. 
(Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 7-22-96) 
CHAPTER 51. - BURG HISTORIC DISTRICT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Historic preservation, § 5.601 et seq. 

Sec. 5.701. - Intent. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to establish a historic district to be known as the Burg Historic District; and is established in accordance with the provisions of section 5.605. 
    This historic district designation is hereby certified as being consistent with the city master plan. 
(Ord. No. 1188, 11-25-85) 
Sec. 5.702. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the Burg Historic District are as shown on the map on file in the office of the city clerk; and more particularly described as follows: 
    A parcel of land being all of Lots 37 and 38 and part of Lot 36 of Supervisor's Plat No. 1, part of Section 20 and part of the west one-half of Section 21 Township 1 North, Range 10 East, City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan, being further described as beginning at a point, said point being distant south 89 degrees 07 minutes 30 seconds east, thirty-three feet along the east-west one-fourth line of Section 21 and north 01 degrees 55 minutes and 50 seconds west, 123 feet from the west one-quarter corner of said Section 21; thence along the east right-of-way line of Berg Road north 01 degrees 55 minutes 50 seconds west, 430.59 feet; then south 89 degrees 44 minutes 24 seconds east, 384.70 feet; thence 5.01 degrees 54 minutes 29 seconds east, 434.72 feet; thence north 89 degrees 07 minutes 30 seconds west, 384.70 feet, to the point of beginning, containing 3.817 acres. 
(Ord. No. 1188, 11-25-85) 
Sec. 5.703. - Design treatment levels. 
    The design treatment level of the Burg Historic District shall be conservation as provided in section 5.602(5). 
(Ord. No. 1188, 11-25-85) 
Sec. 5.704. - Elements of design. 
    The defined elements of design, as provided for in section 5.602(6) shall be as follows: 
(1)  Height. All of the buildings in the district shall be one (1) to two and one-half (21/2) stories in height, meaning they may have two (2) full stories with an attic or a finished third floor within the roof. 
(2)  Proportion of buildings front facades. Proportion varies in the district, depending on style, size and age of buildings. 
(3)  Proportion of openings within the facade. Areas of voids generally constitute between five (5) percent and twenty-five (25) percent of the front and side facades, excluding the roof. Window openings are usually taller than wide, divided into individual panes with muntins and mullions. A variety of sizes and shapes exist within the district. 
(4)  Rhythm of solids to voids in front facades. The structures in the district display a variety of placement of openings within the facades. The Town Hall, Fire Hall and Methodist Church exhibit a regularity of opening placement. 
(5)  Rhythm of spacing of buildings on streets. There is a variety of placement of buildings on the streets, either Berg Road or Civic Center Drive. 
(6)  Rhythm of entrance and/or porch projections. Porches exist on most of the buildings in the district, with the exception of the D.P.S. Garage. Positions of porches contribute to a variety of the design of the buildings and may either be placed asymmetrically on the front of the building depending on the original design. 
(7)  Relationship of materials. The districts' predominant building material is wood. Buildings are wood frame construction with wood siding. Wood details and trim are prevalent. Original roofing materials have been replaced by asphalt shingles and fieldstone foundations have been replaced with cement block. Common red brick walkways have been added for pedestrian circulation. Newer buildings, the Fire Hall and D.P.S. Garage, are cement block construction. 
(8)  Relationship of textures. The most common textural relationship in the district is provided in the horizontal wood siding on the buildings. Additional textural relationships are provided for in the wood detailing and trim, shingle patterns, running bond paving and textures in lawn and landscape materials. 
(9)  Relationship of color. The most prevalent color for the buildings is white provided for in the painted white wood siding or painted cement block of the structures. Shutters are either black or other dark colors. Roofs, not original, are dark colors. Walkways are common red brick. Original color schemes for any given building may be determined by a professional paint analysis and deemed appropriate for that building. 
(10)  Relationship of architectural details. Architectural details generally relate to style. The predominant architectural style at the Burgh is reflective of its rural midwestern surroundings. Simple wood frame construction with a minimum to moderate amount of detailing utilizing indigenous materials typifies the architectural detailing for the district. 
(11)  Relationship of roof shapes. The predominant roof types in the district are either hipped or gabled, with gables frequently intersecting. The buildings which were originally residences have roof shapes of greater complexity. 
(12)  Walls of continuity. There are no major walls of continuity caused by the placement of buildings on the site. Buildings are sited at right angles to each other. Some buildings walls are set on the same line. 
(13)  Relationship of significant landscape features and surface treatment. The characteristic landscape features and surface treatments for the district include open lawn areas traversed by walkways, planted with large shade and small ornamental trees. Some deciduous and evergreen shrub and groundcover beds are planted adjacent to the buildings. Most plant material is typical of ornamental plantings used in the region from 1840 to 1900. An asphalt parking lot has been added in recent years. 
(14)  Relationship of open space to structures. Most of the open space in the district is used as landscaped lawn areas with walks and flower beds. The Parks House, Simmons House, Methodist Church and the D.P.S. Garage all are set off by large open spaces on their front or side yards while the Fire Hall and Town Hall are set in a smaller space. A courtyard has been established in their side yard. The open space within the district serves as a commons. Visually, it is not divided according to lot lines but has a unified appearance. 
(15)  Scale of facades and facade elements. The scale of all the buildings in the district is relatively small, directly relating to human scale. 
(16)  Directional expression of front elevations. The majority of the buildings in the district have vertically expressed front facades with the exception of the D.P.S. Garage which is horizontal. 
(17)  Rhythm of building setbacks. There is no consistent setback for the buildings within the district. 
(18)  Relationship of lot coverage. Lot coverage averaging over the entire district runs approximately six (6) percent. Lot coverage in the north third of the district is greater; approximately fifteen (15) percent. 
(19)  Degree of complexity within the facade. The degree of complexity is determined by what is appropriate for a given style. The buildings in the district exhibit simple forms, colors, materials and textures within the facades. The two (2) houses in the district have a greater amount of complexity in their facades. 
(20)  Orientation, vistas, overviews. The Simmons House, D.P.S. Garage, Methodist Church and Parks House are oriented south toward Civic Center Drive with large open spaces between the buildings and the road. The Town Hall and Fire Hall front west, toward Berg Road, with relatively short setbacks. 
(21)  Symmetric or asymmetric appearance. The Town Hall, Fire Hall and Methodist Church generally exhibit a symmetrical appearance, while the D.P.S. Garage, Simmons House and Parks House exhibit an asymmetrical appearance. 
(22)  General environment character. The character of the district is based on its origin as a late nineteenth to early twentieth century midwestern farming settlement with residential, commercial, and governmental uses. Cohesiveness for the district through the use of uniform building materials, colors, textures, siting of buildings and common green space. 
(Ord. No. 1188, 11-25-85)

Sec. 5.727. - Design treatment level. 
    The design treatment level of the Brooks School Historic District shall be conservation as provided for in section 5.602(5)(c). 
(Ord. No. 1245, § 1, 4-25-88) 
Sec. 5.728. - Elements of design. 
    The defined elements of design, as provided for in section 5.602(6), shall be as follows: 
(1)  Height. All buildings in the district shall be no taller in height than the existing Brooks School building. 
(2)  Proportions of building front facades. Shall be similar in nature to the Brooks School building. 
(3)  Proportions of openings within the facade. Areas of voids generally constitute between five (5) percent and thirty (30) percent of building facades. Window openings are of several different sizes and shapes. 
(4)  Rhythm of solids to voids in front facades. The existing structure displays a variety of placements of openings within the facades. Most facades exhibit a regularity of opening placement. 
(5)  Rhythm of spacing of buildings on streets. There is no defined rhythm of building spacing. 
(6)  Rhythm of entrance and/or porch projections. The main building entrance is asymmetrically placed on the east facade, while a secondary entrance is symmetrically placed on the west facade of the building. 
(7)  Relationship of materials. The district's predominant building material is brick. The Brooks School is of wood frame construction with a brick facade in a running bond pattern. Original roofing materials have been replaced by asphalt shingles. There is minor detailing in limestone window sills. 
(8)  Relationship of textures. The most common textural relationship in the district is provided in the brick facade of the building. Additional textural relationships are provided for in the limestone and brick detailing and shingle patterns. 
(9)  Relationship of color. The most prevalent color for the district is provided by the natural brown of the brick facade of the Brooks School. Window trim is painted dark brown with limestone sills. 
(10)  Relationship of architectural details. Architectural details generally relate to style. The predominant architectural style of the historical buildings in Southfield reflect their rural midwestern surroundings. Minimal architectural detailing in the masonry of the Brooks School typifies the architectural detailing for the district. 
(11)  Relationship of roof shapes. The predominant roof type in the district is hipped and/or gabled, with gables intersecting. The Brooks School also has a cupola. 
(12)  Walls of continuity. There are no major walls of continuity in the district. 
(13)  Relationship of significant landscape features and surface treatment. There are no significant landscape features or surface treatments in the district. 
(14)  Relationship of open spaces to structures. The Brooks School is set at the intersection of Eleven Mile Road and Lahser Road set off to the south and west by large open space typical of a school yard. 
(15)  Scale of facades and facade elements. The scale of the Brooks School building is relatively small, directly relating to human scale. 
(16)  Directional expression of front elevation. The Brooks School building facades are horizontally expressed. 
(17)  Rhythm of building setbacks. The district setback is set by the building facades of the Brooks School. 
(18)  Relationship of lot coverage. Lot coverage in the district runs approximately three (3) percent. 
(19)  Degree of complexity within the facade. The Brooks School exhibits simple forms, colors, materials and textures within the facade. 
(20)  Orientation, vistas, overviews. The Brooks School is oriented north/south and east/west along the alignments of Eleven Mile and Lahser Roads. 
(21)  Symmetric or asymmetric appearance. The Brooks School exhibits an asymmetrical appearance. 
(22)  General environmental charter. The character of the district centers on the architectural style, scale of materials and the Brooks School structure itself. Cohesiveness for the district shall be provided by maintaining the use of uniform building materials, scale, colors, textures and siting of buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1245, § 1, 4-25-88) 
CHAPTER 53. - LOG CABIN HISTORIC DISTRICT 

Sec. 5.750. - Intent. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this chapter to establish a historic district to be known as the Log Cabin Historic District; and which is established in accordance with the provisions of section 5.605. 
(b)  This historic district designation is hereby certified as being consistent with the city master plan. 
(Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 5.751. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the Log Cabin Historic District are as shown on the map on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be: 
    Legal Description: A parcel of land located in the W. 1/2 of the N.W. 1/4 of Section 27, T.1N., R.10E., City of Southfield, Oakland County, Michigan and more particularly described as commencing at the N.W. corner of said Section 27, distant S. 01 10'00? W., 1731.55 feet along the west line of said Section 27 and S. 41 52'00? E., 87.94 feet to the POINT OF BEGINNING; thence continuing S. 41 52'00? E., 261.29 feet; thence S. 87 39' 40? W., 178.65 feet; thence along a line 60.0 feet each of and parallel to the said west line of Section 27, N. 01 10'00? E., 201.91 feet to the point of beginning and contains 0.41 acres. 
.61 acres       Sidwell No. 2427-101-013 
(Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 5.752. - Design treatment levels. 
    The design treatment level of the Log Cabin Historic District shall be conservation as provided for in section 5.602(5). 
(Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 5.753. - Elements of design. 
    The defined elements of design, as provided for in section 5.602(6) shall be as follows: 
(1)  Height: All buildings in the district shall be one-story and no taller than the existing log cabin structure. 
(2)  Proportions of building front facades: Shall be similar in nature to the existing log cabin building. 
(3)  Proportions of openings within the facade: Areas of voids generally constitute between five (5) and twenty-five (25) percent of building facades. Window openings are of several different sizes and shapes. 
(4)  Rhythm of solids to void in front facades: The existing structure displays a variety of placements of openings within the facades. 
(5)  Rhythm of spacing of building on streets: There is no defined rhythm of building spacing. 
(6)  Rhythm of entrance and/or porch projections: The main building entrance is asymmetrically placed on the west facade. 
(7)  Relationship of materials: The districts predominant building materials are logs, primarily twelve inches (12?) in diameter or larger. The logs are hand hewn and interior construction is wood paneling, all fitted without nails. Roof is asphalt shingles. An addition of modern wood construction is located on the north end of the structure. Windows are of wood construction. 
(8)  Relationship of textures: The predominant textural relationship is provided in the log construction of the building. 
(9)  Relationship of color: The most prevalent color for the district is provided by the dark brown stain on the exterior log surfaces. Window frames are also dark brown and the roof is tan. 
(10)  Relationship of architectural details: Architectural details for this district relate primarily to the hand-hewn and fitted log cabin construction of the building. Minimal and/or "rustic" architectural detailing typifies this district. 
(11)  Relationship of roof shapes: The predominant roof type in this district is hipped and/or gabled. 
(12)  Wall of continuity: There are no significant walls of continuity within the district. 
(13)  Relationship of significant landscape features and surface treatment: The site is heavily wooded with some major evergreen and deciduous trees. The trees are important to retain the historic character of a "log cabin in the woods". Surface treatment is natural ground covers with a gravel drive. Extensive lawns or paving are incongruous with the nature of this district. 
(14)  Relationship of open spaces to structures: The log cabin is set adjacent to Lanser Road and overlooks the ravine to the rear of the property. 
(15)  Scale of facades and facade elements: The scale of the log cabin is small, directly relating to human scale. 
(16)  Directional expression of front elevation: The log cabin's front elevation is horizontally expressed. 
(17)  Rhythm of building setbacks: The districts setback is determined by the setback of the log cabin building from Lanser Road. 
(18)  Relationship of lot coverage: Lot coverage in the district runs approximately five (5) to ten (10) percent. 
(19)  Degree of complexity within the facade: The log cabin exhibits simple form, color, and texture within the facade. 
(20)  Orientation, vistas, overviews: The log cabin is oriented north/south along Lahser Road. A significant vista, from the rear of the building, overlooks a ravine containing the Evans Branch of the Rouge River. 
(21)  Symmetric or asymmetric appearance: The log cabin exhibits an asymmetric appearance. 
(22)  General environmental character: The character of this district centers on the original log cabin construction of the building. Cohesiveness for the district relies on maintaining and preserving the integrity of this structure and limiting and controlling any future additions to the building or significant site development. 
(Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 12-11-89)

    The design treatment level of the McDonnell House Historic District shall be conservation provided for in section 5.602(5).

Sec. 5.757. - Elements of design. 
    The defined elements of design, as provided for in section 5.602(6) shall be as follows: 
(1)  Height. All of the building in the district shall not exceed two and one-half stories in height, meaning they may have two (2) full stories with an attic of a finished third floor within the roof. 
(2)  Proportion of buildings front facades. Proportion varies in the district, depending on style, size and age of buildings. 
(3)  Proportion of openings within the facade. Areas of voids generally constitute between five (5) percent and twenty-five (25) percent of the front and side facades, excluding the roof. Window openings are usually taller than wide, divided into individual panes with muttons and mullions. A variety of sizes and shapes exist within the district. 
(4)  Rhythm of solids to voids in front facades. The structure in the district displays a regular placement of openings within the facade. 
(5)  Rhythm of spacing of buildings on streets. The McDonnell House faces Twelve Mile Road with out buildings behind the main house. The setback of the building is approximately eighty-five (85) feet from the front lot line and no buildings shall be permitted in this existing yard. 
(6)  Rhythm of entrance and/or porch projects. The house has a front porch. 
(7)  Relationship of materials. The district's predominant building material is wood. Buildings are wood frame construction. Wood details and trim are prevalent. Original roofing materials have been replaced by contemporary building materials. Original wood clapboard siding has been covered with contemporary building materials that maintain the horizontal character of the original clapboard siding. 
(8)  Relation of textures. The most common textual relationship in the district is provided in the horizontal siding on the buildings. Additional textural relationships are provided for in the wood detailing and trim, shingle patterns, and textures in lawn and landscape materials. 
(9)  Relationship of color. The most prevalent colors of the buildings are white and forest green. 
(10)  Relationship of architectural details. Architectural details generally relate to style. The predominant architectural style of the McDonnell House is reflective of its rural Midwestern surroundings and American Greek Revival architecture. Simple wood frame construction with a minimum to moderate amount of detailing utilizing indigenous materials typifies the architectural detailing of the district. 
(11)  Relationship of roof shapes. The predominant type of roof in the district is gable. Any modifications to the McDonnell House or other existing or new structures should maintain the same roof pitch. 
(12)  Walls of continuity. There are no major walls of continuity caused by the placement of the house on the site. 
(13)  Relationship of significant landscape features and surface treatment. The characteristic landscape features and surface treatments for the district include open lawn areas traversed by walkways, planted with large shade and small ornamental trees. Some deciduous and evergreen shrub and groundcover beds are planted adjacent to the buildings. Most plant material is typical of ornamental plantings used in the region from 1840 to 1900. The driveway and parking areas are gravel and dirt, which reflects elements of the culture and architectural history of the district. 
(14)  Relationship of open space to structures. Most of the open space in the district is used as landscaped lawn areas. 
(15)  Scale of facades and facade elements. The scale of all the buildings in the district is relatively small, directly relating to human scale. 
(16)  Directional expression of front elevations. The McDonnell House has a vertically expressed front facade. 
(17)  Rhythm of building setbacks. The front setback is determined by the McDonnell House. 
(18)  Relationship of lot coverage. Maximum lot coverage for buildings in the district shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent. 
(19)  Degree of complexity within the facade. The degree of complexity is determined by what is appropriate for a given style. The McDonnell House exhibits simple forms, colors, materials and textures within the facades. 
(20)  Orientation, vistas, overviews. The McDonnell House is oriented south toward Twelve Mile Road, with an open yard between the buildings and the road. Any building addition to the district shall adhere to the guidelines established herein. 
(21)  Symmetric or asymmetric appearance. The McDonnell House generally exhibits a symmetrical appearance. 
(22)  General environmental character. The character of the district is based on its origin as a late nineteenth to early twentieth century Midwestern farmstead. Cohesiveness exists for the district through the use of uniform building materials, colors, textures, siting of buildings and common green space. 
(Ord. No. 1316, 1-14-91) 
CHAPTER 59. - CITY CENTRE ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 5.990. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and cited as the "City Centre Advisory Board Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 5.991. - Establishment. 
    In order to promote economic activity in the city centre, and to provide for the maintenance, security, and operation of the city centre, the city centre advisory board is hereby established pursuant to Act No. 146 of the Public Acts of 1992. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 5.992. - Boundaries of the city centre. 
    The city centre advisory board shall exercise its authority within the area designated as the City Centre Mixed Use Area in the city's future land use plan as delineated on Exhibit "A" attached hereto and made a part hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Note- Said Exhibit "A" referred to in § 5.992 above is not set out in this article, but is on file and available for inspection of the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 5.993. - Organization. 
    The city centre advisory board shall be composed of eleven (11) members who shall be appointed by the mayor with the concurrence of the council. At least seven (7) of the members of the board shall be nominees of the businesses located within the boundaries of the city centre as defined in the preceding section. One (1) member of the board shall be a resident from a residential area adjacent to the city centre, and one (1) member of the board shall be an officer, official, or other representative of the city. Of the members first appointed, three (3) shall be for one (1) year, three (3) shall be for two (2) years, and three (3) shall be for three (3) years. A member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. Thereafter, members shall serve for a term of three (3) years. An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be made by the mayor with the concurrence of council for the unexpired term only. Members of the board shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. A chairperson of the board shall be elected by the members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92; Ord. No. 1680 , § 1, 8-31-17) 
Sec. 5.994. - Powers and duties. 
    The city centre advisory board shall manage programs initiated by the city to promote economic activity and to provide for the maintenance, security, and operation of the city centre. The board shall have those powers prescribed by Act No. 146 of the Public Acts of 1992. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 5.995. - Financing. 
    The costs, in whole or in part, of projects in the city centre initiated by the city pursuant to Act No. 146 of the Public Acts of 1992 may be financed by the city by one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  Grants and gifts to the city. 
(2)  City funds. 
(3)  The issuance of general obligation bonds of the city. 
(4)  The issuance of revenue bonds by the city under the Revenue Bond Act of 1933, being Act No. 94 of the Public Acts of 1933, as amended, or under any other applicable revenue bond act. The issuance of bonds shall be limited to the part or parts of the city centre that are public improvements. 
(5)  The levying of special assessments against land or interests in land or both. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 5.996. - Budget. 
    The board shall operate on a fiscal year which coincides with the city's fiscal year. The board shall provide the city administrator with a copy of its proposed budget on or before the first day of February. Any requests for appropriation of city funds or the levy of a special assessment shall be specifically identified in the proposed budget. Funds appropriated to the board by the city to fund any portion of the board's activities shall be held by the city and may be disbursed to the board from time to time from payments of expenses incurred by the board. The board shall submit an annual accounting of its financial records to the city within one hundred twenty (120) days of the close of each fiscal year. The city controller or his or her designee shall have the right at any time to examine the financial records of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-24-92) 
Title VI - FOOD AND HEALTH (RESERVED) 
Title VII - BUSINESS AND TRADES[1] 
Footnotes:
