Cross reference- Police regulations, tit. IX. 

CHAPTER 70. - LICENSES 

Sec. 7.1. - Licenses required. 
    No person shall engage, or be engaged, in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege for which any license is required by any provision of this Code without first obtaining a license from the city in the manner provided for in this chapter. Any person duly licensed on the effective date of this Code shall be deemed licensed under this Code for the balance of the current license year. 
Sec. 7.2. - Multiple businesses. 
    The granting of a license or permit to any person operating, conducting or carrying on any trade, profession, business or privilege which contains within itself, or is composed of, trades, professions, businesses or privileges which are required by this Code to be licensed, shall not relieve the person to whom such license or permit is granted from the necessity of securing individual licenses or permits from the city if such license or permit is required by this Code. 
Sec. 7.3. - State licensed businesses. 
    The fact that a license or permit has been granted to any person by the state to engage in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege shall not exempt such person from the necessity of securing a license or permit from the city if such license or permit is required by this Code. 
Sec. 7.4. - License application. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, every person required to obtain a license from the city to engage in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege shall make application for such license to the city clerk upon forms provided by the city clerk and shall state under oath or affirmation such facts as may be required for, or applicable to, the granting of such license. 
Sec. 7.5. - License year. 
    Except as otherwise provided as to certain licenses, the license year shall begin January 1 of each year and shall terminate at midnight on December 31 of that year. Original licenses shall be issued for the balance of the license year at the full license fee. License applications for license renewals shall be accepted and licenses issued for a period of fifteen (15) days prior to the annual expiration date. In all cases where the provisions of this Code permit the issuance of licenses for periods of less than one (1) year, the effective date of such licenses shall commence with the date of issuance thereof. 
Sec. 7.6. - Conditions for issuance. 
    No license or permit required by this Code shall be issued to any person who is required to have a license or permit from the state until such person shall submit evidence of such state license or permit and proof that all fees appertaining thereto have been paid. No license shall be granted to any applicant therefore until such applicant has complied with all of the provisions of this Code applicable to the trade, profession, business or privilege for which application for license is made. Applicants for any license are subject to inquiries regarding such applicant's recording of prior criminal convictions; all inquiries shall be conducted pursuant to section 1.500 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 9-25-89) 
Sec. 7.7. - Where certification required. 
    No license shall be granted where the certification of any officer of the city is required prior to the issuance thereof until such certification is made. 
Sec. 7.8. - Health officer's certificate. 
    In all cases where the certification of the health officer is required prior to the issuance of any license by the city clerk, such certification shall be based upon an actual inspection and a finding that the person making application and the premises in which he proposes to conduct or is conducting the trade, profession, business or privilege comply with all the sanitary requirements of the state and of the city. 
Sec. 7.9. - Fire chief's certificate. 
    In all cases where the certification of the fire chief is required prior to the issuance of any license by the city clerk, such certification shall be based upon an actual inspection and a finding that the premises in which the person making application for such license proposes to conduct or is conducting the trade, profession, business or privilege comply with all the fire regulations of the state and of the city. 
Sec. 7.10. - Police chief's certificate. 
    In all cases where the certification of the chief of police is required prior to the issuance of any license by the city clerk, such certification shall be based upon a finding that the person making application for such license is of good moral character. 
Sec. 7.11. - Building and safety engineering director's certificate. 
    In all cases where the carrying on of the trade, profession, business or privilege involves the use of any structure or land, a license therefor shall not be issued until the director of building and safety engineering shall certify that the proposed use is not prohibited by Title V of this Code, or other zoning regulations of the city, nor until a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
Sec. 7.12. - Bonds. 
    Where the provisions of this Code require that the applicant for any license or permit furnish a bond, such bond shall be furnished in an amount deemed adequate by the proper city officer, or, where the amount thereof is specified in the schedule of fees and bonds set out in Chapter 71 or elsewhere in this Code, in the amount so required; the form of such bond shall be acceptable to the city attorney. In lieu of a bond, an applicant for a license or permit may furnish one (1) or more policies of insurance in the same amounts and providing the same protection as called for in any such bond; any such policies of insurance shall be approved as to substance by the city official issuing the license or permit and as to form by the city attorney. 
Sec. 7.13. - Later renewals. 
    All fees for the renewal of any license which are not paid at the time they shall be due shall be paid as late fees with an additional twenty-five (25) percent of the license fee required for such licenses under the provisions of Chapter 71 for the first fifteen (15) days that such license fee remains unpaid and thereafter the license fee shall be that stipulated for such licenses under Chapter 71, plus fifty (50) percent of such fee. 
Sec. 7.14. - Right to issuance. 
    If the application for any license is approved by the proper officers of the city, as provided in this Code, such license shall be granted and shall serve as a receipt for payment of the fee prescribed for such license. 
Sec. 7.15. - Fees, when paid. 
    The fee required by this Code for any license or permit shall be paid at the office of the city treasurer upon or before the granting of such license or permit. 
Sec. 7.16. - Exempt persons. 
    No license fee shall be required from any person exempt from such fee by state or federal law. Such persons shall comply with all other provisions of this chapter. The city clerk shall, in all such cases, issue to such persons licenses which are clearly marked as to the exemption and the reasons therefor. 
Sec. 7.17. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Any license issued by the city may be suspended by the city clerk or city administrator for cause, and any permit issued by the city may be suspended or revoked by the issuing authority for cause. The licensee shall have the right to a hearing before the city council on any such action of the city clerk or city administrator, provided a written request therefor is filed with the city clerk within five (5) days after receipt of the notice of such suspension. The city council may confirm such suspension or revoke or reinstate any such license. The action taken by the city council shall be final. The same procedure shall apply where a license application is denied. Upon suspension or revocation of any license or permit, the fee therefor shall not be refunded. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, any licensee whose license has been revoked shall not be eligible to apply for a new license for the trade, profession, business or privilege for a period of one (1) year after such revocation. 
Sec. 7.18. - "Cause" defined. 
    The term "cause" as used in this chapter shall include the doing or omitting of any act, or permitting any condition to exist in connection with any trade, profession, business or privilege for which a license or permit is granted under the provisions of this Code, or upon any premises or facilities used in connection therewith, which act, omission or condition is: 
(1)  Contrary to the health, morals, safety or welfare of the public; 
(2)  Unlawful, irregular or fraudulent in nature; 
(3)  Unauthorized or beyond the scope of the license or permit granted; 
(4)  Forbidden by the provisions of this Code or any duly established rule or regulation of the city applicable to the trade, profession, business or privilege for which the license or permit has been granted. 
Sec. 7.19. - License renewal. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, an application for renewal of a license shall be considered in the same manner as an original application. 
Sec. 7.20. - Exhibition of license. 
    No licensee shall fail to carry any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter upon his person at all times when engaged in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege for which the license was granted; except that where such trade, profession, business or privilege is operated, conducted or carried on at a fixed place or establishment, the license shall be exhibited at all times in some conspicuous place in his place of business. Every licensee shall produce his license for examination when applying for a renewal thereof or when requested to do so by any city police officer or by any person representing the issuing authority. 
Sec. 7.21. - Exhibition on vehicle and machine. 
    No licensee shall fail to display conspicuously on each vehicle or mechanical device or machine required to be licensed by this Code such tags or stickers as are furnished by the city clerk. 
Sec. 7.22. - Displaying invalid license. 
    No person shall display any expired license or any license for which a duplicate has been issued. 
Sec. 7.23. - Transferability; misuse. 
    No license or permit issued under the provisions of this Code shall be transferable unless specifically authorized by the provisions of this Code. No licensee or permittee shall, unless specifically authorized by the provisions of this Code, transfer or attempt to transfer his license or permit to another nor shall he make any improper use of the same. 
Sec. 7.24. - Misuse automatic revocation. 
    In addition to the general penalty provision for violation thereof, any attempt by a licensee or permittee to transfer his license or permit to another, unless specifically authorized by the provisions of this Code, or to use the same improperly shall be void and result in the automatic revocation of such license or permit. 
CHAPTER 71. - FEES AND BONDS REQUIRED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1511, enacted April 25, 2005, deleted ch. 71, which consisted of §§ 7.31-7.40, and enacted new provisions to be designated as ch. 71, § 7.31. Former ch. 71 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the original codification of the Code. 

Sec. 7.31. - Schedule established. 
    The fee required to be paid and the amount of any bond required to be posted, or insurance required to be carried, to obtain any license to engage in the operation, conduct, or carrying on of any trade, profession, business, or privilege for which a license is required by the provisions of this Code shall be established from time to time by a resolution of the city council. No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he first pays to the city clerk the fee and posts a bond or evidence of insurance coverage in the amount required for the type of license desired. 
(Ord. No. 1511, 4-25-05) 
CHAPTER 72. - VENDORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1517, enacted May 16, 2005, deleted ch. 72, §§ 7.51-7.61, which pertained to peddlers and which derived from the original codification of the Code. Said ordinance enacted new provisions to be designated as ch. 72, §§ 7.51-7.64. 
Cross reference- Uninvited peddlers going upon private property declared a nuisance, § 9.3. 

Sec. 7.51. - Definitions. 
(a)  Chief means the Southfield Chief of Police. 
(b)  Clerk means the Southfield City Clerk. 
(c)  Person shall mean any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, association, organization, society, or any other business entity. 
(d)  Vendor shall mean any person, other than a solicitor as defined in section 7.602 of this Code, who sells or offers to sell goods, merchandise, or services of any kind for immediate or future delivery or performance while: 
(1)  Traveling by foot, wagon, cart, motor vehicle, or other conveyance from place to place. 
(2)  Using or occupying any lot, right-of-way, building, tent, or other structure for a period of less than six (6) consecutive months. 
(3)  Outside of a building or structure using a stationary cart, stand, wagon, concession trailer, motor vehicle, or any other method of display. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.52. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter do not apply to: 
(a)  Veterans exempt from local license requirements pursuant to state law. 
(b)  Salespersons calling upon business establishments. 
(c)  Vendors located on city property pursuant to a written lease agreement. 
(d)  Vendors required to be licensed under a more specific licensing provision contained in Title VII of this Code. 
(e)  A vendor conducting a temporary, outside sale accessory to its principal business conducted within a structure. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.53. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of vending without first obtaining a license from the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.54. - Duration. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on December 31 of the year issued, unless an earlier expiration date is noted on the license. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.55. - Transfer prohibited. 
    No license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be transferred to or used by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.56. - Application for license. 
    Applicants for a license under this chapter shall file a verified application on a form provided by the clerk containing the following information: 
(a)  Proof of age, address, and identification of the applicant, to be provided through the applicant's drivers license or other legally recognized form of identification. If the applicant's vending activities will be conducted through a business which has a different name, identify the name and form of the business; 
(b)  A brief description of the vending activity to be conducted, including the methods to be used and a description of the types of goods and services to be sold; 
(c)  The dates, hours, and locations for which the right to engage in vending is sought; 
(d)  Proof that the applicant has permission to use the property where the vending activity will be conducted; 
(e)  If employed, the name, address, and telephone number of the employer; or, if acting as an agent, the name, address, and telephone number of the principal who is being represented; 
(f)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor (other than traffic violations); the nature of the offense or violation; the date when and place where such offense occurred; the court where such offense was adjudicated; and the penalty or punishment imposed; 
(g)  A statement as to whether or not a governmental license issued to the applicant has ever been suspended or revoked; and if so, the reason for the revocation or suspension; 
(h)  Two (2) photographs of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing such application, which photograph shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches and shall show the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(i)  A description and license number of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the vending activity; 
(j)  A copy of a valid, current, Michigan sales tax license, or, if exempt, a copy of a current exemption certificate, if required for the goods or merchandise sold; and 
(k)  Such other information as the clerk shall determine to be appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.57. - Health department approval prior to selling food. 
    Any person licensed under this chapter shall obtain approval from the Oakland County Health Department prior to selling any food or beverages. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.58. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    Prior to the issuance of a license, a certificate of occupancy, if required, shall be obtained from the building department. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.59. - Single event. 
    If a person sponsors or organizes a single event with a duration of five (5) days or less at which ten (10) or more vendors are present, such person shall have the option of applying for a single license on behalf of all participating vendors. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.60. - Administrative fee. 
    An administrative processing fee shall be paid for a vendor's license in accordance with the fee schedule established by city council resolution pursuant to section 7.31 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.61. - Application review and license issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application, the clerk shall forward it to the chief for review of the application, as deemed necessary, to ensure the protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  After such review, the chief shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and return the application to the clerk who shall, if the application is approved, deliver the license to the applicant. 
(c)  The license shall show the name, address, and photograph of the licensee; the kind of goods or services to be sold or delivered; the date of issuance; and the length of time that the license shall be in effect. The license shall also show the license number and identifying description of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the business for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.62. - Denial of license. 
(a)  Upon the chief's review of the application, the chief may refuse to approve an application for a license under this chapter for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The location and time of vending would endanger the safety and/or welfare of the licensee or his or her customers. 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application. 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving a sex offense; trafficking in controlled substances; any violent acts against persons or property, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation. 
(4)  The applicant has been denied a license or had a license revoked by the city within the two (2) years immediately preceding the date of application unless the applicant can and does show to the satisfaction of the chief that the reasons for such earlier denial or revocation no longer exist. 
(5)  Any other reason that relates to the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(b)  The chief's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application and the applicant shall be notified by the clerk that his or her application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.63. - License display. 
    Every person required to obtain a license under the provisions of this chapter shall at all times conspicuously display the license while conducting vending activities in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 7.64. - License revocation. 
    Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended in accordance with section 7.17 of this Code, for any of the following reasons: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for a license; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made by the licensee in the course of conducting vending activities; 
(c)  Conducting vending activities contrary to the provisions contained in the license or any provision of the City Code; 
(d)  Conviction for any crime identified in section 7.62; or 
(e)  Conducting vending activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance; constitute a breach of the peace; or endanger the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 1517, § 1, 5-16-05) 
CHAPTER 74. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[5] 
(RESERVED) 
Footnotes:

CHAPTER 75. - SECONDHAND DEALERS, JUNK DEALERS AND PAWNBROKERS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Used automobile dealers, § 7.121 et seq.; auctioneers, § 7.181 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7.111. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of dealer in secondhand goods or junk dealer without first obtaining a license therefor. Such license shall be issued by the mayor in accordance with the provisions of Act 350 of the Public Acts of 1917, as amended (C.L. '48, Sec. 445.401 et seq.). The fee for such licenses shall be as specified in Chapter 71 of this Code. A licensee under Chapter 76 of this Code shall not be required to obtain an additional license under this chapter. 
Sec. 7.112. - Statutes applicable. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter the provisions of Act 350 of the Public Acts of 1917, as amended, and the provisions of Act 231 of the Public Acts of 1945, as amended (C.L. '48, Sec. 445.471 et seq.) shall apply to licensees under this chapter. Any licensee who shall violate any provision of such statutes shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and punished as prescribed in Chapter 1 hereof. 
Secs. 7.113-7.115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 7.116. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of pawnbroker without first obtaining a license therefor. In accordance with the provisions of Act 273 of Public Acts of 1917, State of Michigan, (C.L. '48, Sec. 446.201 et seq.) pawnbroker licenses shall be issued by the mayor. The fee for such license shall be as prescribed in Chapter 71 of this Code. Any licensee violating any of the provisions of Public Act 273 of 1917, as amended, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and punished as prescribed in Chapter 1 hereof. The provisions of Act 231 of the Public Acts of 1945, State of Michigan, as amended (C.L. '48, Sec. 445.471 et seq.) shall also apply to pawnbrokers licensed under the provisions of this chapter and any licensee violating any provision of the same shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and punished as provided in Chapter 1 hereof. 
CHAPTER 76. - USED AUTOMOBILE DEALERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Secondhand dealers, § 7.111 et seq. 

Sec. 7.121. - Definitions. 
(1)  In the interpretation of this chapter "dealer in secondhand vehicles" shall mean any person who engages in the business of purchasing, selling, trading or exchanging any kind of secondhand motor vehicle and parts and accessories, or who keeps a store, place or lot for the purposes of carrying on and/or maintaining the business of purchasing, selling, trading or exchanging any kind of secondhand motor vehicle and parts and accessories, is hereby declared to be a dealer in secondhand motor vehicles. 
(2)  In the interpretation of this chapter "place of business or lot" shall mean a single platted lot or any group of contiguous lots having one (1) or more common entrances or exits shall be construed as one (1) used automobile lot or place of business. 
(3)  "License." A license for dealing in secondhand motor vehicles shall include the right to deal in used trailers, tractors, motorcycles, automobile parts and accessories, but not the operation of a separate storage yard where used trailers, secondhand motor vehicles, automobile parts and accessories, and other similar items are kept or stored. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 7.1. 
Sec. 7.122. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of dealer in secondhand vehicles without first having obtained a license therefor. 
Sec. 7.123. - Application. 
    Application for a license to carry on and/or maintain a business of dealer in secondhand vehicles shall be made by the owner or his authorized agent upon blanks to be furnished by the city clerk and shall contain, in addition to that information required by Chapter 70, the following: 
(1)  The length of time engaged in the business as a used automobile seller, buyer, trader or dealer prior to the application, stating where and inclusive dates engaged in such business; 
(2)  The date and number of the license from the Michigan Secretary of State authorizing the conduct of a business in secondhand vehicles; 
(3)  Whether or not the applicant or his authorized agents has ever been convicted of a violation of any federal, state or city law governing the purchase, selling, trading or exchanging of vehicles, whether new or secondhand and the nature of such violation. 
Sec. 7.124. - Approval required. 
    No license shall be issued under this chapter except upon certification of the police chief, the fire chief and the director of the department of building and safety engineering. 
Sec. 7.125. - Licenses; regulations governing. 
(1)  Except as provided in this chapter, the provisions of Chapter 70 shall govern all phases of the issuance of licenses to dealers in secondhand vehicles. The license fee and bond to be posted shall be as specified in Chapter 71. 
(2)  Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable. Where the licensee is a corporation, the transfer of the controlling interest in the corporation shall be deemed a transfer of the business which will require the issuing of a new license therefor. 
Sec. 7.126. - Limited to one place. 
    A single license under this chapter shall be valid for only one (1) store, place or lot for the purpose of carrying on and/or maintaining the business of dealer in secondhand motor vehicles and parts and accessories thereto of any description in any place other than his licensed place of business. 
Sec. 7.127. - Open or uncovered sales lots. 
    In the case of open or uncovered sales lots where the business of dealing in secondhand motor vehicles shall be carried on and/or maintained, the following regulations, in addition to those required by Chapter 45, Zoning, shall apply: 
(1)  The surface of the lot used by any dealer in the conduct of his business shall be constructed of a dustless and durable Portland cement concrete, or asphaltic concrete, complying with the Michigan State Highway Specification #412 and maintained in a usable condition. 
(2)  Adequate ingress and egress to the lot shall be provided by means of clearly limited and defined drives for vehicles and such drives shall be surfaced as provided in subparagraph (1) of this section. Such places of ingress and egress shall be situated so as not to constitute a menace to the flow of vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic on the abutting streets. 
(3)  All places of business and sites upon which businesses have been licensed to operate under the provisions of this chapter shall be kept neat and orderly at all times, and in cases of open or uncovered sales lots, automobiles and vehicles shall not be parked closer than four (4) feet from the lot line. 
(4)  There shall be installed wheel chocks of concrete or similar permanent material so as to prevent any vehicle from projecting beyond the limits as set forth above. 
(5)  Open lots shall be lighted by "moon glow" or equivalent-type lights on supports to extend not more than fourteen (14) feet above the surface of paved parking area. 
(6)  The lot shall be drained by providing subsurface drainage for the entire lot by installing catch basins and/or storm lines to the nearest outlet to eliminate surface water. 
(7)  Whenever any such open lot shall abut either the rear or side lot lines of any residentially zoned property, there shall be erected a coped wall of solid masonry construction, not less than six (6) feet in height adjacent to such lot lines. 
(8)  Each such lot shall have thereon a suitable permanent structure or building which provides not less than seven hundred and fifty (750) square feet of floor space at the first floor level, and such building shall be provided with running water and sanitary facilities as required by Chapter 98, Building Regulations. 
(9)  The zoning board of appeals may authorize, upon appeal, a variance from the strict application of the provisions of this section and each of the subsections thereof where the strict application of the provisions would result in practical difficulties to, or undue hardship upon the owner of property which is the subject of regulation under this chapter, provided such relief may be granted without substantial detriment to the public good and without substantially impairing the intent and purpose of this chapter. In granting a variance, the board of appeals may attach thereto such conditions regulating the location, character and other features of the proposed use as it may deem reasonable. In furtherance of the purpose of this chapter, in granting a variance the board of appeals shall state the grounds upon which it justifies the granting of a variance. 
Sec. 7.128. - Records to be kept. 
    Every dealer licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall keep in his place of business named in such license so issued to him a record of the purchase and sale of all automobiles, motor vehicles and accessories thereof and all other records as are required by the Michigan Secretary of State. Such records shall be kept up to date and legibly written in the English language, and all such records and stock in trade shall be open to the inspection of the police department of the city or any member thereof without the formality of legal process. 
Sec. 7.129. - Insurance required. 
    Each dealer in secondhand vehicles shall carry public liability and property damage insurance upon each automobile or motor vehicle operated by him upon the streets and alleys of the city in the amounts prescribed in Chapter 71. 
Sec. 7.130. - Posting a copy of chapter. 
    Every person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall post in a conspicuous location in his place of business a copy of this chapter, such copies to be furnished by the city clerk. 
CHAPTER 77. - CITY CHAUFFEURS AND PUBLIC CARRIERS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7.141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Administrator or city administrator means the city administrator of the city or his designated agents. 
(2)  Chief means the chief of police of the city or his designated agents. 
(3)  City means the City of Southfield. 
(4)  City chauffeur means every person who is employed for the principal purpose of operating a motor vehicle while in use as a public or common carrier of persons or property in a manner such that the transference or conveyance of such persons or property originates within the city. 
(5)  Driver means every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a public carrier vehicle. 
(6)  For hire means for remuneration or reward of any kind, paid or promised, either directly or indirectly. 
(7)  Licensee means any person, as in this section, who is licensed as a city chauffeur according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(8)  Motor vehicle for hire means a motor vehicle not equipped with a taximeter, designed to carry persons for public hire at an hourly rate. A motor vehicle for hire shall be deemed a public carrier for purposes of this chapter. 
(9)  Owner means (a) any person, firm, association or corporation renting a motor vehicle or having the exclusive use thereof, under a lease or otherwise, for a period of greater than thirty (30) days; (b) a person who holds the legal title of a vehicle or if a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for the conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of purchase upon performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with an immediate right of possession vested in the conditional vendee or lessee or if a mortgagor of a vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be deemed the owner. 
(10)  Person. The word "person" includes firms, joint adventures, partnerships, corporations, clubs and all associations or organizations or natural persons, either incorporated or unincorporated, howsoever operating or named, and whether acting by themselves or by a servant, agent or fiduciary, and includes all legal representatives, heirs, successors and assigns thereof. 
(11)  Public carrier means any person who holds himself out to the public as being engaged in the business of a common carrier as at the common law, either directly or through any device or arrangement, including those who operate over fixed routes or between fixed termini, in the transportation by motor vehicle from place to place upon or over the streets or highways of this city, or for the purpose of transporting any package, or baggage or any person who may choose to employ him for such purpose, in a manner such that the transference or conveyance of such package, baggage or person originates within the city. 
(12)  Public place as used in this chapter shall mean any street, alley, park, public building, cemetery, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public and any other place, which is open to the public view, or to which the public has access. 
(13)  Registrant means any person, as defined in this section, to whom a public carrier vehicle is registered according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(14)  Registration means registration certificate or certificates and registration plates issued under the laws of this city pertaining to the registration of public carriers. 
(15)  Revocation means that the city chauffeur's license or public carrier registration and privilege to operate a public carrier on the public highways is terminated and shall not be renewed or restored except that an application for a new license or registration may be presented and acted upon by the clerk after the expiration of at least one (1) year after the date of revocation. 
(16)  Street or highway means the entire width between boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(17)  Taxicab means a vehicle on which a taximeter is affixed. A taxicab shall be deemed a public carrier for purposes of this chapter. 
(18)  Taxicab business means soliciting or picking up passengers for hire within the city by the use of a taxicab. 
(19)  Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.142. - City chauffeur's license required. 
    No person shall drive, cause to be driven or permit to be driven any taxicab, or motor vehicle for hire, while in use as a public carrier, upon the streets, alleys or public ways in the city unless the driver thereof is licensed as a chauffeur by the city according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.143. - City chauffeur's license; application, contents. 
    Every application for a city chauffeur's license shall be made upon a form furnished by the clerk and shall contain such provisions not inconsistent with this chapter as the clerk may determine. At a minimum such application shall contain the following information regarding the applicant: full name, date of birth, physical description of the applicant, business address and telephone number, home address and telephone number, two recent photographs, state chauffeur's license number and date of expiration, social security number. Each application must be accompanied by a state chauffeur's license, a social security card, and a set of the fingerprints of the applicant prepared by the city police department. All applicants must be a United States citizen or eligible to work in the United States, pursuant to federal law and must submit appropriate documentation to substantiate such status. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.144. - City chauffeur's licenses; examination of applicants. 
    Every application shall be referred by the clerk to the chief of police, who, through his agents assigned by him, shall investigate and make a recommendation as to the acceptability of the applicant's qualifications. The chief of police shall establish rules and regulations for the examination of the applicant as to his physical, mental and ethical qualifications to operate such a motor vehicle in such a manner as not to jeopardize the health or safety of persons or property. The chief of police shall, within ten (10) days, examine the applicant and return such application to the clerk together with the result of such examination or determination and his recommendation in respect thereto. The recommendation of the chief of police with respect to any application shall in all cases be binding upon and followed by the clerk. The examination shall include, but not be limited to, a test of the applicant's: 
(1)  Ability to operate a public carrier; 
(2)  Knowledge of the geography of the city; 
(3)  Knowledge of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.145. - City chauffeur's license, issuance of same. 
    The clerk shall issue to every person licensed as a city chauffeur, a city chauffeur's license. Every license shall bear thereon the distinguishing number permanently assigned to the licensee and shall contain the name, date of birth, place of residence, business address, photograph, physical description of applicant on the public vehicle card, fingerprint and signature of the licensee for the purposes of identification. No license shall be issued until the fee shown in section 7.170 of this chapter has been paid to the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.146. - Alteration of license prohibited. 
    No person shall deface, remove or alter any city chauffeur's license, or any entry made thereon by the clerk. 
Sec. 7.147. - Display of city chauffeur's license in vehicle. 
    The licensee shall have such license in his immediate possession at all times when operating a public carrier pursuant to this chapter, and shall conspicuously display his license on the inside of the vehicle, with a light shining on it at night, so that it may be easily seen both in the day and nighttime by occupants of the vehicle. 
Sec. 7.148. - Complaints and records thereof. 
    The clerk shall keep a complete and public record of the issuance of each city chauffeur's license and public carrier registration issued pursuant to this chapter, together with a record of all complaints, suspensions and revocations. Any person being aggrieved by reason of the conduct or action of any licensee or registrant may present his complaint to any police officer. Such complaint shall be promptly investigated by the chief of police and his finding filed with the clerk. The license or registration of any person complained of may be revoked as provided in section 7.171. 
Sec. 7.149. - Expiration of city chauffeur's license; renewal thereof. 
    Each city chauffeur's license shall expire on December 31 of the license year. The clerk may renew a city chauffeur's license from year to year upon application to the clerk as provided for in section 7.143 and upon endorsement by the chief of police as provided for in section 7.144. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.150. - Compliance with laws, regulations and public carriers code. 
    Any person who is granted the privilege of operating a public carrier or to whom is registered a public carrier pursuant to this chapter shall comply with and abide by the provisions of this chapter, all traffic regulations now in effect or hereinafter enacted, the regulations set forth in the "Public Carriers Code" as provided in section 7.173 and all state and federal laws. Failure to so comply may result in revocation of the city chauffeur's license pursuant to section 7.171. 
Sec. 7.151. - Registration as a public carrier required. 
    No person shall drive, cause to be driven or permit to be driven any taxicab, or motor vehicle for hire, while in use as a public carrier, upon the streets, alleys or public ways in the city, unless such vehicle is registered as a public carrier according to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.152. - Application for registration as a public carrier; contents; fees. 
    Every owner or potential owner of a vehicle who desires that vehicle to be subject to registration in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall make application to the clerk for the registration thereof and issuance of a certificate of registration for each such vehicle accompanied by the required fees as established from time to time by a resolution of the council and upon the appropriate forms furnished by the clerk. 
    Applications shall be placed in an active file for a period of one (1) year from the date of application. If during the year, additional registration plates become available, approval of issuance of the registration plates shall be made by the city clerk and the police department, in accordance with the provisions of section 7.166, section 7.167-A or section 7.171. The successful applicant will be advised to supply the additional information indicated in the following portions of this chapter, pay the additional necessary fees outlined in section 7.170, and to meet all other requirements of this chapter, all within ninety (90) days of the date of notification. Failure to do so will indicate that the applicant has no intention of obtaining the approved registration plate and the registration plate will be considered to be available for issuance to other applicants by the city. 
    Every original application for a certificate of registration shall bear the signature of the owner or potential owner written with pen and ink and such signature shall be acknowledged by the applicant before a person authorized to administer oaths. The original application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, bona fide residence, telephone number and mail address of the owner or potential owner; 
(2)  The name, bona fide residence, telephone number and mail address of the business firm under which the registered vehicle will be operated; 
(3)  The color scheme, emblem identification or characteristic markings intended to be used by the owner of the vehicle to identify the vehicle as part of the business firm outlined in subsection (2) above; 
(4)  The hours of the day and the days of the week during which the registered vehicle will be in service; 
(5)  All items relating to the vehicle listed in the following paragraph if the vehicle is owned at the time of application. 
    Successful applicants will be required to supply the following information, after notification of approval, in addition to the foregoing information: 
(1)  A description of the vehicle including the make or name, style of the body, year, model, manufacturer's serial number or in the absence of such serial number, a number assigned by the secretary of state; 
(2)  Current State of Michigan vehicle registration number; 
(3)  Name and local address of the insurance carrier or bonding company retained pursuant to section 7.153. 
    Application for renewal of existing registration plates shall take the same form as original application and contain the same information outlined above. If a renewal application is not filed on an existing registration and all other elements of this chapter complied with, prior to the yearly expiration date, as outlined in section 7.158 of this chapter, this failure will indicate that the applicant has no intention of renewing the registration plate and continuing the carrier in public service and the plate will be considered to be abandoned and revoked and shall be available for issuance pursuant to this section to other applicants by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1366, § 1, 5-9-94; Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.153. - Insurance requirements. 
    Before issuance of registration as a public carrier, the applicant shall file a certificate, signed by a duly authorized officer of a company authorized to write insurance in the state, to the effect that a policy of insurance has been issued and is in full force and effect to the applicant, and that the premium has been paid as required thereon, together with a true copy of the policy contract or certificate of insurance. In cases where the insurance premium is payable monthly, proper certificates or evidence of payment of premiums shall be delivered to the clerk no later than the first of each month. 
    The minimum amount of the insurance coverage as to any one public carrier shall be in accordance with the laws of the state regarding "no fault" insurance and be in accord with the following minimums: 
(1)  On account of injury to, or death of, any person in any one (1) accident, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); 
(2)  On account of any one (1) accident resulting in injury to, or death of, more than one (1) person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00); 
(3)  On account of damage to property in any one (1) accident, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). 
    Such policy of insurance shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereunder the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon, and that until the policy is revoked, as herein provided, the insurance company will not be relieved from liability on account of nonpayment of premium, failure to renew license at the end of the year, or any act or omission of the named assured. 
    Any insurance company whose policy has been so filed pursuant to this section shall file a notice in the office of the clerk of its intention to terminate and cancel such policy and give ten (10) days' notice thereof to the named applicant, whereupon ten (10) days after such filing such applicant or owner shall cease to operate or cause to be operated within the city such public carrier, and the registration issued therefor shall be automatically revoked and liability on such policy shall cease and terminate; provided, that the liability of the insurance company thereon for any act or omission of the applicant or owner occurring prior to the effective date of cancellation shall not be thereby discharged or impaired. The clerk may from time to time, at his discretion, require financial reports to be furnished to him by any or all insurance companies writing policies of insurance filed in compliance with this chapter. If the financial condition of any such companies shall at any time be found unsatisfactory or insecure with reference to the extent of the risks assumed or policies outstanding, the clerk, after ten (10) days' notice to the owner of any vehicle covered or affected by insurance policies issued by any such companies in pursuance of the provisions of this chapter, shall revoke the public carrier registration of such owners, unless a satisfactory policy, or bond, shall have been previously filed in the manner and form required by this section. 
    In lieu of insurance required the applicant may furnish a surety company bond or bonds, in a form to be approved by the city attorney in penal sums of not less for each public carrier than the amounts specified for insurance, and binding the principal and surety to the same conditions as are required in the insurance policies as set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 1209, § 1, 8-11-86) 
Sec. 7.154. - Inspection of vehicles and equipment. 
    No registration as a public carrier shall be issued by the clerk until such vehicle has been inspected by the Southfield Police Department and the chief of police or his authorized agent has certified in writing to the clerk, on forms provided by the clerk, that such vehicle is mechanically and structurally sound and is fit for public use. No inspection shall be made until the applicant has paid to the clerk the fee therefor as specified in section 7.170. Any city police officer may stop any vehicle registered under this chapter and inspect such vehicle, or may order the operator of such vehicle to convey the vehicle to a designated garage or inspection station in order to conduct such inspection. The public carrier registration of any vehicle found by any police officer to be in violation of the ordinances of this city or laws of the state shall be confiscated and delivered to the clerk, who shall conduct a hearing pursuant to section 7.171(5) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1366, § 1, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 7.155. - Communication system required. 
    No public carrier shall be issued registration by the clerk unless the provisions of this chapter relating to mobile radio communication equipment have been satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.156. - Listed telephone number required. 
    No public carrier shall be issued registration by the clerk unless the provisions of this chapter relating to listed telephone numbers and established place of business have been satisfied. 
Sec. 7.157. - Public convenience and necessity required. 
    No public carrier registration shall be granted by the clerk until public convenience and necessity require the operation of such additional public carrier as hereinafter provided. 
Sec. 7.158. - Expiration of public carrier registrations. 
    All registrations issued under this chapter, unless sooner revoked or suspended by the clerk as provided in this chapter, shall expire on the thirtieth day of June, of the year following the registration year. 
(Ord. No. 1133, § 1, 12-15-83; Ord. No. 1366, § 1, 5-9-94) 
Sec. 7.159. - Vehicle color, emblem and identification. 
    No public carrier shall be issued registration by the clerk unless the vehicle to be registered has first been identified with characteristics sufficient to distinguish the particular vehicle from vehicles operated by other persons, firms or corporations engaged in the same or similar business. All vehicles operated by the same person shall be identified by the same color, emblem and other characteristics. 
Sec. 7.160. - Issuance of public carrier vehicle registration. 
    The clerk, upon registering a public carrier upon receipt of the required fees, shall issue a registration certificate which shall be delivered to the owner and shall contain upon the face thereof the date issued, the date of expiration, name and address of the owner, the registration number assigned to the vehicle, and such description of the vehicle as deemed necessary by the clerk, and the name and address and telephone number of the business operating such vehicle. 
Sec. 7.161. - Registration to be signed, carried and displayed. 
    Every owner upon receipt of a public carrier registration certificate shall write his signature thereon with pen and ink in the space provided. Every registration certificate shall be prominently displayed in the vehicle to which it refers in a position such that it may be seen and read from both inside and outside the vehicle. The person driving or in control of such vehicle shall display the registration to any customer, potential customer or Southfield police officer upon request. 
Sec. 7.162. - Registration plates; issuance, number. 
    The clerk, upon registering a public carrier, shall issue to the owner one (1) registration plate. The owner shall display such registration plate on the vehicle so registered as provided in this chapter. The registration plate shall display upon it the registration number assigned to the vehicle for which it is issued, also the name of this city, which may be abbreviated, and the year number for which it is issued, and/or the date of expiration thereof which may be shown by a tab or sticker furnished by the clerk. The registration plates and the required letters and numerals thereon, except the year number for which issued, shall be of sufficient size to be plainly readable from a distance of fifty (50) feet during the day light. In any year during which registration plates are furnished, the clerk shall furnish for each annual registration a year plate, tab or sticker designating the year of registration. 
Sec. 7.163. - Use of other registration plates prohibited. 
    No person shall operate a public carrier upon the streets or highways of this city under registration plates other than those issued for it pursuant to this chapter. 
Sec. 7.164. - Registration plates; attachment, display. 
    The public carrier registration plate issued for a vehicle shall be attached at the rear of the vehicle for which it is issued, securely fastened in a horizontal position so as to prevent the plate from swinging and at a height of not less than twelve (12) inches from the ground measuring from the bottom of such plate, in a place and position to be clearly visible and shall be maintained free from foreign materials and in a condition to be clearly legible. 
Sec. 7.165. - Preparation, numbering and color of plates. 
    Public carrier registration plates shall be prepared by the clerk, who shall cause an individual numeral, letter or combination numeral and letter to be affixed or imprinted upon each set of plates, and cause a color or combination of colors to be affixed thereto, as he shall deem necessary in his discretion. 
Sec. 7.166. - Transfer of registration. 
(1)  If the owner of a currently registered vehicle acquires another vehicle with or without transferring his title or interest in such original vehicle the owner may have such registration transferred to the new vehicle, upon application to the clerk as provided for in section 7.152 and payment of the required fees as provided in section 7.170. 
(2)  If the owner of a currently registered vehicle is considering selling such vehicle, without any intention of continuing such vehicle in public service, the existing registration plate may be transferred to the new owner upon request made in writing by the original owner. Such application for transfer must be approved by both the city clerk and the chief of police after a review thereof and a payment of the fee as required under section 7.170. Provided, however, that unless such vehicle has undergone an issuance or renewal inspection within ninety (90) days from the date of application of such transfer, such transfer shall not be approved until the vehicle is presented for inspection and the necessary inspection fees paid. No transfer applications will be processed April 1 through June 30. 
(3)  Any ownership change of an existing vehicle registered pursuant to this chapter, whether by operation of law or otherwise, which is intended to effectively place the operation of the vehicle under the control of a nonregistered owner prior to official approval of a potential transfer as outlined above, shall automatically require revocation of the registration plate. 
(4)  Application for transfer of registration by a new owner, or potential new owner, shall be made in the same manner as original application for registration. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.167. - Taxicabs; rules for operation. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following subsections shall apply to the operation of taxicabs and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to operate, or permit to be operated, a taxicab in the city in violation thereof: 
(1)  Taximeter. Each taxicab shall be equipped with a taximeter, installed so that the amount of fare determined thereby is plainly visible to the customer, and shall be illuminated by a suitable light after sundown. The case of each taximeter shall be sealed and the cover and gear thereof intact. The chief of police shall inspect, test and approve each taximeter before the clerk may issue a registration for the vehicle. 
(2)  Establishment of taxicab stands. The chief of police may recommend to the traffic engineer that taxicab parking and waiting stands be established at specific locations on public streets, and on property open to the public with the permission of the owner of such property, provided such owner requests and consents to the establishment of such stands: 
(a)  The traffic engineer is hereby authorized to establish taxicab stands in the locations recommended by the chief of police, provided the traffic engineer determines such locations to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and as provided in this section. 
(b)  The traffic engineer shall exercise his authority to establish and regulate taxicab stands by issuance of traffic control orders which shall specify the rules and regulations adopted or established by him, including the maximum number of taxicabs which may park at any one (1) stand at once. Such traffic control orders shall become effective upon approval of the council, filing with the clerk, and the posting of appropriate signs. 
(c)  No taxicab stand shall be established within five (5) feet of the entrance to any building or within five (5) feet of any crosswalk. The first five-foot limitation shall be determined by measuring five (5) feet on either side of a point at the curb, opposite the door or entrance of building. The chief of police may recommend stands for night use only. No taxicab shall be permitted to park anywhere within a one-mile circle except at stands therein established as provided in this section. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the parking or standing of taxicabs outside of the one-mile circle, where parking is permitted, other than on authorized taxicab stands when such taxicab is not being used in the soliciting of business. 
(d)  The department of public works shall cause to be attached to a post or stanchion a metal sign which shall state the number of taxicabs, which shall be permitted to stand at such particular stand. 
(e)  No taxicab shall be permitted to park or stand at such a designated area except as provided in the traffic control order. 
(f)  No vehicle except a registered taxicab shall park or stand at any stand established under this section. 
(3)  Fares. The maximum rates of fare which shall be charged and collected for service by taxicabs shall be determined by resolution of the council and shall be reviewed and adjusted from time to time. There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the inside of each taxicab a card on which shall be printed, in plain, legible type, the maximum rates of fare as provided by resolution of council, and shall indicate reference to this chapter. No fare shall be charged for the hire of any taxicabs which exceeds the maximum fares established by resolution of the council. 
(4)  Cruising. No taxicab, while awaiting employment by passengers, shall stand on any public street or place other than upon a taxicab stand, nor shall any taxicab driver seek employment by repeatedly and persistently driving his taxicab to and fro in a short space before or by otherwise interfering with the proper and orderly access to or egress from any theater, hall, hotel, public resort, bus station or other place of public gathering, or in any manner obstructing or impeding traffic; but any taxicab driver may solicit employment by driving through any public street and at such speed as not to interfere with or impede traffic and may pass and repass until he shall have gone a distance of at least one-half (1/2) mile beyond such place. 
(5)  Soliciting passengers. No person shall solicit passengers for a public taxicab upon the streets of the city except the driver of the taxicab when sitting upon the driver's seat or inside his vehicle at all times when such vehicle is standing upon any taxicab stand or when actually engaged in carrying passengers, except that every taxicab driver shall be permitted to leave his taxicab to assist passengers into or out of such taxicab. Any taxicab driver may leave his taxicab or a taxicab stand to take care of the calls of nature and during such absence, his taxicab shall be parked at the rear of such taxicab stand and no such absence shall be longer than thirty (30) minutes. 
(6)  Intoxicating beverages. No taxicab or motor vehicle for hire driver or operator shall drink, nor shall the employer of any driver, permit the driver to drink any intoxicating beverage while on duty, or immediately prior thereto. 
(7)  Carrying additional passengers. No taxicab shall carry any other person than the person first employing a taxicab without the consent of the first passenger. 
(8)  Passengers in front seat. No persons shall be permitted to ride on the front seat with the driver of a taxicab. 
(9)  Change of fare. No change of fare shall be made until the taximeter shall be adjusted to the rate changed and the meter approved by the chief of police. No fare in excess of, or less than, the indication shown by the taximeter shall be charged. 
(10)  Loitering near taxicabs. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver or owner of a taxicab standing upon the public streets, to loiter at, within or near such taxicab. 
(11)  Operation of taxicab stands. Only registered taxicabs in such numbers as are set forth on the taxicab stand signs provided for in subsection (2) of this section may remain at taxicab stands while waiting for employment, and they must be parked in single file. The taxicab standing at the head of such parked line shall not be permitted to refuse to carry an orderly person who offers to hire such taxicab and agrees to pay the proper rate of fare, provided that the foregoing provisions shall not be construed to prevent any person from selecting any taxicab he may desire on the stand, whether it be at the head of the line or not. As taxicabs leave the parked line, those in the rear shall move up, and any taxicab seeking space on such stand shall not approach the same except from the rear thereof and shall move up as closely as possible to the last taxicab on the parked line. 
(12)  Right to collect fare in advance. It shall be the right of any city chauffeur to demand payment of the legal fare in advance and may refuse employment until so prepaid, but no city chauffeur of a taxicab shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person or persons upon request anywhere in the city unless previously engaged or unable to do so. 
(13)  Communication systems required. No registered taxicab shall be operated in the city unless the owner of such vehicle has established a place of business and has a two-way communication system. All registered taxicabs operating in the city shall at all times be able to maintain two-way communications with their business office. 
(14)  Listed telephone number required. Each taxicab business office shall have installed thereat a telephone service having a telephone number listed in the area telephone book under the name of the taxicab business. If such business telephone number is advertised in any publication, such advertisement shall also show the hours and days during which the business will be conducted or will be closed. 
(15)  Property lost or left in vehicle. Every city chauffeur of a taxicab, immediately after the termination of hiring or employment, shall carefully search such taxicab for any property lost or left therein, and any such property, unless sooner claimed or delivered to the owner, shall be taken to the city police station and deposited with the officer in charge within twenty-four (24) hours after the finding thereof. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply in case a profit corporation or a nonprofit corporation composed of members engaged in the taxicab business shall have a regularly established lost and found department, in which case such property must be kept subject to the call of the owner for at least thirty (30) days, at the end of which time it shall be disposed of in accordance with the law. 
(16)  Pictorial communications. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any communication by display or exhibition, on or within any taxicab, of any drawing, photograph, image, statuary, sign, symbol, characterization, portrayal or representation of any form which: 
(a)  Exposes or tends to expose any individual or any ethnic, racial or religious group to hatred, contempt, ridicule or obliquity; or 
(b)  Suggests or is likely to suggest any lewd or lascivious act; or 
(c)  Represents or tends to represent any private part of the human body which is customarily not exposed in a public place; or 
(d)  Condones, encourages or invites violation of any federal, state or local law. 
(17)  Trip sheet records. Every city chauffeur of a taxicab shall maintain a trip sheet record containing the date, cab number, name of driver, time of start and completion of work period, and the taximeter and odometer readings at the start and completion of the work period. The record shall also list in chronological order the address or street intersection at which a fare was picked up or discharged. The location at which the fare was picked up shall be recorded before beginning the trip or as soon as traffic conditions permit and the address at which the fare was discharged shall be recorded as soon as the passenger leaves the vehicle or as soon as traffic conditions permit. Taxicab owners shall be responsible for filing and maintaining trip sheet records for a period of ninety (90) days. 
(18)  Soliciting bus passengers. No city chauffeur of any taxicab shall ask or request persons to take passage in such vehicle when waiting to take passage on a bus at an established loading point for such bus. 
(19)  Advertising. It shall be lawful for any person to permit commercial advertising matter to be affixed to or installed on or within any taxicab, not inconsistent with subsection (16) above, provided such commercial advertising meets all regulations which shall be established by the chief of police and published in the public carrier's code. The chief of police shall establish regulations for the exhibition and display of such commercial advertising which are not in conflict with this chapter and which shall limit and regulate the location, size and physical composition of such commercial advertising material so as to prevent driver visibility restrictions, unnecessary distractions to other vehicle operators and physical dangers to pedestrians, passengers and other vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 1, 5-27-80; Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.167-A. - Public convenience and necessity. 
(1)  Number of taxicab registration plates. Factors affecting public convenience and necessity, which affect the number of taxicab registration plates to be in service at any given time, may be reviewed by council periodically to determine the level of service being provided by existing taxicabs and the need for issuance of additional taxicab registration plates, if any, or the removal of existing plates from service. The number of taxicab registration plates shall be established after a public hearing by council resolution in accordance with the following guidelines: 
(a)  All current taxicab registration plate holders and persons who have a current application on file for a certificate of registration in accord with section 7.152 shall be given notification by first class mail by the city clerk, addressed according to the clerk's registration records, mailed not less than seven (7) days prior to the hearing, of the date, time and place of the public hearing. In addition, notice of the date, time and place of hearing shall be published in the official newspaper of the city at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date. 
(b)  In determining the need for additional taxicab registration plates, the council shall consider as a minimum the following factors: 
1.  The number of existing taxicabs operating in the city; 
2.  The manner in which existing taxicabs are operated; 
3.  The needs and demands of the public; 
4.  Traffic conditions; and 
5.  Such other relevant facts as the council may deem advisable. 
(2)  Procedure for selecting registration plate recipients. If council determines that additional taxicab registration plates should be issued, it shall direct the staff transportation committee to investigate all persons who at the time of the public hearing have applications for registration plates on file under section 7.152 of this chapter. The staff transportation committee shall consist of such administrative employees as may be appointed by council. Upon concluding such investigation, the committee shall file a report and recommendation to the council as to which of the applicants should receive the additional plates. The council, after considering the report and recommendation of the committee, shall by resolution grant such additional registration plates to such applicants as in its discretion deems advisable. In determining the applicants to be issued the additional registration plates the council may, among others, consider the following factors: 
(a)  Financial capability; 
(b)  Criminal record; 
(c)  Driving record; 
(d)  Proposed taxicab service levels; 
(e)  Past taxicab experience; and 
(f)  Other such factors as the committee may deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 1, 5-27-80; Ord. No. 1209, § 1, 8-11-86; Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.168. - Motor vehicles for hire. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following subsections shall apply to the operation of motor vehicles for hire and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to operate, or permit to be operated a motor vehicle for hire in the city in violation thereof: 
(1)  Public convenience and necessity. The city council is hereby vested with power and authority, upon the filing of an application for registration as a motor vehicle for hire, to ascertain and determine, after considering all existing public carrier facilities and the demand for or need of additional service, whether there exists a public necessity for such service and whether public convenience will be promoted by granting the application and permitting the operating of such vehicle as a public vehicle. The application shall be granted by resolution of the city council to that effect. Such resolution, after certification to the clerk, shall fulfill the requirements of section 7.157 of this chapter. An application shall be granted or denied within ninety (90) days of the filing of the application for registration with the clerk. The council may, if it deems advisable, conduct a public hearing and take the testimony of interested persons and experts in areas related hereto. 
(2)  Fares. The rates of fare which shall be charged and collected for service by motor vehicles for hire shall be determined by resolution of the city council. There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the inside of each motor vehicle for hire, a card on which shall be printed, in plain, legible type, the rates of fare as provided by resolution of the city council, and shall indicate reference to this chapter. No fare shall be charged for the hire of any motor vehicle other than in accordance with the fees established by resolution of the city council. 
(3)  Soliciting bus passengers. No city chauffeur of any motor vehicle for hire shall ask or request persons to take passage in such vehicle when waiting to take passage on a bus at an established loading point for such bus. 
(4)  Inapplicability of sections to motor vehicle for hire. When a motor vehicle for hire has been approved for registration as outlined in subsection (1) above, section 7.155 and section 7.159 shall not apply to such motor vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION, FEES, REVOCATION OF CHAUFFEUR'S LICENSE AND PUBLIC CARRIER REGISTRATION, PUBLIC CARRIER'S CODE 

Sec. 7.169. - Administration, forms. 
    All licenses and registration issued pursuant to this chapter shall be administered by the clerk. The clerk shall collect fees as hereinafter provided, which shall be applied to the cost of administering this chapter. The clerk shall formulate and prepare all necessary forms for implementation of this chapter and shall maintain an index of all chauffeurs and registrants by name and by license number. 
Sec. 7.170. - Fees. 
    The applicant or registrant shall pay fees to the city clerk, the amount of such fees being determined from time to time by resolution of the council, in accordance with the following table of services: 
(1)  Vehicle, inspection of condition by police department, each vehicle: 
Section 7.154; 
(2)  Taximeter, inspection of: 
Subsection 7.167(1); 
(3)  Public carrier registration and registration plate: 
Section 7.152 
Each original issuance of a plate; 
Each renewal of a plate; 
(4)  City chauffeur's license: 
Section 7.145, each new license; 
Section 7.149, each renewal. 
(Ord. No. 1488, § 1, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 7.171. - Revocation of city chauffeur license or public carrier registration. 
    Any license or registration issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked as hereinafter provided. Any license or registration so revoked shall not be renewed or restored, except that an application for a new license or registration may be presented and acted upon by the clerk after the expiration of at least one (1) year after the date of revocation. 
(1)  A city chauffeur's license is automatically and simultaneously revoked whenever the licensee's state chauffeur's license is revoked, suspended or restricted by the secretary of state, or by a court of competent jurisdiction; or whenever the licensee's state chauffeur's license has expired; or when the licensee's certified driving record, as maintained by the secretary of state, indicates more than twelve (12) points in moving violations have been entered thereon in any two-year period. No notice is necessary on the part of the city to effectuate revocation of the city chauffeur's license under any of the aforesaid circumstances. 
(2)  A city chauffeur's license and any public carrier registration may be revoked upon a finding that the licensee or registrant has violated any of the provisions of this chapter, or has violated any administrative rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto. Such finding shall be according to subparagraph (5) of this section. 
(3)  A licensee or registrant to whom notification of revocation of registration or city chauffeur's license has been mailed, pursuant to this chapter shall forthwith surrender such license or registration to the clerk. The clerk shall then mutilate or cancel the license or registration. Any police officer shall confiscate a registration or license which has been revoked and which has not been surrendered to the clerk. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any revoked license or registration. 
(4)  When a city chauffeur has been found in violation of the provisions of this chapter, pursuant to proceedings held under subparagraph (5) below on two (2) occasions within a twelve-month period, the registration certificate and the registration plates of the vehicle involved in the latest violation shall be revoked regardless of the identity or relationship of the owner of such vehicle with the prior violation. 
(5)  Whenever the chief of police has reason to believe that a licensee or registrant has violated the provisions of this chapter or other city ordinance, or state or federal law, he may notify the clerk. The clerk shall then send a notice to the licensee or registrant by first class mail, postage prepaid thereon, addressed to the licensee or registrant at the address indicated on the license or registration, informing the licensee or registrant of the violation charged and of the time, place and date of a hearing before the city clerk and chief of police for the purpose of determining whether or not there has been any such violation. The licensee or registrant may appear at the hearing, in which event he shall be heard. The hearing shall be conducted within sixty (60) days of the alleged violation. Witnesses to the violation shall be heard. Papers and documents may be received and examined by the clerk and the chief of police in their discretion. If the city clerk and the chief of police each find beyond a reasonable doubt, as a matter of fact, that the licensee or registrant has violated any provision of this chapter, or has violated any ordinance of the city, or has violated any state or federal law, such license or registration shall forthwith be revoked, and the clerk shall file a copy of the findings of fact and reasons for revocation in the licensee's or registrant's permanent file. A verbatim stenographic or other permanent record of such hearing shall be made and filed with the clerk, and retained for a period of not less than two (2) years. 
(6)  Notice of revocation pursuant to subparagraph (5) above shall be served personally upon the license or registrant, or the clerk shall mail such notice to the licensee or registrant by first class mail, postage prepaid thereon, addressed to the licensee or registrant at the address indicated on the license or registration. Such notice shall contain the findings of fact made by the city clerk and the chief of police and the reasons for the revocation. The clerk shall file in the permanent file an affidavit of the service of such notice. 
(7)  A public carrier registration may also be revoked upon a finding being made pursuant to the provisions of this section that the vehicle is being unreasonably held from public service or that the number of passenger runs made by vehicle within a ninety-day period is less than twenty-five (25) percent of the average run established by the registered taxicabs during the normal course of operations as established by the passenger runs recorded under the provisions of subsection (18) of section 7.167. 
Sec. 7.172. - Interstate and interurban commerce. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit any public carrier from coming into the city to discharge persons or goods accepted for transportation outside the city, and this chapter shall apply only insofar as it may be consistent with the Constitution or the laws of the United States and the State of Michigan.
