Sec. 7.173. - Public Carrier's Code. 
(1)  The city administrator shall formulate, prepare, publish, and file with the clerk, a regulation which shall be entitled "Public Carrier's Code." Such code shall specify: 
(a)  The personal conduct required of all persons licensed as city chauffeurs, necessary to protect the safety and welfare of those persons serviced by the licensee; 
(b)  The type and manner of dress or uniform necessary to identify a licensee as a Southfield city chauffeur; 
(c)  The standards of personal cleanliness and hygiene necessary to protect the health of those persons serviced by the licensee; 
(d)  Other regulations deemed necessary by the city administrator in order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(2)  The public carrier's code shall state that "Violations of the provisions of this code, at the unanimous decision of the clerk and the chief of police, may result in revocation of the violator's city chauffeur's license or public carrier registration, or both license and registration, pursuant to section 7.171 of this chapter." A copy of the code shall be presented to each applicant for a city chauffeur's license or public carrier registration. 
CHAPTER 78. - AUCTIONEERS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Secondhand dealers, § 7.111 et seq. 

Sec. 7.181. - License. 
    No person shall engage in the trade or business of auctioneer without first obtaining a license therefor and payment of fees as provided in Chapter 71. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police. 
Sec. 7.182. - Prohibited activity. 
    No auctioneer shall knowingly misrepresent the quality of any goods sold by him. No auctioneer shall accept any goods from any minor for sale at auction. 
Sec. 7.183. - Auction accounts. 
    Every auctioneer shall keep a full and accurate account of all goods sold by him, indicating the prior owner, the price at which sold, and to whom sold. Such account shall be open for inspection by any police officer of the city at any reasonable time. No auctioneer shall fail to make such account accessible to any police officer upon demand. 
Sec. 7.184. - Prohibitions. 
    The following acts, omissions and practices in connection with auction sales are prohibited: 
(1)  The use of deceit, fraud or misrepresentation in the sale of any property; 
(2)  The substitution of another article for that bid upon by the prospective purchaser; 
(3)  The use of false bidders, cappers or puffers; 
(4)  The use of bells, buzzers, ballyhoo, loudspeakers or any variety of mechanical or excessive vocal sound to attract attention; 
(5)  The use of any false or misleading advertising matter; 
(6)  A sale by a person other than the licensed auctioneer named in the application; 
(7)  Failure to exhibit an auctioneer's license to a police officer on demand at the place where the auction is being conducted. 
Cross reference- Noise control, § 9.10 et seq. 
Sec. 7.185. - Exempt sales. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to sheriffs, constables or other public or court officers or to any person acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling property in the course of their official duties or to any person selling property under and by virtue of any statute, state or federal. 
CHAPTER 79. - LIQUOR LICENSES AND RELATED PERMITS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1239, § 1, enacted December 21, 1987, deleted ch. 79, §§ 7.190-7.193, as derived from Ord. No. 1093, § 1, enacted April 26, 1982, and added new provisions in lieu thereof, as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquor, § 9.151 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - DENIAL OF RENEWAL OF LIQUOR LICENSES AND RELATED PERMITS; OR REVOCATION HEARING PROCEDURES; PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES ON LICENSED PREMISES; PENALTIES 

Sec. 7.190. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in this chapter: 
(1)  Licensee shall mean and include all persons, including their agents, servants and employees, holding a license to sell beer and wine or spirits for consumption on the premises issued by the state liquor control commission. 
(2)  Licensed premises shall mean the location at which a licensee is authorized to sell beer and wine or spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(3)  License means a license issued by the state liquor control commission to sell beer and wine or spirits for consumption on the premises. 
(4)  Related permit means any permit issued by the state liquor control commission to a licensee for entertainment or other activities at the licensed premises which legally require such a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1239, § 1, 12-21-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 7.1. 
Sec. 7.191. - Enforcement officer. 
    The primary responsibility for ensuring compliance by any licensee under this chapter shall be reposed upon the chief of police who shall have the continuing responsibility to ensure that all licensees operating licensed premises within the city are in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1239, § 1, 12-21-87) 
Sec. 7.192. - Prohibited activities. 
    No licensee within the boundaries of the city shall knowingly engage in, allow or permit any of the following activities to be conducted by any person upon any licensed premises owned, occupied or controlled by such licensee: 
(1)  Dancing, monologues, dialogues, motion pictures, still slides, closed circuit television, contests or other performances for public viewing on the licensed premises, unless the licensee has been granted an entertainment or dance-entertainment permit by the state liquor control commission which is in legal effect at the time of the occurrence of such activity; 
(a)  This subsection shall not prohibit orchestra playing, piano playing, the playing of other types of musical instruments, singing or publicly broadcast television transmissions from federally licensed stations. 
(2)  The exposing to public view by any person of the less than completely and opaquely covered pubic region, genitals, anus, buttock, female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola, and human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered; 
(3)  The showing of films, television, slides, pictures or any form of reproductions, electronic or otherwise, which depict scenes wherein any person exposes to public view the less than completely and opaquely covered pubic region, genitals, anus, buttock, female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola, and human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered; 
(a)  This subsection shall not prohibit any publicly broadcast television transmission from federally licensed stations. 
(4)  The performance, or simulated performance, by any person of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, fellatio or cunnilingus; or the fondling or other erotic touching by any person of the genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast; 
(5)  The showing of films, television, slides, pictures or any form of reproduction, electronic or otherwise, which depict scenes wherein any person performs, or simulates performance of, sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, fellatio, cunnilingus or fondles or erotically touches the genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast; 
(a)  This subsection shall not prohibit any publicly broadcast television transmission from federally licensed stations. 
(6)  The distribution, dissemination or circulation of obscene literature, pictures or advertising materials; 
(7)  The knowing permission of the licensed premises to be frequented by, or to become a place of repeated congregation of, prostitutes or of persons seeking to exchange sexual favors and services for valuable consideration in a commercial manner; 
(8)  The knowing allowance of the licensed premises to be used by any persons for the engaging in any illegal conduct in violation of any law of the state or ordinance of the city in legal effect at the time of such allowance, including, but not limited to, the use, possession or delivery of controlled substances, illegal gambling, and the possession of illegal gambling devices. 
(Ord. No. 1239, § 1, 12-21-87) 
Sec. 7.193. - Criteria for revocation or denial of renewal of licenses and related permits. 
    The city council may recommend revocation or denial of renewal of a license or related permit to the state liquor control commission upon a determination by it that based upon a preponderance of the evidence presented at a public hearing, conducted in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 7.194, any of the following exist: 
(1)  A licensee has engaged in any of the prohibited activities specified in section 7.192; 
(2)  Personal property taxes, real property taxes or any other obligations due and payable to the city relating to the licensed premises have not been paid; 
(3)  Maintenance of a nuisance upon or in connection with the licensed premises, including, but not limited to, any of the following: 
(a)  Existing violations of building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, zoning, health, fire or other applicable regulatory codes; 
(b)  A pattern of patron conduct in the neighborhood of the licensed premises which is in violation of the law and/or disturbs the peace, order and tranquility of the neighborhood; 
(c)  Failure to maintain the grounds and exterior of the licensed premises, including litter, debris or refuse blowing or being deposited upon adjoining properties; 
(d)  Entertainment on the licensed premises without a permit and/or entertainment which disturbs the peace, order and tranquility in the neighborhood of the licensed premises; 
(e)  Any advertising, promotion or activity in connection with the licensed premises which by its nature causes, creates or contributes to disorder, disobedience to rules, ordinances or laws, or contributes to the disruption of normal activity of those in the neighborhood of the licensed premises; 
(4)  Failure by the licensee to permit the inspection of the licensed premises by the city's agents or employees in connection with the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1239, § 1, 12-21-87) 
Sec. 7.194. - Procedure for recommendation of denial of renewal or revocation of licenses and related permits. 
(1)  If the chief of police determines that any licensee has committed a violation of this chapter, the chief of police shall prepare a report in writing specifying (i) the specific factual details of such violation(s); (ii) the particular chapter subsection(s) violated; and (iii) any other information or recommendation relevant to a proper determination by the city council as to the nature of such violation(s) and the appropriate action to be taken by council. 
(2)  The chief of police shall file the original report prepared under subsection (1) with the city council, and serve a copy of such report upon the licensee or its authorized agent or employee personally or by registered mail. 
(3)  Within twenty (20) days from the date such report has been filed with the city council, the city clerk shall set a date for a hearing before council on the alleged violation(s) and for a determination by council as to whether or not council shall request and recommend to the state liquor control commission that the commission revoke or deny the renewal of any license or permit held in conjunction with such license. Notice of this hearing shall be served by the city clerk upon the licensee or its authorized agent or employee personally or by registered mail not less than seven (7) days before the scheduled hearing date, and such notice shall advise the licensee of its right to be represented by legal council at the hearing before city council. 
(4)  At all such hearings, the licensee shall have the legal right to defend against the allegations made by way of confronting any adverse witnesses, by being allowed to present live witnesses in its own behalf, by being allowed to present other evidence in its own behalf, and by being allowed to present arguments, personally or through legal counsel, in its own behalf. 
(5)  The city council shall prepare a written statement of its findings, which may be formal or informal in nature, within a reasonable time, not to exceed sixty (60) days, after the conclusion of all such hearings. Such statement of findings may be embodied in a resolution as described in subsection (6), below, if council determines that objection to renewal or request for revocation of a license or related permit is appropriate. 
(6)  If the city council determines after due notice and proper hearing upon a preponderance of the evidence presented that a violation of this chapter has been committed by a licensee, or that, even if no violation has been demonstrated, nevertheless the interests of public health, safety or welfare warrant that council object to renewal or request revocation of any existing license or related permit issued to such licensee, the council may adopt a resolution recommending to the state liquor control commission that it deny renewal or revoke any such license or related permit to such licensee. 
(7)  Within ten (10) days of the council's final approval of any such resolution, the city clerk shall forward a copy thereof to the state liquor control commission pursuant to MCL 436.17, as amended, as council's official notice of objection to renewal or request for revocation of any existing license or related permit. 
(Ord. No. 1239, § 1, 12-21-87) 
Sec. 7.195. - Licenses. 
    Any and all new liquor licenses and transfers of a license for consumption of intoxicating liquor on premises of any kind shall require the approval of the city council including, but not limited to: ownership of the license, stock in a corporation that owns a license, interest in a license through any entity, or location of the licensed premises. Applications for a new license or transfer shall be in writing and filed with the city clerk. An application for a new license or transfer of a license for consumption of intoxicating liquor on the premises will be considered by the city council based upon the following standards: 
(1)  All personal property taxes, real property taxes, water bills, or any other obligations due and payable to the city relating to the applicant and/or the proposed licensed premises shall have been fully paid and satisfied; 
(2)  The police chief shall have certified that the person(s) making application for the license is/are of good moral character; 
(3)  The location proposed and methods of operation must not detrimentally or unreasonably impact nearby property owners, businesses and/or residents; 
(4)  The location proposed must have adequate parking; 
(5)  All applicable health and safety codes and ordinances, including zoning, must have been met, and the premises shall have been certified by the director of building and safety engineering as in compliance with title V, zoning, of this Code, and a certificate of occupancy has been issued for the premises; 
(6)  The applicant has sufficient, measurable management experience in the alcohol/liquor business, including crowd control; 
(7)  The applicant has sufficient financial ability to build and/or operate the proposed facility on which the proposed liquor license is to be located; and 
(8)  Any other factor(s) determined by the city council that may affect the health, safety, and welfare or the best interests of the city and its residents. 
(Ord. No. 1629 , § 1, 9-7-14) 
Sec. 7.196. - Application and procedure. 
(a)  Each applicant for a new license or transfer of a license for consumption of intoxicating liquor on the premises must make an application to the city clerk on forms provided by the city. This application is in addition to any application required by the State of Michigan Liquor Control Commission (the "liquor control commission"). The application shall include at least the following information: 
1.  Name and address of applicant. If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each partner shall be provided, and a copy of any partnership agreement attached. If the applicant is a privately held corporation, the names and addresses of all corporate officers, members of the board of directors, and stockholders shall be provided, and a copy of the articles of incorporation attached. If the applicant is a publicly held corporation, the names and addresses of all corporate officers, members of the board of directors, and stockholders who own ten percent (10) percent or more of the corporate stock shall be provided. If the applicant is a limited liability company, the names and addresses of all members, managers and assignees of membership interests shall be provided, and a copy of the articles of incorporation attached; 
2.  Type of license desired; 
3.  The address and legal description of the property where the license it to be located; 
4.  If the facility is to be located in a proposed building for which site plan approval has not yet been obtained, or in an existing building that is to be remodeled, the applicant shall submit a conceptual plan showing the relationship of the building to the surrounding properties and uses, proposed building elevations, floor plans, seating arrangements, and site dimensions, including parking areas; 
5.  A written statement as to the applicant's character, experience, and financial ability to meet the obligations and business undertakings for which the license is to be issued; and 
6.  A written statement demonstrating that the location proposed and the methods of operation will not detrimentally and unreasonably impact nearby property owners, businesses, and residents. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application for a new license or transfer of a license, the city clerk will refer it to the police chief, building official, fire chief, planning director, city treasurer, and public works director, who shall each cause a thorough investigation of the application, the proposed licensed premises and the applicant. 
(c)  The applicant will be required to pay the new license or transfer of a license application fee in such amount as established by city council resolution from time to time. 
(d)  The applicant will be required to appear before the city council, making a presentation concerning the plans for the operation of the proposed licensed premises, and answer any questions pertaining to such plans. 
(e)  If the city council is satisfied that the issuance of a new license or transfer of a license for consumption of intoxicating liquor on the premises will constitute an asset to the community and meets the standards of this chapter, it will adopt a resolution approving the new license or transfer of the license, subject to any conditions stated in the resolution. The applicant must comply with all representations made to the city council as part of this request for a new license or transfer of a license. If, following issuance of the license or transfer of the license it is determined that the project was not completed as required by the plans and specifications presented to the city council, the city council may request that the liquor license issued by the liquor control commission be revoked pursuant to the administrative rules of the liquor control commission, or may object to the renewal of the license for the following year, in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 7.194 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1629 , § 1, 9-7-14) 
Sec. 7.197. - Duty of continuing compliance. 
    Successful applicants for a new license or transfer of a license for consumption of intoxicating liquor on the premises shall continue to comply with all city and state codes and the standards set forth in this chapter, including the plan of operation submitted to the city and any representations made to the city council in obtaining the requested license or transfer of a license. Licensee's failure to comply with all codes or variation from the plan of operation may result in a request by the city council to the liquor control commission to revoke the liquor license of the licensee, or the city council may object to the renewal of the license for the following year. 
(Ord. No. 1629 , § 1, 9-7-14) 
CHAPTER 80. - PUBLIC DANCES AND DANCE HALLS 

Sec. 7.221. - Definitions. 
    In the interpretation of this chapter the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Public dance shall mean any dance to which admission may be had by payment of a fee, or by purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket or token obtained for money or any valuable thing, or in which a charge is made for caring for clothing or other property or where a dance is held in conjunction with or as entertainment to any place where food or beverages, either alcoholic or nonalcoholic, are sold, or any other dance to which the public generally may gain admission with or without payment of a fee. 
(2)  Public dance hall shall mean any hall, room or place in which a public dance is given or public ball shall be held. 
(3)  Operator shall be any operator, proprietor, lessee, manager or employee of any public dance hall. 
(4)  Municipal dance shall be any dance or ball which is sponsored by the board of education, department of parks and recreation or schools of the city and conducted in a building owned or leased by the city. 
(5)  Teenage dance shall be any dance or ball where admission is granted to minors thirteen (13) to sixteen (16) years of age inclusive. 
Sec. 7.222. - Licenses required. 
(1)  No person as defined herein shall conduct or sponsor any public dance or hall for hire without first being duly licensed as required in this chapter; provided, however, that the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to municipal dances, dances or balls conducted by a religious or fraternal organization. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to private parties and receptions or to taverns or cocktail lounges, and other facilities licensed under the laws of the state. 
(2)  No operator, as defined herein, shall allow or permit the use of any public dance hall unless a license for such use shall have been obtained from the city clerk. 
Sec. 7.223. - Neighbor's consent. 
    No license to operate a public dance hall under this chapter shall be issued until the applicant for such license has filed a petition signed by at least fifty-one (51) percent of the persons living or doing business within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of any proposed location or any part thereof approving the issuance of such license. There shall be attached to such petition an affidavit signed by the party circulating such petition, which affidavit shall be in the following form: 
State of Michigan )  ss. County of Oakland )  
    The undersigned, first being duly sworn, deposes and says that the signatures upon the foregoing petition were obtained by him (or her); that the signatures are the signatures of the persons purporting to sign the same; and that he (or she) verily believes that the signers of such petition are persons living or doing business within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of the proposed new location of the establishment to be licensed. 
_____
    Subscribed and sworn to before me this _____ day of ________, A.D., 19___. 
Notary public, 
Oakland County, Michigan 
My commission expires _____ . 
No license shall be granted until the city clerk shall have referred the petition to the police department and he shall have secured from the police department a certificate certifying that an investigation has been made by the police department of such petition and that such petition contains the signatures of fifty-one (51) percent of persons living or doing business within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of the proposed new location. 
Sec. 7.224. - Application. 
    Every person or operator as defined herein desiring to obtain a license as required by this chapter shall file a written application at least two (2) weeks prior to the date on which license is desired on forms approved by the city clerk for the city, together with the license fee as provided in this chapter. The application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of each person, co-partnership, firm, corporation, society, club, association or organization conducting the public dance hall, public dance or public ball; 
(2)  The location of the public dance hall or the place where dance or ball is to be conducted; 
(3)  The name to be used by the applicant; 
(4)  Any other information required by the clerk of the city or the police department to aid in determining the moral character of the applicant. 
All applicants must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and shall not have been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude. 
Sec. 7.225. - Inspection. 
    Before any public dance hall license or any license for any dance shall be issued, the city clerk shall request an inspection of the place to be licensed or where the dance is to be held. Upon full compliance of all pertinent rules or regulations of the department of building and safety engineering, the department of health, the fire department and the police department relating to the safety, health, convenience, comfort and morals of the public and upon the completion of the inspection by the city clerk and/or other departments involved, the city clerk may issue a license for the place to be used as a public dance hall or for a public dance or ball. 
Sec. 7.226. - Regulations. 
    Each licensee shall: 
(1)  At all times open each and every portion of the licensed premises for inspection by the police department and/or other city departments for the purpose of enforcing any provisions of this Code relating to the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(2)  At all times display the license granted under this chapter in a conspicuous place near the entrance to the licensed establishment. 
(3)  Provide proper ventilation and sufficient toilet and lavatory conveniences as required by the city plumbing regulations and by the board of health for the city. 
(4)  At all times provide adequate lighting in every part of the licensed premises. 
(5)  Provide sufficient fire exits free from all rubbish and inflammable material as required by the regulations of the state fire marshal and/or this Code. 
(6)  Provide private guard service which service shall be a licensed and bonded service registered within the state. At least one (1) uniformed guard shall be employed for every seventy-five (75) persons attending. The chief of police may at any time require additional protection which shall be provided. 
Cross reference- Plumbing regulations, § 8.451 et seq.; disorderly conduct, § 9.122; fire prevention regulations, § 9.181 et seq. 
Sec. 7.227. - Compliance with codes. 
    No license shall be issued for any place in which public dances are to be held unless the building code, fire code and other pertinent provisions of the City Code as far as can be determined, are being complied with. 
Cross reference- Building code, § 8.201 et seq.; fire prevention regulations, § 9.181 et seq. 
Sec. 7.228. - Conduct on premises. 
    No licensee, by himself, directly or indirectly, or by any servant, agent or employee shall: 
(1)  Permit any indecent, immoral or profane language, or indecent, immoral or disorderly conduct; 
(2)  Permit the licensed premises to become a resort for disorderly persons of any type; 
(3)  Permit immoral, vulgar, lewd, obscene, improper or freak dancing; 
(4)  Permit smoking in the area designated for dancing; 
(5)  Permit gambling or the use, possession or presence of gambling paraphernalia on the premises; 
(6)  Permit overcrowding in the area designated for dancing (For the purposes of this chapter, "overcrowding" shall mean any number of persons in excess of the maximum number approved for the hall or building by the fire department and building department.); 
(7)  Permit intoxicated persons to dance or loiter on the premises; 
(8)  Employ a person who is under the age of eighteen (18) years; 
(9)  Permit any persons under the age of seventeen (17) years to be upon the premises unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian excepting where this chapter expressly allows persons between the ages of thirteen (13) and sixteen (16) inclusive to attend; 
(10)  Permit the possession or use of any alcoholic liquor on the premises, nor shall the licensed premises be accessible in any way with any place where alcoholic liquor is kept, sold, distributed or given away. This prohibition shall not apply while a state liquor control commission special beer and wine license is in effect at the licensed premises; 
(11)  Permit dancing on the licensed premises between the hours 2:00 a.m. and 7:30 a.m. without first having obtained a special permit from the city council. Applications for such special permit shall be filed with the city clerk at the time of filing the application; 
(12)  Permit noise or music to emerge from licensed premises which is disturbing to the surrounding area. 
Cross reference- Noise control, § 9.10 et seq.; alcoholic liquor regulations, § 9.151 et seq. 
Sec. 7.229. - License fees and transfers. 
    The fee to be paid for licenses issued under this chapter shall be as specified in chapter 71. Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter are not transferable. 
Sec. 7.230. - Teenage dances. 
    A licensee conducting or sponsoring a teenage dance shall, while the teenage dance license is in effect: 
(1)  Be permitted to admit minors thirteen (13) to sixteen (16) years of age inclusive; 
(2)  Not permit admission of the general public; 
(3)  Not permit dancing between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 7:30 a.m.; 
(4)  Provide proper and adequate adult supervision, such supervision to be in the minimum ration of one (1) adult to every twenty (20) teenagers unless additional supervision is found to be necessary by the chief of police upon investigation of the application for the license. The applicant shall be informed in writing as to the necessity of any additional adult supervisors within one (1) week of filing the application. 
Sec. 7.231. - Suspension and revocation. 
(1)  Any dance license may be suspended or revoked as provided in Chapter 70. 
(2)  Any public dance hall may be entered at any time by any member of the police department or other city officer or employee in the course of his employment. Any police officer of the city may cause any public dance to be discontinued and the hall to be vacated during the progress of a public dance for any reason for which a license may be suspended or revoked. 
CHAPTER 81. - RECREATION, AMUSEMENTS AND GAMES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Responsibilities of department of parks and recreation, § 1.138. 

ARTICLE I. - POOLROOMS AND BOWLING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 7.251. - Definitions. 
    The term "poolroom" as used in this chapter shall mean any place open to the public for playing pool or billiards and having two (2) or more pool or billiard tables. The term "bowling establishment" shall mean any place open to the public for bowling, and having two (2) or more lanes. 
Sec. 7.252. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating a poolroom or bowling establishment without first obtaining a license therefor. No license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police and director of building and safety engineering and unless a complete set of fingerprints of the applicant therefor are on file in the noncriminal identification file of the police department. No person shall be granted a license to operate a poolroom or bowling alley unless he is a citizen of the United States over the age of eighteen (18) years. Each license shall designate the number of pool or billiard tables or bowling lanes permitted under this chapter, and no licensee shall keep or maintain more tables or lanes than permitted by such license. 
Sec. 7.253. - Public institutions excepted. 
    This chapter shall not be applicable to bowling establishments or poolrooms operated and owned by public institutions. 
Secs. 7.254-7.260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - THEATERS, SHOWS AND EXHIBITIONS 

Sec. 7.261. - Show license. 
    No person shall conduct a circus, carnival or show, except in a theater licensed under the provisions of this chapter, without first obtaining a license therefor which shall be known as a show license. No license for a carnival shall be issued unless all rides have current state approval. 
Sec. 7.262. - Animal shows and exhibitions. 
    No person shall conduct any dog or pony show or menagerie, without first obtaining a license therefor. Such license shall be known as an animal show license. No person shall conduct any panorama, exhibition of statuary or painting, or any other exhibition not otherwise licensed under this chapter and for which an admission fee is charged, without first obtaining a license therefor to be known as an exhibition license. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any fair held under the direct management and supervision of any recognized agricultural association or society, nonprofit association or corporation, at which are exhibited agricultural or industrial products, principally. 
Sec. 7.263. - Theaters. 
    No person shall conduct a moving picture show, vaudeville, opera house, theater or other place for the giving of plays and other theatrical exhibitions where an admission fee is charged, without first obtaining a license therefor to be known as a theater license. The requirements of this section shall not be applicable to exhibitions or shows given for charity or for the benefit of schools or benevolent, educational or fraternal or religious societies. 
Sec. 7.264. - Certification required. 
    No show, animal show, exhibition or theater license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of police, fire chief and director of building and safety engineering or their respective representatives. 
Sec. 7.265. - Adult bookstores, adult motion picture theaters and cabarets. 
(1)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating any adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater or cabaret without being licensed therefor. 
(2)  Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this section shall, for the purpose of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them below, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Adult bookstore: An establishment wherein more than twenty (20) percent of its stock in trade is comprised of books, magazines and other periodicals having as dominant theme matter, depicting, describing or relating the specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section, or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the sale or display of such material. 
(b)  Adult motion picture theater: An enclosed building used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section for observation by patrons therein. 
(c)  Cabaret: Any place wherein food and any type of alcoholic beverage is sold or given away on the premises and the operator thereof holds a yearly license to sell such beverages by the glass and which features topless dancers, go-go dancers, exotic dancers, strippers, male or female impersonators or similar entertainers. 
(d)  Specified anatomical areas: For the purposes of this section shall be defined as follows: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: (i) human genitals, pubic region; (ii) buttock; and (iii) female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(e)  Specified sexual activities: For the purposes of the section shall be defined as follows: 
1.  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
2.  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; 
3.  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast. 
(3)  Application. Application for a license to engage in the business of operating an adult bookstore, an adult motion picture theater or a cabaret shall be made to the city clerk as provided in Chapter 70 of this Code. No such application for the original granting of such license shall be considered by the city clerk, unless such application is accompanied by a petition filed with such clerk and verified as to sufficiency. Such petition shall indicate a recommendation for approval of the granting of such license signed by fifty-one (51) percent or more of the persons owning real property within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of the location of the proposed business as measured from the lot line, and provided further: 
(a)  The petition shall contain an affidavit signed by the party circulating such petition attesting to the fact that the petition was circulated by him and that the circulator personally witnessed the signatures on the petition and that the same were affixed to the petition by the person whose name appeared thereon and that the circulator verily believes that the signers of such petition are persons owning real property which is situated within a radius of five hundred (500) feet of the location of the proposed business as measured from the lot line; 
(b)  The petition shall clearly state the name and address of the applicant, the address at which the intended business is to be operated, whether the intended business is an adult bookstore, and adult motion picture theater or a cabaret, and shall state that it is being circulated pursuant to section 7.263 of the City Code; 
(c)  Adjacent to every signature appearing on such petition shall be the full residence address of such signatory, together with a description of the property for which he qualifies as owner for purposes of the petition; 
(d)  "Persons owning real property" shall mean each and every person having an interest in fee simple in any such property, whether the interest be held by entireties, jointly, in common or otherwise, and each such person having such an interest shall be entitled to only one (1) signature on the petition regardless of the number of parcels in which he is interested; 
(e)  Names appearing as taxpayers in the records of the assessor shall be prima facie evidence of the owners of the fee interest for purposes of verification of the petition by the clerk. 
(4)  Certification required. No license shall be granted without the certification of the health officer, the fire chief, the police chief and the building and safety engineering director, as provided in Chapter 70 of this Code. Prior to certification the police chief shall cause an investigation to be made as to the character of the applicant and of the officers of the club, society or corporation and of the person who is to have general management of the business. If the applicant, or the officers of the club, society or corporation or the person who is to have general management of the business is found to have been convicted within the preceding two (2) years of the violation of any criminal statute of this state, except traffic offenses, or of any ordinance regulating, controlling or in any way relating to the construction, use or operation of any establishments included in this section which evidences a flagrant disregard for the safety or welfare of either the patrons, employees or person residing or doing business nearby, the police chief may refuse certification. Upon refusal of any certification required in this subsection the applicant shall have a right to a hearing and review before the city council, provided a written request is filed with the city clerk within five (5) days after notice of denial is received by the applicant. The city council may confirm such denial or order the license to be issued if it finds such certification should not have been refused under the provisions of this section. 
(5)  Term of license. The license year shall begin January 1 of each year and shall terminate at midnight on December 31 of that year. Original license shall be issued for the balance of the license year at the full license fee. License applications for license renewals shall be accepted and licenses issued for a period of fifteen (15) days prior to the annual expiration date. 
(6)  Bond and fee required. No license shall be granted to any person unless the person shall execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with two (2) sufficient sureties, conditioned for the faithful observance of this section, the Charter, this Code and other ordinances of the city and laws of this state. The bond shall not be accepted unless approved by the city attorney. 
(7)  Advertising. It shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agent or employee to knowingly permit any exhibition or advertising in connection with any establishment regulated under this section depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical activities to be displayed in any manner which is visible from any public street or highway. 
(8)  Conduct of licensees and patrons. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit any obscene or disorderly conduct or permit the use of any immoral, profane or indecent language, or to permit such business to become and be a place of resort of thieves, prostitutes or disorderly persons. 
(9)  Fee. The annual license fee for an adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater or cabaret shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) each. 
(10)  Suspension and revocation. A license may be suspended or revoked as provided in Chapter 70 of this Code. 
Secs. 7.266-7.270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SKATING RINKS 

Sec. 7.271. - Skating rinks. 
    No person shall conduct, maintain or operate any place open to the public for ice skating or roller skating without first obtaining a license to operate such skating rink in the manner provided in Chapter 70 of this Code. No such licenses shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police and the fire chief. 
Secs. 7.272-7.275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOXING, WRESTLING, JUDO AND KARATE 

Sec. 7.276. - Exhibitions and matches. 
    No person shall conduct any exhibition or match of boxing, wrestling, judo, karate or similar martial art, or any entertainment in which such exhibition or match constitutes a part, without first obtaining a license therefor in the manner provided for in Chapter 70 of this Code. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police and the fire chief. This section shall not be applicable to exhibitions or matches conducted as a regular part of the athletic program of any educational institution or other public agency. 
Secs. 7.277-7.280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT RIDES 

Sec. 7.281. - Mechanical amusement rides. 
(1)  The term "mechanical amusement ride" shall mean any device or assembly designed to carry three (3) or more persons which is propelled by motive power, to amuse, entertain or thrill the persons occupying seats thereon in a manner similar to devices commonly associated with a carnival, fair, amusement park or the like. This term shall not be deemed to include coin-operated cars, ships, mechanical horses, airplanes, spacecraft and similar devices designed, installed and used for the purpose of providing amusement for not more than two (2) small children or infants at a time by providing a rocking, vibrating or oscillating ride when limited to the confines of a stationary platform or pedestal. 
(2)  No person shall engage in the business of operating any mechanical amusement ride without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted until each such ride shall have been inspected by the department of building and safety engineering and approved. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of police. 
Secs. 7.282-7.285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND ARCADES 

Sec. 7.286. - Definitions. 
    Certain words and phrases as used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed in this section: 
(1)  Mechanical and electrical amusement devices. The term "mechanical and electrical amusement device" shall, for the purposes of this chapter, mean all mechanical devices or machines which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc or any charge therefor, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It shall include, but is not limited to, such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical or electrical machines, and all games, operations or transacting similar thereto under whatever name they may be indicated; it shall specifically include any machine which may, on the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc or any charge therefor, operate or be operated or used as a game, contest or amusement, and which consists solely of electronic play appearing on a video screen; it shall not include "vending machines" as defined in section 7.288(1) of this chapter nor to public utility machines such as telephones, newspaper vending machines and similar machines which provide a product or information or other tangible commodity and are not designed or operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement. 
(2)  Arcades. The term "arcade" shall, for the purposes of this chapter, mean any public place of amusement or public place of business located within a building and in which more than three (3) mechanical and electrical amusement devices are installed, whether intended as a principal use or accessory use. 
(3)  Owner. "Owner" means any person who owns, operates or conducts any place of establishment in which any mechanical and electrical amusement device may be operated; the term shall not apply to a person who owns or operates a mechanical and electrical amusement device solely for personal use within a residential dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 1085, § 1, 2-23-82) 
Sec. 7.287. - Licenses; rules and regulations. 
(1)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain, distribute for the purpose of operation, own, operate or possess with the intent to operate any mechanical and electrical amusement device without having first procured a license and paid the requisite fees therefor as provided in this Code. It shall be further unlawful for any person to own, operate or conduct any place or establishment open to the public where any mechanical and electrical amusement device may be operated without first obtaining a license therefor and paying the required fees prescribed in this Code, or by city council. 
(2)  Application for license; fee term. 
(a)  An application for a license shall be made to the building official on a form provided, and shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section. The application for license shall state, among other things: The number and type of machines or devices intended to be operated, the proposed locations for such machines or devices; the proposed business address; the full name of the business; and the full name, present addresses and date of birth of each and every owner of such business. 
(b)  The application for license shall be accompanied by the requisite license fee as established by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  The application for license shall also be accompanied by a scale drawing showing the floor plan of the proposed business, all exits and the proposed location of each machine or device. 
(d)  No license shall be issued until such time as the chief of the fire department has determined that the proposed location of each machine or device will not interfere with the egress from the building in case of fire, and that all fire regulations have been satisfied. 
(e)  No license shall be issued until such time as the building official has determined that all electrical, pneumatic and hydraulic connections to each machine or device comply with the City Code, and that all building and zoning regulations or other regulations of the city have been satisfied. 
(f)  No license shall be issued until such time as the chief of police has determined that the applicant, or each officer and each director, if the applicant is a corporation, has not been convicted within the preceding two (2) years of the violation of any criminal statute of this state, or of any municipal ordinance, excepting traffic offenses, regulating, controlling or in any way relating to the construction, use or operation of any establishments included in this section, which evidences a flagrant disregard of the safety or welfare of either the patrons, employees or persons residing or doing business nearby. 
(g)  If, after the issuance of any license, the licensee desires to operate other mechanical and electrical amusement devices in addition to those licensed, the applicant shall submit an amended application, in a form similar to the original application, showing the additions, changes or modifications desired. Any drawings or other information filed with the original license application and not affected by the additions, changes or modifications requested may be incorporated by reference in the amended application. 
(h)  The term of any license granted in this chapter shall begin January 1 of the license year and shall terminate at midnight on December 31 of the year. Original licenses shall be issued for the balance of the license year at the full license fee. License applications for license renewals shall be accepted and licenses issued for a period of fifteen (15) days prior to the annual expiration date. All licenses issued under this chapter shall be issued by the city clerk. 
(3)  Right of issuance. The chief of the fire department and chief of police shall either approve or disapprove the application for license within fifteen (15) days of receipt by them, and forward such recommendation to the building official. Should an application be disapproved by any of the aforementioned city officials, the reason therefor shall be endorsed upon the application and the applicant shall be notified thereof. The applicant shall be entitled to request a hearing before the city council as provided in section 7.17 of Chapter 70 of this Code in the event of disapproval of an application. 
(4)  Exempt persons; fee. No license fee shall be required for any person exempt from such fee by state or federal law. Such persons shall comply with all the provisions of this section and chapter. The city clerk shall, in all such cases, issue to such persons licenses which are clearly marked as to such exemption and the reasons therefor. 
(5)  Prohibitions and restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit or allow: 
(a)  Any person under the age of sixteen (16) years to operate or play any mechanical and electrical amusement device unless such person under the age of sixteen (16) years is accompanied by his parent or legal guardian. 
(b)  The operating or playing of any mechanical and electrical amusement device between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. of any day. 
(c)  The operating or playing of any mechanical and electrical amusement device unless a person eighteen (18) years of age or older is in control of the premises. 
(6)  Display of license. The license shall be exhibited at all times in some conspicuous place in the place of business. 
(7)  Transferability of license. It shall be unlawful to transfer any license from the licensee to any other person. 
(8)  Suspension or revocation right reserved. Any mechanical and electrical amusement device or arcade license may be revoked as provided in section 7.17 of Chapter 70 of this Code. 
(9)  Density area requirements in arcades. No owner shall permit, suffer or allow any less than a minimum of one hundred (100) gross square feet of building area per mechanical and electrical amusement device within the premises of any arcade. 
(10)  Maintenance of device required. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly permit any mechanical and electrical amusement device to be offered to the public for operation in return for payment of a fee or consideration, unless such device is fully operable and in safe operating condition. 
(11)  Establishment of license fee. The city council shall from time to time by resolution establish and revise the fee that shall accompany the application for license required by this section. 
(12)  Enforcement officer. The primary responsibility for ensuring compliance by any licensee under this section shall be reposed upon the building official who shall have the continuing responsibility to ensure that all mechanical and electrical amusement devices and arcades contained within the city are in compliance with the provisions of this Code. 
(13)  Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs of prosecution or by imprisonment, unless otherwise provided; it is specifically provided, however, that a mandatory minimum fee of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) be imposed by the sentencing court upon persons violating any of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1085, §§ 1, 5, 2-23-82) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1085, enacted February 23, 1982, amended §§ 7.286 and 7.287 to read as herein set out. Section 3 of that ordinance provided as follows: 
"All ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are to the extent of such conflict hereby repealed; it is the express intent of this ordinance, however, that it be harmonized with the provisions of Ordinance No. 678, as amended, containing section 5.3(4) and section 5.7(12) of chapter 45, zoning, of title V, zoning and planning, of the Code of the City of Southfield in respect to the definitions contained therein." 
Section 5, which provided the penalty for violation and did not specifically amend the Code, was designated by the editor as § 7.287(13). 
ARTICLE VII. - VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 7.288. - Definitions. 
    Certain terms as used in this chapter are defined as follows: 
(1)  Vending machine is a mechanical or electrical device which, upon the insertion of a coin or token, returns to the purchaser thereof the value of his money or token in merchandise, the value of which is five cents ($0.05) or more. 
(2)  Class I operator is any person, firm, corporation or partnership who contracts or permits any vending machine to be installed, used and/or operated in other than his own place of business. 
(3)  Class II operator is any person, firm, corporation or partnership who operates his own vending machines in his own place of business and derives all proceeds and profits from same. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.289. - License and fees. 
    No person, firm, corporation or partnership shall own or operate any vending machine as in section 7.288 defined without first obtaining a license therefor, and paying such fees as required pursuant to Chapter 71 of this Code. 
Sec. 7.290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MINIATURE GOLF COURSES AND DRIVING RANGES 

Sec. 7.291. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating any miniature golf course or driving range without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the director of the department of building and safety engineering. The director of building and safety engineering shall not grant any certification under the provisions of this section unless he shall have caused an inspection of the premises to have been made and has determined that no excessive danger or hazard to the public will result from the operation of the proposed business in the manner planned. Once the plans for the method of construction and operation of any such licensed business shall have been approved, the method of operation or construction shall not be materially changed except upon approval of the director of building and safety engineering. 
Secs. 7.292-7.295. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ARCHERY RANGE 

Sec. 7.296. - License required. 
    No person shall operate an archery range without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification by the chief of police and submission of plans and proposed method of operation to the city clerk. The city clerk shall submit such plans and method of proposed operation to the city council. No license to operate an archery range shall be issued until the city council shall affirmatively find that operation pursuant to the proposed plans and method of operation will not cause an undue hazard to the public or adjacent property owners. No licensee shall make any material change in the approved plan or approved method of operation without obtaining permission from the city council. 
Secs. 7.297-7.300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 7.301. - Definition. 
    The term "public swimming pool" shall have the meaning as defined in regulations of the state department of health issued pursuant to regulations contained in the Michigan Administrative Code, sections 325.392 through 325.396 (1954 Michigan Administrative Code). 
Sec. 7.302. - License required. 
    No person shall operate a public swimming pool without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification by the health officer. 
Sec. 7.303. - Rules and regulations. 
    Users of any public swimming pool shall comply with "Rules for Users of Pool" as issued and promulgated by the state department of health; all pool personnel shall comply with the rules and regulations of the state department of health applicable to such personnel. The construction, operation, sanitation, lighting, baths, toilets, dressing rooms, towers, floats and emergency equipment shall conform to the "General Regulations" for the operation of public swimming pools as promulgated by the state health department. Any violation of any of such rules or regulations shall constitute a violation of this Code and be punishable as prescribed in Chapter 1 hereof. 
CHAPTER 82. - MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESSES AND TRADES 
ARTICLE I. - CHRISTMAS TREES 

Sec. 7.321. - Christmas tree sales. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling Christmas trees on any open lot in the city, without first obtaining a license in the manner provided in Chapter 70 from the city clerk and paying a license fee in the amount prescribed in Chapter 71. 
(2)  All applications for a license shall be accompanied by a cash deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus evidence of a Michigan sales tax license granted or applied for, plus evidence of lease or ownership of the licensed premises, and permission for the city to enter upon the premises and clean them if necessary under the provisions of subsection (3) of this section. 
(3)  Each licensee shall clean up the licensed premises and remove unsold trees, branches and debris on or before the succeeding January 2. It shall be unlawful for a licensee to abandon licensed premises without such cleaning and removal. If any licensee fails to do such cleaning and removing, the director of public service or persons designated by him shall enter upon the premises, do such cleaning and removing, and charge the cost thereof to the deposit and the remainder, if any, shall be refunded. Any licensee who performs his obligations, as required by this section, shall be refunded his deposit on the next succeeding January 15. 
(4)  Local charitable, benevolent or educational nonprofit organizations shall not be required to pay the license fee established for Christmas tree sale by Chapter 71 of this Code nor required to post cash deposit established by this section, but shall otherwise comply with this section. 
Secs. 7.322-7.325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOTELS AND MOTELS 

Sec. 7.326. - Definitions. 
    The terms "hotel" and "motel" shall have the meanings ascribed to them in Chapter 45 (Zoning) of this Code. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.327. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain any hotel or motel without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police, the fire chief and the director of the department of building and safety engineering. 
Sec. 7.328. - Registration. 
    Every licensee shall provide and maintain a register or record in which shall be entered in ink the name of any person who is charged or pays for lodging or the rent of a room, the home address of such person or his last place of residence and the number of the room to which such person has been assigned. Such registration shall be completed at the time of the arrival of any such guests. No person shall enter any false information in such register, nor give any false information to any licensee or his employees, for the purpose of having the same entered in such register. Such register shall be maintained in such premises in plain view, and in a convenient place and shall be submitted upon the demand of any police officer of the city for examination. 
Secs. 7.329-7.335. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPEN PARKING STATIONS 

Sec. 7.336. - Definitions. 
    In the interpretation of this chapter an "open parking station" shall mean any plot, piece or parcel of land used for the purpose of temporarily storing ten (10) or more motor vehicles, where the owner or person storing such vehicles is charged a fee, and which are open to the general public. The unit of measurement of capacity of stations shall be as specified in Chapter 45, Zoning, for off-street parking lots. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.337. - License required. 
    No person shall maintain or conduct an open parking station within the city without first having obtained a license therefor. 
Sec. 7.338. - Abandoned vehicles. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee to report to the chief of police the make and license number of any car that shall have remained more than forty-eight (48) hours on any open parking station of the licensee without having been reclaimed. Such report shall be made within three (3) hours after the expiration of the forty-eight-hour period. 
Sec. 7.339. - Parking of vehicles. 
    Persons operating open parking stations shall at all times leave within the boundaries of such stations as much space as is required for shifting vehicles, and shall not move vehicles into nor park vehicles in the streets adjacent to such open parking station. 
Sec. 7.340. - Consent of owner to use of vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful to make any use for any purpose whatsoever of any motor vehicle parking in any open parking station, unless such use shall first be expressly authorized by the owner or person having control of such vehicles. 
Secs. 7.341-7.350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AMBULANCE SERVICE 

Sec. 7.351. - License required. 
(1)  No person, either as owner, agent or otherwise, shall furnish, operate, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in or profess to be engaged in the business or service of the transportation of patients upon the streets, alleys or any public way or place in the city, unless he holds a current valid license therefor. An ambulance operated by an agency of the United States shall not be required to be licensed under this chapter. 
(2)  No ambulance shall be operated, and no individual shall drive, attend or permit it to be operated as such on the streets, alleys or any public way or place in the city unless it shall be under the immediate supervision and direction of a person who is holding a currently valid license as an attendant-driver or attendant. 
(3)  Provided, however, that no such license shall be required for an ambulance, or for the driver, attendant or attendant-driver of an ambulance, which: 
(a)  Is rendering assistance to licensed ambulances in the case of a major catastrophe or emergency with which the licensed ambulances of the city are insufficient or unable to cope; 
(b)  Is operated from a location or headquarters outside of the city in order to transport patients who are picked up beyond the limits of the city to locations within the city or to transport patients who are picked up within the city to locations beyond the limits of the city but no such outside ambulance shall be used to pick up patients within the city for transportation to locations within the city, unless the driver, attendant and attendant-driver and the person subject to the provisions of subsection (1) of this section in respect of such ambulance, hold currently valid licenses issued pursuant to this chapter. 
Sec. 7.352. - Standards of ambulance equipment; duties of health officer. 
(1)  Required equipment in each ambulance shall include equipment adequate in the judgment of the health officer for dressing wounds, splinting fractures, controlling hemorrhage and providing oxygen. 
(2)  The health officer is authorized and directed to certify to the chief of police standards for ambulance equipment to implement the standards provided herein as to required equipment in ambulances. In determining the adequacy of equipment, the health officer shall take into consideration the current list of minimal equipment for ambulances adopted by the American College of Surgeons or its duly authorized Committee on Trauma. 
No license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of police. In addition to the requirements for certification of Chapter 70, certification shall be withheld for failure to conform to standards certified to the chief of police by the health officer. 
The chief of police, or his representative, shall periodically inspect the mechanical condition of licensed ambulance for safety. No licensee shall fail to submit his vehicles for inspection on request of the chief of police nor fail to correct any defect in condition in accordance with the written direction of the chief of police or his representative. 
Secs. 7.353-7.370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LOCKSMITHS 

Sec. 7.371. - Definitions. 
    The term "locksmith" shall mean a person engaged in the business of selling or repairing locks or of opening locks for which the key or for which the key or combination has been lost, mislaid or is otherwise not available. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.372. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of locksmith without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification of the chief of police. No locksmith shall open any lock by any means whatever unless he shall keep a record of such transaction in a record kept available for police inspection at the licensee's premises, which record shall state the name and address of each person for whom locks were opened and a description of the premises, place, or thing or vehicle for which the lock was opened. 
Secs. 7.373-7.375. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RENTAL AGENCIES-BICYCLES, MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR-DRIVEN CYCLES 

Sec. 7.376. - Definitions. 
    The terms "bicycle," "motorcycle" and "motor-driven cycle" shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Michigan Vehicle Code Act 200, Public Acts of Michigan, 1949, as amended. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.377. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of renting bicycles, motorcycles or motor-driven cycles without first obtaining a license therefor. Every licensee shall keep records clearly showing when each bicycle, motorcycle and motor-driven cycle was obtained and from whom obtained, which records shall be open for inspection by the police department at any time. Every bicycle, motorcycle and motor-driven cycle shall be equipped with all equipment required by this Code or the provisions of the Michigan Vehicle Code. No bicycle, motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall be rented until the same has been inspected and a tag or sticker issued for such vehicle by the police department. Every such vehicle kept for rental shall be subject to inspection at any reasonable time by any police officer of the city. If upon reinspection such vehicle is found not fit for operation or as not having required equipment, such vehicle shall not again be rented or offered for rent until made fit, reinspected and approved by the police department. No license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of police. 
Secs. 7.378-7.380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DRY CLEANING AND DYEING 

Sec. 7.381. - Definition. 
    The term "dry cleaning and dyeing" shall have the meaning as defined in Act 327 of the Public Acts of 1947, the State of Michigan, as amended (CL 48 Sec. 29.201 et seq.) and shall include Class I, II, III and IV installations, as therein defined. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.382. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of dry cleaning or dry dyeing or operating any dry cleaning or dry dyeing plant without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of the fire department and of the director of building and safety engineering. The fire department shall conduct periodic inspections to determine that the provisions of state law are being complied with. 
Secs. 7.383-7.390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SNOW REMOVAL EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 7.391. - Use of snow removal equipment. 
    No person shall use any mechanically driven vehicle for the removal of snow from sidewalks or other pedestrian easements in the city which will, by virtue of its use for such purpose, damage or tend to damage any sidewalk or improved easement in the city. The use of mechanically driven vehicles for such purpose shall be lawful only where such mechanically driven vehicles do not cause damage herein prohibited. 
Sec. 7.392. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of snow removal by the use of mechanically driven vehicles without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued until the director of the department of building and safety engineering shall determine whether any of the equipment which the applicant proposes to use would be detrimental to or tend to damage streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city. If the director determines that the vehicle or equipment which the applicant proposes to use will not damage or tend to damage any street, alley or sidewalk the license may be granted upon payment of the fee and the filing of any bond or insurance which may be required in accordance with Chapter 71 of this Code. Any license issued hereunder shall permit the use of only the equipment described in the application for the license. No licensee shall use other equipment without first obtaining approval therefor based upon an additional application fully describing such equipment which shall be submitted to the director of the department of building and safety engineering for his approval the same as in the case of a new application. An additional fee for the additional equipment shall be paid by the licensee but no additional annual fee for operation of the business shall be payable solely because of the additional or substitution of equipment. 
Secs. 7.393-7.395. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - LAWN CARE SERVICE 

Sec. 7.396. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the term "lawn care service" shall mean offering to the public a service of caring for or maintaining any lawn by cutting, trimming, fertilizing, rolling or otherwise maintaining or improving any lawn. It shall not include landscape services or tree care even though cutting, fertilizing, rolling or otherwise maintaining or improving a lawn may be incidental thereto. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.397. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating a lawn care service without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon certification by the chief of police. Every applicant shall file his fingerprints in the noncriminal identification file of the police department. No license shall be required for the casual operation of a lawn care service on a temporary basis. 
Sec. 7.398. - Commercial pesticide application. 
    No person shall engage in the business of applying commercial economic poisons for control or extermination of lawn or garden pests without being first licensed by the Michigan Department of Agriculture pursuant to 1949 PA 297 (MCL 286.161 et seq.). 
Cross reference- Fumigation regulations, § 9.251 et seq. 
Secs. 7.399, 7.400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - GASOLINE STATIONS AND CAR WASH ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 7.401. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the operation of any gasoline station without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the chief of the fire department. Licensees shall conform in all respects to the requirements pertaining to gasoline stations of the National Fire Prevention Code, 1965 Edition, as promulgated by the American Insurance Association, New York City, New York. The use and storage of flammable liquids shall conform to the Flammable Liquids Regulations of the state fire marshal, adopted November 29, 1955, effective February 15, 1956. The fire department shall make periodic inspections of gasoline stations to determine compliance with such codes and regulations and the requirements of this Code. 
Sec. 7.402. - Car wash license. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating a car wash pursuant to which all or part of such operations are conducted within a building, without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued except upon certification by the director of the department of building and safety engineering. Persons holding licenses for gasoline stations may engage in the washing of motor vehicles on the licensed premises without obtaining an additional car wash license. 
Secs. 7.403-7.406. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ICE CREAM TRUCKS 

Sec. 7.407. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the term "ice cream truck" shall mean any truck or other vehicles used for the sale or delivery of ice cream, either on an established route or traveling from house to house. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.408. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating an ice cream truck without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be issued until such vehicle is inspected and approved by the county health department in order to protect the health and safety of the general public. 
Sec. 7.409. - Fees. 
    Before any such license is issued, the applicant shall pay to the city treasurer such fees as prescribed in Chapter 71. 
Secs. 7.410-7.420. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 7.421. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the term "garage sale" shall include the terms "basement sale," "attic sale" or other types of so-called residential sales of used tangible personal property such as clothing, household effects, tools, garden implements, toys, recreation equipment or other used or secondhand items customarily found in and about the home and advertised in a manner whereby the public at large is, or can be, aware of such sale. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.7. 
Sec. 7.422. - Permit required. 
    Before a garage sale can be conducted the homeowner or occupant of the premises at which such sale shall be held shall obtain a permit from the city clerk. In addition to other information that may be required by the city clerk the permit shall contain the name of the applicant and the duration of the sale. The fee for such permit shall be the sum of one dollar ($1.00). No additional permit shall be issued for the conducting of a garage sale on the premises covered by the permit until at least six (6) months have expired from the date of expiration of the original permit. 
Sec. 7.423. - Duration of sale. 
    Each garage sale shall be limited to five (5) consecutive days of operation and shall not be conducted before 8:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m. of each day. 
Sec. 7.424. - Signs and display of merchandise. 
    At the time the application for a permit is granted the city clerk shall furnish the applicant with a garage sale sign not to exceed four (4) square feet in area which shall be used to advertise the garage sale. Such sign shall contain the street address of the premises on which the sale is to be conducted, the permit number, and the expiration date of the permit. Such sign shall be placed at least ten (10) feet within property line of the premises. The applicant may, at the time of obtaining the permit, request an additional sign upon payment of the sum of two dollars ($2.00). Such additional sign shall be placed at a location other than the premises at which the garage sale is being held and shall also contain the words "Warning: Not to be placed in a public right-of-way or on private property without the owner's consent." It shall be the duty and responsibility of the permittee to remove such sign or signs immediately after the completion of the garage sale in accordance with the permit. Any other sign pertaining to the garage sale is prohibited. Outside display of merchandise to be sold is also prohibited. 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, § 8.31 et seq. 
Sec. 7.425. - Limitations on sales. 
    The garage sale shall be conducted only by the homeowner or occupant and no merchandise of any nature shall be brought in from any other source in connection with such sale. The limitations of this section shall not be applicable, however, when the permit is obtained and the sale conducted by a church, school, veterans organization, fraternal or religious society or other civic or charitable nonprofit organization. 
Sec. 7.426. - Nonapplicability. 
    Sections 7.422, 7.423 and 7.425 shall not apply to the homeowner or occupant who, during the normal course of housekeeping, advertises or otherwise offers for sale individual pieces of furniture or an appliance being replaced or no longer needed. 
Secs. 7.427-7.429. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TREE SERVICES 

Sec. 7.430. - Definitions.
