    For the purposes of this chapter the term "tree services" shall mean offering to the public the service of removing, transplanting or the trimming of trees as the term "trees" is defined in section 5.56 of Chapter 45, Zoning, of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1325, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 7.431. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of providing tree services without first obtaining a license in the manner provided in Chapter 70 from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1325, § 1, 8-12-91) 
Sec. 7.432. - License fee; bond. 
    An application for a tree services license shall be accompanied by a license fee as established by resolution of the city council. In connection with the license application a proposed licensee shall sign an acknowledgement of receipt of a copy of section 5.56 of Chapter 45, Zoning, of this Code and an agreement to comply with the terms and provisions of said section. No tree services license shall be granted unless the proposed licensee has also executed a bond in favor of the city that complies with the provisions of section 7.12 of this Code. The sum of the bond shall be established by resolution of the city council and conditioned for the faithful performance of this code and the laws of this state. 
(Ord. No. 1325, § 1, 8-12-91) 
CHAPTER 83. - MYOMASSOLOGISTS AND MASSAGE PARLORS 

Sec. 7.501. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words have the meanings hereinafter ascribed to them: 
    Applicant means a person applying for a license under this chapter. 
    Employee means any and all persons employed by a massage establishment or any person who renders any service to a massage establishment or its customers on its premises and receives compensation for that service. 
    Instructor means a person who is a licensed myomassologist and teaches in a school of massage. 
    License means the document issued under this chapter that enables a person to operate a massage establishment. 
    Massage establishment or massage parlor means a building, place or establishment which is used primarily for the practice of body massage on the human body for compensation and for other than cosmetic or beautifying purposes, with or without the use of nonpowered mechanical or bathing devices. 
    Myomassologist means a person who offers his or her services for hire in the practice of massage and who is licensed by the State of Michigan as a massage therapist. 
    Myomassology or practice of massage means the scientific art of body massage, whether by hand or with a nonpowered mechanical or electrical apparatus, for the purpose of body massage or contouring; including the use of oil rubs, salt glows, hot and cold packs, and baths. 
    Owner means a person who conducts, operates, or owns a massage establishment. 
    Person means an individual, sole proprietorship, partnership, association, corporation firm or other form of business organization or group, or the individuals comprising such business organization or group. 
    School of massage means a school recognized by the state board of massage which requires for admission students with a tenth-grade education or its equivalent; which employs one (1) or more competent licensed myomassologists as instructors; and which has minimum requirements of a continuous course of study and training and consisting of study in physiology, anatomy, massage theory, hydrotherapy, ethics, and practical massage, which courses of study and training are approved by the state. 
    Sexual area or genital area means the genitals, pubic area, anus, or perineum of any person, or the breasts of a female. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.502. - Massage establishment license required. 
    No person shall operate, conduct, engage in, or carry on, or permit to be operated, conducted, engaged in, or carried on, in or upon any premises in the city, the operation of a massage establishment or school of massage without a valid massage establishment license. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, § 7.1 et seq. 
Sec. 7.503. - Certification required for massage establishment license. 
(1)  No massage establishment license shall be granted without the certification and approval of the fire chief, and the director of building, housing and redevelopment, as prescribed in chapter 70. 
(2)  No massage establishment license shall be granted without the certification and approval of the chief of police. Certification shall be based on a finding that the applicant's character, moral integrity, and physical and mental condition is not inimical to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare. Such finding shall be based on all competent and pertinent information available to the chief of police. The chief of police shall deny certification if he finds that: 
(a)  The operation of the massage establishment, as proposed by the applicant, will not comply with all applicable ordinances and statutes; or 
(b)  The applicant or any other person who will be directly or indirectly engaged in the management or operation of the massage establishment has been convicted of: 
i.  A felony; or 
ii.  Any offense involving criminal sexual conduct; or 
iii.  Prostitution, pandering, solicitation for the purpose of prostitution; or 
iv.  Any crime involving theft, fraud or deceit. 
(3)  Upon refusal of any certification required herein the applicant shall have the right to a hearing and review as prescribed in chapter 70. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.504. - Massage establishment license. 
    This issuance, renewal, suspension or revocation of a massage establishment license shall be in the manner prescribed in chapter 70. Additionally, any applicant for a massage establishment license, including any partner or limited partner of a partnership applicant, and any officer or director of a corporate applicant and any shareholder holding more than ten (10) percent of the stock of a corporate applicant, shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  The type of ownership of the business. 
(2)  The business address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted. 
(3)  The names of all myomassologists, including a copy of their current massage therapy license issued by the State of Michigan, and other employees and their residential addresses. 
(4)  The business, occupation, or employment and addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(5)  The massage establishment or similar business license history of the applicant; whether such person has had a license suspended or revoked, and the reason therefor. 
(6)  All criminal convictions, forfeiture of bonds, and pleas of nolo contendere on all criminal charges, except minor traffic violations. 
(7)  The fingerprints and two (2) front face, color portrait photographs of the applicant taken within thirty (30) days of the date of application. 
(8)  Authorization for the city, its agents and employees, to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license. 
(9)  Written declaration, by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the foregoing information in the application is true and correct, said declaration being duly dated and signed. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.505. - License fee; bond. 
    An application for a massage establishment license shall be accompanied by the requisite license fee as established by resolution of the city council. No massage establishment license shall be granted to any person unless the person has executed a bond to the city that complies with the provisions of section 7.12 of this Code. The sum of the bond shall be established by resolution of the city council and conditioned for the faithful performance of these sections, the City Charter, this Code, and other ordinances of the city and laws of this state. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.506. - Inspections. 
    The department of building, housing and redevelopment, the fire department, and the police department may visit and enter a massage establishment for the purposes of inspection and determining that the massage establishment is complying with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.507. - Rules and regulations. 
    A massage establishment shall comply with the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Service in massage establishments shall be limited to exercise, baths and massage and items related to the practice of massage. Medical treatment shall not be given to a patron. 
(2)  Only myomassologists with current State of Michigan massage therapy licenses shall conduct the practice of massage in a massage establishment 
(3)  All employees shall wear clean, nontransparent uniforms or outer garments covering his or her breasts, buttocks and genital areas. Sleeves shall not extend below the elbow. 
(4)  All robes, towels, blankets and linens furnished for the use of one (1) patron shall be thoroughly laundered before being offered to another. 
(5)  The sexual or genital area of patrons must be covered by towels, cloths, or undergarments when in the presence of employees, myomassologists and other patrons. 
(6)  No massage establishment shall be conducted in direct connection with living quarters. 
(7)  Bathing devices shall be thoroughly cleaned before the use of each patron. 
(8)  Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area of a massage establishment. 
(9)  Massage establishments shall meet all applicable building, fire and health requirements imposed by law, ordinance, rule or regulation enacted by the city, the county, or the state. 
(10)  Massage establishment licenses, and the licenses for all myomassologists on the premises, shall be prominently posted in the massage establishment for easy inspection. 
(11)  Adequate equipment for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in performing the practice of massage shall be provided and used between each massage. 
(12)  Adequate bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities shall be provided for patrons. If male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at the establishment, separate bathing, locker and toilet facilities shall be provided as well as separate and segregated rooms for the practice of massage. The practice of massage shall not be conducted on male and female patrons in the same room or area of the establishment. 
    Violation of any of these rules and regulations is deemed to be "cause" as defined by section 7.18(4) of this Code for the purpose of suspending or revoking a massage establishment license pursuant to section 7.17 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.508. - Unlawful activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, employee or myomassologist to knowingly place his or her hand upon, to touch with any part of his or her body, to fondle in any manner, or to massage a sexual or genital area of any other person in a massage establishment. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.509. - Licenses required. 
    It shall be unlawful for an owner of premises required to have a license pursuant to section 7.502 to employ as a myomassologist any person who does not have a current State of Michigan massage therapist license. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.510. - Hours of operation. 
    No massage establishment shall be open for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.511. - Patronage by minors. 
    No massage of any person under the age of eighteen (18) years upon premises required to have a license pursuant to section 7.502 shall be permitted except upon written order of a licensed physician, osteopath, or physical therapist, said order being dated and in the possession of the myomassologist administering the massage. This section does not apply to persons under the age of eighteen (18) years accompanied by a parent or legal guardian who are present during the massage. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
Sec. 7.512, 7.513. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, adopted April 12, 2018, repealed §§ 7.512 and 7.513, which pertained to myomassologist permits and derived from Ord. No. 1214, § 1, adopted December 8, 1986. 
Sec. 7.514. - Exemptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, psychiatrists, psychologists, clinical social workers, family counselors and clergymen who are currently licensed to practice their respective professions in the state, or who are permitted to practice temporarily under the auspices of an associate or establishment duly licensed in the state. 
(2)  Nurses who are currently registered under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of nursing duties. 
(3)  A trainer of any duly constituted athletic team who administers a massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(4)  Barbers and beauticians who are duly currently licensed under the laws of this state and who administer a massage in the normal course of their duties. 
(5)  Participants in growth seminars or sensitivity sessions, provided such seminars or sessions are conducted by a member of one (1) of the exempted professions defined in section 7.514(1) above. 
(6)  Any duly licensed establishment within which persons in professions identified in this section 7.514 practice their respective professions. 
(Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 12-8-86; Ord. No. 1688 , § 1, 4-12-18) 
CHAPTER 84. - SOLICITORS 

Sec. 7.601. - Findings. 
    It is hereby determined that it is in the best interest of the city to enact an ordinance regulating organizations and persons soliciting in the city in order to promote and protect the public safety of those persons soliciting, as well as those persons in the city being solicited. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.602. - Definitions. 
(a)  Chief means the Southfield Chief of Police. 
(b)  Clerk means the Southfield City Clerk. 
(c)  Person means an individual or any firm, corporation, association, club, society, or other organization. 
(d)  Solicitor means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence or residential building in the city, not having been invited by the owner or legal occupant thereof, for the purpose of offering or attempting to offer goods, wares, merchandise, services, items of personal property or real property, either for immediate or future delivery; or to request a contribution of funds or anything of value, or sell goods or services for political, charitable, religious, or other noncommercial purposes. 
(e)  Solicitation includes all activities ordinarily performed by a solicitor as indicated under paragraph (d) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.603. - Permit requirements and exemptions. 
    No person shall engage in solicitation activities within the city without first obtaining a permit issued by the clerk; provided, however, that the following are exempted from the provisions of this section: 
(a)  Persons engaged in soliciting within three (3) miles from their residence for an educational, charitable, religious, or youth organization. 
(b)  Veterans exempt from local license requirements under state law. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.604. - Permit application. 
    A permit application filed hereunder shall furnish the following information: 
(a)  Proof of age, address and identification of the applicant, to be provided through the applicant's drivers license or other legally recognized form of identification; 
(b)  A brief description of the solicitation activity to be conducted; 
(c)  The hours and location for which the right to solicit is desired; 
(d)  The length of time the applicant intends to solicit; 
(e)  If employed, the name, address, and telephone number of the employer; or, if acting as an agent, the name, address, and telephone number of the principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form establishing the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case may be; 
(f)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor, or ordinance violation (other than traffic violations), the nature of the offense or violation, the penalty or punishment imposed, and the date when and place where such offense occurred; 
(g)  Two (2) photographs of the applicant, one (1) photograph being a photograph taken within one hundred twenty (120) days prior to the date of filing of the application and the other photograph being from the applicant's drivers license, a copy of said driver's license to be attached to the applicant's application. The photograph, which is not from the applicant's drivers license, shall be at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches and shall show the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. In the event that the applicant does not have a driver's license, then the applicant shall submit a second, separate photograph with his application, said photograph being at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches and showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; and 
(h)  A description and license number of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the solicitation activity. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.605. - Administrative fee. 
    An administrative, processing fee for a solicitor's permit shall be established by resolution of the city council, and said administrative processing fee shall be paid when the application is filed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.606. - Application review and permit issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application, the clerk shall forward it to the chief for review of the application as deemed necessary to ensure the protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(b)  After such review, the chief shall endorse upon the application his or her approval or disapproval and return the application to the clerk who shall, if the application is approved and upon payment of the prescribed fee, deliver the required permit to the applicant. 
(c)  The permit shall show the name, address, and photograph of the permittee; the kind of goods or services to be sold or delivered; the date of issuance; and the length of time that the permit shall be in effect. The permit shall also show the permit number and identifying description of any vehicle to be used in carrying on the business for which the permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.607. - Denial of permit. 
(a)  Upon the chief's review of the application, the chief may refuse to approve an application for a permit under this chapter for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The location and time of solicitation would endanger the safety and welfare of the solicitors or their customers. 
(2)  An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on the application. 
(3)  The applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor, or ordinance violation involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled substances, any violent acts against persons or property, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation. 
(4)  The applicant has been denied a permit or had a permit revoked under this chapter within the two (2) years immediately preceding the date of application unless the applicant can and does show to the satisfaction of the chief that the reasons for such earlier denial or revocation no longer exist. 
(5)  Any other reason that relates to the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(b)  The chief's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall be noted on the application; and the applicant shall be notified by the clerk that his or her application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. Notice shall be mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application form. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.608. - Permit expiration. 
    All permits issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on December 31 of the year issued, unless an earlier expiration date is noted on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.609. - Identification badges. 
    At the same time the permit is issued, the clerk shall issue to each permittee a badge, which shall be worn by the permittee in such a way as to be conspicuous at all times while the permittee is soliciting or peddling in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.610. - Permit exhibition. 
    Every person required to obtain a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall exhibit the permit when requested to do so by any prospective customer or city employee. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.611. - Transfer prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the permittee to use or wear any permit or badge issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.612. - Entry upon signed premises unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct solicitation activities, with or without a permit, where the owner or legal occupant has posted, at the entry to the premises, a sign bearing the words "No Solicitors", "No Solicitation", or words of similar import, indicating that no solicitation is desired. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.613. - Hours of solicitation. 
    Solicitation activities shall only be permitted within the city between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.614. - Permit revocation. 
    Any permit issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended by the chief, after notice of hearing, for any of the following reasons: 
(a)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for a permit; 
(b)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made by the permittee in the course of conducting solicitation activities; 
(c)  Conducting solicitation activities contrary to the provisions contained in the permit or this chapter; 
(d)  Conviction for any crime identified in subsection 7.607(a)(3); or 
(e)  Conducting solicitation activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace, or endanger the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.615. - Notice and hearing. 
    Notice of a hearing before the chief for revocation or suspension of a permit issued under this chapter shall be provided in writing and shall set forth specifically the grounds for the proposed revocation or suspension and the time and place of the hearing. Notice shall be sent by first class mail to the permittee at the address shown on the permit application at least five (5) days prior to the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
Sec. 7.616. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the chief to disapprove, suspend, or revoke a permit applied for under the provisions of this chapter shall have the right to appeal such action or decision to the city council within fifteen (15) days after the notice of the action or decision has been sent by first class mail to the person's address as shown on the permit application form. 
(b)  An appeal shall be taken by filing with the clerk a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. 
(c)  The clerk shall transmit the written statement to the city council within ten (10) days of its receipt, and the city council shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal. 
(d)  A hearing shall be set not later than thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of the appellant's written statement. 
(e)  Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be sent by first class mail to the appellant at the address shown on the permit application at least five (5) days prior to the hearing. 
(f)  The decision of the city council on the appeal shall be final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 1458, § 1, 11-13-00) 
CHAPTER 85. - SMOKING LOUNGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 7.701 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in this chapter. 
a.  Smoking lounge means an establishment, which, as one of its principal business purposes, promotes the smoking of tobacco products or other legal substances on its premises. The term "smoking lounge" includes, but, is not limited to: cigar lounges, hookah cafes, tobacco lounges, tobacco clubs, or tobacco bars. 
b.  Principal business purpose means: 
i.  The devotion of more than fifty (50) percent of its interior floor space for the promotion of smoking tobacco products or other legal substances at the establishment; or, 
ii.  The receipt of more than thirty-five (35) percent of its revenues from the smoking of tobacco products or other legal substances at the establishment; or, 
iii.  The devotion of more than thirty-five (35) percent of its advertising expenditures to the promotion of smoking tobacco products or other legal substances at the establishment. 
c.  Tobacco products mean any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigars, cigarettes, hookah tobacco, or non-cigarette, smoking tobacco. 
d.  Other legal substances include clove cigarettes, kreteks, herbal cigarettes, and any other legal substance that can be consumed by smoking. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.702. - Smoking lounge establishment license required. 
    No person shall operate a smoking lounge in the city without first obtaining a smoking lounge license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. A smoking lounge license shall not be issued unless the applicant is approved by the state department of community health to operate a tobacco specialty retail store or cigar bar and possesses a valid exemption of the state smoking prohibition of section 12603, Public Act 368 of 1978, and presents a copy of such exemption along with the application as set forth in section 7.703 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.703. - Application for smoking lounge license. 
a.  An applicant shall submit to the city clerk a fully completed application, on a form that is prepared and furnished by the city clerk. 
b.  The application shall include at least the following information: 
i.  The full and complete name and current address of the applicant(s). 
1.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each partner shall be listed. 
2.  If the applicant is a privately-held corporation, the name and address of each corporate officer, member of board of directors, and stockholder shall be listed, and a copy of the articles of incorporation shall be attached to the application. 
3.  If the applicant is a publicly-held corporation, the name and address of each corporate officer, each member of the board of directors and each stockholder who owns ten (10) percent or more of the corporate stock shall be listed on the application. 
4.  If the applicant is a limited liability company, the name and address of each member, manager, and assignee of a membership interest shall be listed, and the articles of incorporation shall be attached to the application. 
ii.  The complete name, address, and telephone number of the proposed licensed business; 
iii.  Written statement as to the applicant's experience in operating similar businesses; 
iv.  A concise statement as to the individual applicant's past employment; 
v.  Any other information pertinent to the applicant and the operation of the proposed licensed business. 
c.  An applicant shall attach to the completed application a floor plan, drawn to scale, showing the interior of the proposed business, and uses of the proposed spaces. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.704. - Licensing. 
    Smoking lounge licenses shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 70 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.705. - License fees. 
    The fee for a smoking lounge license shall be established by resolution of the city council, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.706. - Investigation. 
a.  After the city clerk has received a completed application, it shall be, at a minimum, forwarded to the following city departments for review and investigation: 
i.  Police; 
ii.  Fire; and, 
iii.  Building inspection. 
b.  During city business hours or at another mutually agreeable time, the applicant shall allow the representatives of the above referenced city departments onto the property and into the proposed licensed premises to complete an investigation. 
c.  If all of the above listed city departments approve the application, and it conforms to the provisions of this chapter, the city clerk shall issue a smoking lounge license to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.707. - Reasons for denial. 
a.  Requirements for applicants. A license may be denied as a result of one or more of the following factors: 
i.  If any of the individuals who are required to be identified on the application, as set forth in section 7.703 above, who have previously received a smoking lounge license, has had the license revoked for cause, as defined in chapter 70 of this Code. 
ii.  If any of the individuals who are required to be identified on the application, as set forth in section 7.703 above, have been convicted or found responsible for a violation of any federal, state, or local law involving moral turpitude, dishonesty, fraud, violence, criminal sexual conduct, controlled substances, the sale, distribution, or furnishing of tobacco, or the sale, distribution, or furnishing of alcoholic liquors. 
iii.  If the applicant proposes to hire a manager or agent to handle the business operations, and the proposed manager or agent does not possess the same qualifications as those required of the licensee as set forth herein. 
iv.  If an applicant does not own the premises for which a smoking lounge license is sought or does not have a lease or other right of exclusive possession of the premises proposed for the business for the full period for which the license is issued. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.708. - Requirement for the proposed licensed premises. 
    A smoking lounge license shall not be issued if there are any violation(s) of the applicable building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, or fire prevention codes, applicable zoning regulations, or applicable public health regulations, unless such violation can be remedied within a stated period of time as determined by the fire department and/or building department. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.709. - Display of smoking lounge license. 
    A smoking lounge license issued, pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall be prominently displayed near the entrance of the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.710 - No transferability; change of ownership. 
a.  Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable. 
b.  Each license issued under this chapter is separate and distinct, and no person shall exercise any of the privileges granted under any license other than that which he/she holds. A separate license shall be issued for each specific smoking lounge business within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.711. - Manager-Change of manager. 
    At least one (1) registered manager who has been identified on the application for a smoker's lounge license shall be on the premises at all times that the business is open. It shall be unlawful for any person not identified on the smoker's lounge license application to work as a manager of a smoking lounge business unless the proposed manager or operator has submitted a registration form with the individual's legal name and any aliases; home address; telephone numbers; date of birth; and driver's license number; and, is determined qualified to serve as a manager by the city clerk, using the criteria, as set forth in this chapter. All managers must be over the age of twenty-one (21) years old. The licensee shall be responsible for notifying the city of any proposed change in management and insuring that the proposed new manager has obtained the required approval before working or serving as a manager of the licensed establishment. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.712. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for a smoking lounge business to be open for business or for the licensee, manager, or any employee of a licensee to allow patrons to enter into the licensed premises between midnight (12:00 a.m.) of each day until 10:00 a.m. the next day. All individuals, except employees of the smoking lounge business, shall be required to leave or be removed from the building by 12:30 a.m. Only a maximum of three (3) employees shall remain on the premises after 12:30 a.m.; and, each shall carry proof of employment at the licensed establishment, such as an identification badge. The manager and/or employees shall provide proof of such employment when requested to do so by a member of the police department or fire department. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.713. - Age restrictions. 
    No one shall be allowed on the premises of a smoking lounge business unless the individual is the age of eighteen (18) years of age or older. The manager and/or employees shall ensure that identifications of individuals on the premises have been checked to determine that every individual is over the age of eighteen (18) years of age or older before entry into the premises. The manager and/or employees shall secure exit doors to ensure that no one has or is attempting to gain secret entry into the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.714. - Parking restrictions. 
    The manager and/or employees shall require patrons to leave the parking lot of the smoking lounge business by 12:30 a.m. The manager and/or employees shall insure that patrons of the smoking lounge business are not parking in adjacent or neighboring parking lots or in residential areas that are not part of the parking area provided to the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.715. - Rules and regulations. 
a.  The following rules and regulations shall be adhered to by managers and employees of any smoker's lounge establishment: 
i.  Alcohol and liquor: No manager, employee, volunteer, or representative of the licensee shall serve or engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages on the premises, including, but not limited to: any spirituous, vinous, malt or fermented liquor, beverages, liquids, and compounds; nor shall persons obviously under the influence of any intoxicating drug or beverage be allowed to enter or remain upon the establishment premises. 
ii.  Consumption of alcohol: It shall be unlawful to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages in any smoking lounge business. The licensee's manager and/or employees shall immediately remove any person who opens or consumes alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
iii.  Controlled substances: It shall be unlawful to permit the use, sale, or presence of controlled substances (as defined under MCL 333.7212, et seq., of the Public Health Code, as amended, or a rule promulgated under that Act or Code), on the licensed premises. The manager and/or employees shall immediately remove any person possessing, distributing, selling, consuming, and/or using controlled substances on the licensed premises. 
iv.  There shall be no live entertainment in a licensed establishment; nor shall any products or services other than tobacco products be sold or offered for sale in the establishment, with the exception of packaged food products and bottled non-alcohol beverages, the sale of which constitutes less than five (5) percent of gross sales of the establishment. 
v.  It is the duty of the licensee to ensure that at least one (1) manager is on duty and on the premises at all times that persons are on the licensed premises; and, that, the manager is visible to any patron who is present on the premises. 
vi.  It is the duty of the licensee and managers of the premises to ensure that any doors to public areas on the premises remain unlocked during business hours. 
vii.  The manager and employees of the smoking lounge establishment shall prohibit loitering by persons outside the establishment either on the premises or within fifty (50) feet of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.716. - Compliance with laws. 
    The business licensee, the manager, and employees shall comply with all federal and state laws and the City Code of Ordinances, including, but not limited to, building and fire codes. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
Sec. 7.717. - Right of entry. 
    The filing of an application for a smoker's lounge license shall constitute consent of the applicant and licensee and his/her or its agents, managers, and/or employees to permit the city's police department, building department, planning department, or any other department or agent of the city to conduct routine inspections of any licensed smoker's lounge establishment during the hours the establishment is conducting business and during any time that employees or managers are on the premises. The police department and the fire department shall be allowed unannounced access to the smoking lounge premises to inspect for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1621 , § 1, 3-30-14) 
CHAPTER 86. - MEDICAL MARIJUANA FACILITY LICENSE 

Sec. 7.801. - Purpose and intent. 
    This chapter is adopted for the purpose of regulating and promulgating licensing, regulatory and fee requirements for medical marihuana facilities where medical marihuana is provided to qualified patients by primary caregivers. The fundamental intent of this chapter is to facilitate a private and confidential qualified patient and primary caregiver relationship whereby the cultivation, distribution and use of marihuana is strictly for medical purposes. However, law enforcement officers are required to investigate and pursue prosecution with regard to the unlawful cultivation, distribution or consumption of marihuana. Accordingly, the licensure of a particular medical marihuana facility as the site of cultivation and distribution of marihuana, which need not undermine the privacy and confidentiality of the patient-caregiver relationship, is critical to law enforcement in order to identify and distinguish sites of lawful activity from sites of unlawful activity. Accordingly, this chapter permits authorization for lawful activity based on the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, P.A. 2008, Initiated Law 1 (MMMA). Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as allowing a person or persons to engage in conduct that endangers others or causes a public nuisance, or to allow use, cultivation, growth, possession or control of marihuana not in strict accordance with the express authorizations of the MMMA and this chapter; and, nothing in this chapter shall be construed to undermine or provide immunity from federal law as it may be enforced by the federal or state government relative to the cultivation, distribution, or use of marihuana. Thus, the authorization of activity in chapter 45 and the approval of a license under this chapter shall not have the effect of superseding or nullifying federal law applicable to the cultivation, use, and possession of marihuana, and all applicants and grantees of licenses are on notice that they may be subject to prosecution and civil penalty, including forfeiture of property and revocation of license. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.802. - Definitions. 
(a)  City: The City of Southfield. 
(b)  Debilitating medical condition: Medical conditions defined as debilitating under the MMMA, as amended. 
(c)  Department: The Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs. 
(d)  Enclosed locked facility: An indoor closet, room or other comparable, stationary, and fully enclosed area, equipped with secured locks or other functioning security devices that permit access only by a registered primary caregiver or registered qualifying patient, as defined under the MMMA, as amended. 
(e)  Marihuana: That term as defined in Section 7106 of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.7106. 
(f)  Medical use: The acquisition, possession, cultivation, manufacture, use, internal possession, delivery, transfer, or transportation of marihuana or paraphernalia relating to the administration of marihuana to treat or alleviate a registered qualifying patient's debilitating medical condition or symptoms associated with the debilitating medical condition, as defined by the MMMA, as amended. 
(g)  Medical marihuana facility: Any licensed facility, building or structure used, maintained or occupied to provide the medical use of marihuana by qualifying patient(s) and a primary caregiver as provided and authorized by the MMMA, as amended, and in exchange for compensation for reimbursement of costs associated with assisting a registered qualifying patient in the medical use of marihuana. Any such compensation shall not constitute the sale of controlled substances. A medical marihuana facility is located on land that is owned, leased, or rented by either the registered qualifying patient or a person designated through the departmental registration process as the primary caregiver for the registered qualifying patient or patients for whom the marihuana plants are grown; and equipped with functioning locks or other security devices that restrict access to only the registered qualifying patient or the registered primary caregiver who owns, leases, or rents the property on which the structure is located. 
(h)  Primary caregiver: A person who is at least twenty-one (21) years old and who has agreed to assist with a patient's medical use of marihuana and who has not been convicted of any felony within the past ten (10) years and has never been convicted of a felony involving illegal drugs or a felony that is an assaultive crime as defined in Subsection 9a of Chapter X of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1927 PA 175, and who has been issued and possesses a registry identification card. 
(i)  Qualifying patient: A person who has been diagnosed by a physician as having a debilitating medical condition as defined under the MMMA, as amended. 
(j)  Registry identification card: A document issued by the department that identifies a person as a registered qualifying patient or registered primary caregiver as defined under the MMMA, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.803. - License required. 
    No person or entity shall engage in the business or occupation of providing medical marihuana within the city without first obtaining a medical marihuana facility license issued by the city pursuant to the requirements and procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.804. - Application for license. 
    An application for a license under this chapter shall be submitted to the city clerk's office. An application shall: 
(a)  Provide the primary caregiver's identification number as appears on his/her registry identification card as issued by the State of Michigan. 
(b)  Include the address and legal description of the precise premises at which there shall be possession, cultivation, distribution or other assistance in the use of marihuana; 
(c)  Specify the name and address of the place where all unused portions of marihuana plants cultivated in connection with the use of marihuana or caregiver activity shall be disposed; 
(d)  Describe the enclosed, locked facility in which any and all cultivation of marihuana is proposed to occur, or where marihuana is stored, with such description including: location in building, precise measurement of the floor dimensions and height, and the security device(s) for the facility; 
(e)  Describe all locations in the premises where a caregiver or other person authorized under the MMMA shall render assistance to a qualifying patient; 
(f)  Specify the number of patients to be assisted, including the number of patients for whom marihuana is proposed to be cultivated, and the maximum number of plants to be grown or cultivated at any one (1) time; 
(g)  For safety and code inspection purposes, it shall describe and provide detailed specifications of all lights, equipment, and all other electrical, plumbing, and other means proposed to be used to facilitate the cultivation of marihuana plants; and 
(h)  Include the medical marihuana facility license fee. Such license fee shall be established by resolution of the city council, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.805. - Investigation. 
(a)  After the city clerk has received a completed application, it shall be, at a minimum, forwarded to the following city departments for review and investigation: 
i.  Police; 
ii.  Fire; and 
iii.  Building inspection. 
(b)  During normal business hours of the city, or at another mutually agreeable time, the applicant shall allow the representatives of the above-referenced city departments onto the property and into the proposed licensed premises to complete an investigation. 
(c)  If all of the above-listed city departments approve the application and the proposed licensed premises, and it conforms to the provisions of this chapter, the city clerk shall issue a medical marihuana facility license to the applicant. 
(d)  A medical marihuana facility license shall not be issued if there are any violation(s) of the applicable building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, or fire prevention codes, applicable zoning regulations, or other applicable statutory regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.806. - General certification, license requirements and conditions. 
(a)  A medical marihuana facility license shall not be issued or renewed for a medical marihuana facility proposed or located in any zoning district with the city, other than a light industrial district (I-L) and as more fully specified in chapter 45, article 19, of the City of Southfield Code. 
(b)  A medical marihuana facility license shall not be issued or renewed for a medical marihuana facility that does not comply with all provisions, requirements, limitations, qualifications or restrictions providing for protected medical use of marihuana authorized by the MMMA, as amended. 
(c)  A medical marihuana facility license shall not be issued or renewed for an existing or proposed medical marihuana facility that does not restrict and limit access to the facility areas where marihuana is kept, stored, cultivated, processed, used, exchanged, possessed, sold, or distributed to only qualifying patients and primary caregivers as allowed, limited, restricted or qualified under the MMMA, as amended. 
(d)  Issuance or renewal of a medical marihuana facility license constitutes an unconditional and irrevocable acceptance and agreement by the licensee and all persons and entities operating under a medical marihuana facility license or otherwise utilizing the facility to hold harmless, defend and indemnify the city, including its agents, employees and officers and officials to the fullest extent permitted by law for any and all claims, damages, injuries or liabilities at law or equity in any way arising out of or related to any acts, omissions, activities or conditions in any way related to a licensed medical marihuana facility. 
(e)  A medical marihuana facility license shall be for a specific fixed location which shall be considered the licensed premises. 
(f)  A medical marihuana facility license shall not be required for the principal residence of a qualifying patient where marihuana is cultivated or used exclusively for such qualifying patient's personal consumption in accordance with the MMMA; however, a location other than a qualifying patient's principal residence where such qualifying patient cultivates or uses marihuana shall be subject to the licensure requirements of this chapter. 
(g)  No medical marihuana facility license shall be granted without the certification and approval of the chief of police as prescribed in chapter 70. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.807. - Operating requirements. 
    All medical marihuana facilities in the city shall be maintained, occupied and operated in compliance with all applicable provisions, limitations, qualifications, restrictions, and requirements providing for protected medical use of marihuana authorized by the MMMA, as amended, the provisions of the City of Southfield Code, and the following operation requirements: 
(a)  The licensed premises shall be maintained and operated in compliance with an approved security and lighting plan. 
(b)  The licensed premises shall operate in accordance with all electrical, plumbing, mechanical and building codes. 
(c)  Medical marihuana facilities shall cultivate and distribute marihuana for a medical use only as authorized and in the manner permitted by the MMMA, as amended. 
(d)  Medical marihuana facilities shall not cultivate, possess or distribute marihuana in excess of the quantities authorized and permitted under the MMMA, as amended. 
(e)  All sales, distribution, furnishing or exchange of marihuana for a medical use upon the licensed premises shall be made directly by and between person(s) protected for the medical use of marihuana under and in accordance with the MMMA, as amended. 
(f)  Medical marihuana shall not be possessed, handled, used or made accessible to any person(s) other than departmentally approved primary caregivers and qualifying patients as authorized by the MMMA, as amended. 
(g)  Any change of membership, ownership, shareholder or official status of a licensed entity shall be disclosed and identified by the licensee to the city subject to the confidentiality rules under the MMMA, as amended. 
(h)  Department registry identification numbers for all persons dispensing or otherwise engaging in the medical use of marihuana at or upon the licensed premises shall be promptly disclosed to the city subject to the confidentiality rules under the MMMA, as amended. 
(i)  The medical marihuana facility license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be conspicuously posted on the premises. 
(j)  Any type of consumption of marihuana on the premises is prohibited. There shall be no outdoor, open use or display of marihuana on or at the premises. 
(k)  The hours a medical marihuana facility is permitted to operate and be open for business shall be only as follows: Monday-Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m.; Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.; and Sunday, 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. It shall be unlawful for a medical marihuana facility to be open for business or for any employee or person working at the facility to allow anyone to enter into the premises except during the hours as set forth in this subsection 7.807(k). 
(l)  Entry into the premises by persons under the age of eighteen (18) is prohibited unless they are a qualifying patient and accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(m)  Money or compensation paid to the primary caregiver by qualifying patients shall be promptly deposited into a lock drop box situated on the premises. 
(n)  No signage shall be placed or permitted on the exterior of the premises which identifies or depicts the use, cultivation, growth, possession or distribution of marihuana within or on the premises. 
(o)  No food or drink of any kind shall be sold, transferred or distributed from the medical marihuana facility. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.808. - Inspections. 
    The police department, building department, fire department and the Oakland County Health Department may visit and enter a medical marihuana facility for the purposes of routine inspection and determining that the facility is complying with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.809. - Assignment of license prohibited. 
    The assignment of or attempt to assign any license issued pursuant to this chapter if unlawful and any such assignment or attempt to assign a license shall render the license null and void. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.810. - Renewal of license requirement. 
(a)  A medical marihuana facility license expires one (1) year after issuance or renewal. 
(b)  A medical marihuana facility license shall be renewed if: 
(1)  The licensee submits written request for renewal to the city prior to expiration and pays a renewal fee in an amount to be determined by resolution of council; 
(2)  The city clerk verifies that at or immediately prior to expiration, the information, conditions and representations contained in the approved application remain materially correct, true and accurate; 
(3)  An inspection of the medical marihuana facility premises at or immediately prior to expiration verifies compliance with all provisions of this Code and requirements, restrictions, limitations and qualifications providing for protected medical use of marihuana authorized under the MMMA, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.811. - Revocation, suspension. 
    Any violation of any provision of this chapter, chapter 45 of the zoning ordinance or of the MMMA, as amended, shall constitute cause to revoke or suspend a license pursuant to the procedures and provisions of chapter 70 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.812. - Prohibitions. 
    No person or entity shall distribute, sell, convey, exchange, possess, use or give away marihuana in the city except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, chapter 45 of the zoning ordinance or as otherwise authorized and permitted by the MMMA. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 7.813. - Penalties, remedies. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and upon a finding of responsibility thereof shall be penalized as provided in section 1.703 of the City Code. Additionally, the city may seek enforcement and abatement of any violation of this chapter by instituting any legal or equitable action in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1638 , § 1, 4-5-15)

CHAPTER 99. - SIGNS[2]
