SUBCHAPTER H. - SOUTHFIELD VEHICLE CODE 

Sec. 10.1001. - Adoption of code by reference. 
    Pursuant to subsection 3(k) of the Home Rule Cities Act, 1909 PA 209 as amended, being MCL 117.3(k), the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300 as amended, being MCL 257.1 through MCL 257.923 inclusive, and all future amendments and revisions to the Michigan Vehicle Code when they are effective are hereby adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 9-15-03) 
Sec. 10.1002. - References in code. 
    References in the Michigan Vehicle Code to local authorities shall mean the City of Southfield. 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 9-15-03) 
Sec. 10.1003. - Penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code for violations of said code are hereby adopted by the city by reference, provided however, that the city may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment for violation thereof is greater than ninety-three (93) days; however, a violation of MCL 257.625(1)(C) and the Southfield Motor Vehicle Code 10.625(1)(c) is punishable by one (1) or more of the following: 
i.)  Community service of not more than three hundred sixty (360) hours; 
ii.)  Imprisonment for not more than one hundred eighty (180) days; and, 
iii.)  A fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more than seven hundred dollars ($700.00). 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 9-15-03; Ord. No. 1599 , § 1, 12-23-12) 
Sec. 10.1004. - Notice to be published. 
    The city clerk shall publish this ordinance in the manner required by law and shall publish, at the same time, a notice stating the purpose of the Michigan Vehicle Code and the fact that a complete copy of the code is available for public use and inspection at the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 9-15-03) 
Sec. 10.1005. - Title of subchapter and method of citing. 
    This subchapter shall be known as the Southfield Vehicle Code. For purposes of citing the provisions of this subchapter, the section number of the Michigan Vehicle Code shall be inserted immediately following the designation "section 10". As an example, a violation of section 626(b) of the Michigan Vehicle Code for careless driving shall be cited as a violation of section 10.626(b) of the Southfield Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 1500, § 1, 9-15-03) 
Sec. 10.1006. - Parking regulations. 
    A motor vehicle shall not be parked on any public street between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.; however, permission to park during these hours may be granted by the chief of police or his designee for a period not to exceed seven (7) days when a social function is being held, construction is in progress prohibiting the use of a driveway or garage, or other special occasion(s) upon the finding by the chief of police or his designee that such permission will not be detrimental to the surrounding neighborhood; provided, however, any such permission to park on the public street during these hours issued by the chief of police or his designee shall be limited to no more than two (2) annually per residence or household. 
(Ord. No. 1558, § 1, 5-5-08; Ord. No. 1696 , § 1, 8-9-18) 
Secs. 10.1007-10.1100. - Reserved. 
SUBCHAPTER I. - HAND-HELD PHONES 

Sec. 10.1101. - Using a hand-held phone while committing a traffic offense. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a traffic offense while operating a motor vehicle on any highway, or other place open to the general public including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, while using a hand-held phone. A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction and may be penalized as provided for in section 10.907. 
(Ord. No. 1553, § 1, 10-9-07) 
CHAPTER 127 - SOUTHFIELD MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY CODE 

Sec. 10.1201. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote safety and highways of the city by regulating the operation of certain vehicles, to establish the qualifications of persons necessary for the safe operator of such vehicles, to limit the hours of service of persons engaged in operating such vehicles, to require the keeping of records of such operations, and to provide penalties for the violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Sec. 10.1202. - Adoption of code by reference. 
    Pursuant to subsection 3(k) of the Home Rule Cities Act, being MCL 117.3(k), the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act, being P.A. No. 181 of 1963 (MCL 480.11 et seq.) as amended by P.A. 1984, No. 23; P.A. 1990, No. 339; P.A. 1995, No. 265; P.A. 2000, No. 98; P.A. 2005, No. 177; P.A. 2006, No. 50; P.A. 2011, No. 160; P.A. 2012, No. 231, and as may be further revised or amended now or in the future, is hereby adopted by the City of Southfield, and incorporated by reference as an ordinance of the City of Southfield. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Sec. 10.1203. - References in code. 
    Reference in the Motor Carrier Safety Act to "City" shall mean the City of Southfield, and reference to "local ordinance" shall mean the Code of Ordinances of the City of Southfield. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Sec. 10.1204. - Penalties. 
    The penalties provided by the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act for violations of said code are hereby adopted by the City of Southfield; provided, however, that the City of Southfield shall not enforce any provision of the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act for which the maximum period of imprisonment for violation thereof is greater than ninety-three (93) days. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Sec. 10.1205. - Notice to be published. 
    The city clerk shall publish this ordinance in the manner provided by law, and the fact that a complete copy of the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act is available for public use and inspection at the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Sec. 10.1206. - Title of chapter and method of citing. 
    This chapter shall be known as the Southfield Motor Carrier Safety Code. For purposes of citing the provisions of this chapter the section number of the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act shall be inserted immediately following the designation section "10.1202". As an example, a violation of section 7b of the Michigan Motor Carrier Safety Act, operation of a commercial motor vehicle with serious safety defects, shall be cited as subsection 10.1202.7b of the Southfield Motor Carrier Safety Code. 
(Ord. No. 1631 , § 1, 12-7-14) 
Title XI - TAXES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to tax, § 9.1. 
Cross reference- Special assessments for public improvements, § 1.221 et seq.; tax increment finance authority, § 2.400 et seq. 

CHAPTER 140. - TAX EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 11.1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter (sections 11.1 through 11.9) is to provide for a complete exemption for ad valorem taxes and to provide for a service charge in lieu of taxes for a housing project for low income persons and families to be financed with a federally-aided, or regulated pursuant to section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code, or an authority-aided mortgage loan or an advance or grant from the authority, pursuant to the provisions of the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended; MCL 125.1401, et seq., (the "Act"). 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, published February 9, 2014, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 11.1 through 11.9, and adding new §§ 11.1 through 11.9. Former 11.1 through 11.9 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 943, adopted July 11, 1977. 
Sec. 11.2. - Title. 
    This chapter (sections 11.1 through 11.9) shall be known and cited as the "Southfield Tax Exemption Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.3. - Preamble. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its low income persons and families and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the Act. The city is authorized by the Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses, not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for low income persons and families is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, the encouragement of the same by providing real estate tax exemption for such housing is a valid public purpose. It is further acknowledged that the continuance of the provisions of sections 11.1 through 11.9 for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of all ad valorem taxes during the period contemplated in sections 11.1 through 11.9 are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of the housing projects that is constructed or rehabilitated with financing extended in reliance on such tax exemption. 
    The city acknowledges that the sponsor (as defined below) has offered, subject to receipt of either a mortgage loan from the Michigan State Housing Development Authority, or a federally-aided mortgage and/or receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program from the Michigan State Housing Development Authority, to construct/acquire and rehabilitate, own and operate a housing project identified as "River Park Place" on certain property located at 24300 Civic Center Drive, (more specifically described in Exhibit A, which is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk) in the city to serve low income persons and families, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing project an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14; Ord. No. 1634 , § 1, 12-21-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.4. - Definitions. 
A.  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
B.  Annual shelter rent means the total collections during an agreed annual period from or paid on behalf of all occupants of a housing project representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of utilities. 
C.  Contract rents means the total contract rents (as defined by the US Department of Housing and Urban Development in regulations promulgated, pursuant to section 8 of the US Housing Act of 1937, as amended) received in connection with the operation of a housing project during an agreed annual period, exclusive of utilities. 
D.  Federally-aided mortgage means any of the following: 
(1)  A below market interest rate mortgage insured, purchased, or held by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development ("HUD"); 
(2)  A market interest rate mortgage insured by HUD and augmented by a program of rent subsidies; 
(3)  A mortgage receiving interest reduction payments provided by HUD; 
(4)  A mortgage on a housing development to which the authority allocates low income housing tax credits under section 22b of the Act; 
(5)  A mortgage receiving special benefits under other federal law designated specifically to develop low and moderate-income housing, consistent with the Act. 
E.  Low income persons and families means persons and families eligible to move into a housing project. 
F.  Mortgage loan means a loan or grant made or to be made by the authority to the sponsor for the construction, rehabilitation, acquisition, and/or permanent financing of the housing project, and secured by a mortgage on the housing project. 
G.  Sponsor means the Southfield River Park Place Limited Dividend Housing Association LLC, and any entity that receives or assumes a mortgage loan or federally-aided mortgage. 
H.  Utilities means charges for gas, electric, water, sanitary sewer, and other utilities furnished to the occupants that are paid by the housing project. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.5. - Class of housing projects. 
    It is determined that the class of housing projects to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing projects for low income persons and families that are financed with a mortgage loan by the authority or financed by a federally-aided mortgage. It is further determined that "River Park Place" is of this class. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.6. - Annual service charge. 
A.  Establishment of annual service charge. The housing project identified as "River Park Place" and the property on which it is located, 24300 Civic Center Drive, Southfield, Michigan (more specifically described on Exhibit A), shall be exempt from all ad valorem property taxes from and after the commencement of construction or rehabilitation. The city acknowledges that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing project in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of sections 11.1 through 11.9, and the qualification of the housing project for exemption from all ad valorem property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established in sections 11.1 through 11.9. Therefore, in consideration of the sponsor's offer to construct/rehabilitate and operate the housing project, the city agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all ad valorem property taxes. Subject to receipt of a mortgage loan or a federally-aided mortgage or an allocation under the low income housing tax credit program from the authority, the annual service shall be equal to four (4) percent of the annual shelter rents/contract rents actually collected by the housing project during each operating year. 
B.  Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. Notwithstanding subsection 11.6.A, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing project that is tax exempt but which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing project if the housing project were not tax exempt. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14; Ord. No. 1634 , § 1, 12-21-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.7. - Contractual effect of sections 11.1 through 11.9. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of sections 11.1 through 11.9. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.8. - Payment of service charge. 
    The annual service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under sections 11.1 through 11.9 shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable to the city and distributed to the several units levying the general property tax in the same proportion as prevailed with the general property tax in the previous calendar year. The annual payment for each operating year shall be paid on or before July 1 of the following year. Collection procedures shall be in accordance with the provisions of the General Property Tax Act (1893 PA 206, as amended; MCL 211.1, et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.9. - Duration. 
    The provisions of sections 11.1 through 11.9 shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as a MSHDA mortgage or a federally-aided mortgage, or regulation by a qualified low-income housing credits pursuant to section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code, remains in effect and encumbers the property. 
(Ord. No. 1620 , § 1, 2-9-14) 
Note- See editor's note, § 11.1. 
Sec. 11.10. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter [sections 11.10 through 11.18] is to provide for complete exemption from taxes and any service charges for a proposed multiple-family dwelling project with congregate care amenities for senior citizens and handicapped persons pursuant to the provisions of the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 P.A. 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.11. - Title. 
    This chapter [sections 11.10 through 11.18] shall hereinafter be known and cited as the "City of Southfield Tax and Service Charge Exemption Ordinance No. 2." 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.12. - Preamble. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its senior citizens and handicapped persons and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for an exemption from all taxes imposed by the state or by any political subdivision, public body or taxing district in which the housing is located as permitted by the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 P.A. 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The city (hereinafter "city") is authorized by said Act to establish a service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, the encouragement of the same by providing certain tax and service charge exemption therefor is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of sections 11.10 through 11.18 for tax and service charge exemption during the periods hereinafter contemplated are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance thereon. It is further acknowledged that there presently exists in the city a pressing need for senior citizens congregate care housing facilities. 
    The city acknowledges that McDonnell III Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership (hereinafter the "sponsor") has offered to erect, own and operate a housing development identified as The Trowbridge on certain property located in the city (as more particularly described on Exhibit "A" attached hereto and made a part hereof) to serve senior citizens and handicapped persons and has also agreed to incorporate certain congregate care amenities and that the city has agreed, in consideration thereof, to grant an exemption from all taxes and service charges for such development pursuant to the authority duly vested in the city council by the Act and by the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Editor's note- Exhibit "A" to Ord. No. 1236 is not set out herein but is kept on file and available for inspection at the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 11.13. - Definitions. 
    [As used in sections 11.10 through 11.18:] 
(a)  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
(b)  Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
(c)  Housing development means a development for senior citizens and handicapped persons and such elements of commercial, recreational and communal facilities to improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for senior citizens and handicapped persons. 
(d)  Mortgage loan means the loans to be made by the authority or insured or co-insured by FHA to the sponsor for the construction and permanent financing of the housing development. 
(e)  Sponsor means persons or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan or to FHA for insurance or co-insurance to finance a housing development. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.14. - Class of housing developments. 
    It is hereby determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be those housing developments financed with federally aided or authority aided mortgages which have insurance or co-insurance issued by The Federal Housing Administration ("FHA") under the authority of the department of housing and urban development, as of September 1, 1987, and which housing developments provide, in conjunction with the housing facilities, a dining room sufficient to seat not less than one-half (1/2) of its residents, covered parking, a kitchen with range, refrigerator, disposal and dishwasher in each apartment, community space with kitchen facilities, laundry facilities to service the residents, community space for recreational activities, facilities for barber and beauty shop and space for social work and health personnel. It is further determined that The Trowbridge is of this class of housing developments. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.15. - Exemption from taxes and nonassessment of service charges. 
    The housing development identified as FHA Project No. 044-36604 and the property on which it shall be constructed shall be exempt from all taxes and/or service charges from and after the commencement of construction. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the sponsor's mortgagee have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of sections 11.10 through 11.18 and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all taxes and service charges whatsoever, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer to construct, own and operate said housing development, hereby agrees not to assess any taxes or service charges and to completely abate any taxes or service charges for the duration of sections 11.10 through 11.18 as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.16. - Contractual effect of ordinance. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) or any other provisions of the Act to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the sponsor's mortgagee and the authority as third party beneficiaries thereunder, to provide tax and service charge exemption as hereinabove set forth, is effected and implemented by enactment of sections 11.10 through 11.18 [Ord. No. 1236]. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.17. - Duration. 
    Sections 11.10 through 11.18 shall remain in effect and shall not terminate or be repealed so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the FHA has any interest in the property; provided, that construction of the housing development commences within one (1) year from the effective date of sections 11.10 through 11.18 [Ord. No. 1236]. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.18. - Severability. 
    The various sections and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be severable, and should any section or provision of this chapter be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole or any section or provision hereof other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 10-26-87) 
Sec. 11.19. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27] is to provide for a complete exemption from taxes and any service charges for a proposed multiple-family dwelling project for senior citizens and handicapped persons of low and moderate income to be financed or assisted pursuant to the provisions of the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 P.A. 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.20. - Title. 
    This chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27] shall hereinafter be known and cited as the "City of Southfield Tax and Service Charge Exemption Ordinance No. 3." 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.21. - Preamble. 
    It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its senior citizens and handicapped persons of low and moderate income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for an exemption from all taxes imposed by the state or by any political subdivision, public body or taxing district in which the housing is located as permitted by the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 P.A. 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The city (hereinafter "city") is authorized by such act to establish a service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under the act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for the act. It is further acknowledged that such housing is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefitted and improved by such housing, the encouragement of the same by providing certain tax and service charge exemption therefor is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of this chapter [sections 11.19-11.27] for tax and service charge exemption during the periods hereinafter contemplated are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance thereon. It is further acknowledged that there presently exists in the city a pressing need for housing for senior citizens and handicapped persons. 
    The city acknowledges that Meadowcrest Limited Dividend Housing Association Limited Partnership (hereinafter the "sponsor") has offered, subject to receipt of a mortgage loan from the authority, to erect, own and operate a housing development identified as Meadowcrest Apartments on certain property located in the city (as more particularly described in "Exhibit A" attached hereto and made a part hereof) to serve persons of low and moderate income and that the city has agreed, in consideration thereon, to grant an exemption from all taxes and service charges for such development pursuant to the authority duly vested in the city council by the act and by the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Editor's note- Exhibit "A" to Ord. No. 1293 is not set out herein but is kept on file and available for inspection at the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 11.22. - Definitions. 
    As used in the chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27] the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed in this section: 
(a)  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
(b)  Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966 of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
(c)  Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low or moderate income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, communal and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low and moderate income. 
(d)  Mortgage loan means the loans to be made by the authority to the sponsor for the construction and permanent financing of the housing development. 
(e)  Sponsor means persons or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan to finance a housing development. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.23. - Class of housing development. 
    It is hereby determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply, shall be those housing developments financed with authority-aided mortgages which have been accepted by the authority for participation under the authority's taxable bond program utilizing the nine (9) percent tax credit as of September 1, 1989. It is further determined that Meadowcrest Apartments is of this class of housing development. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.24. - Exemption from taxes and nonassessment of service charges. 
    The housing development identified as authority project No. 803 and the property on which it shall be constructed shall be exempt from all taxes and/or service charges from and after the commencement of construction. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this chapter [sections 11.17 through 11.27] and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all taxes and service charges whatsoever, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to receipt of a permanent mortgage loan from the authority, to own and operate such housing development, hereby agrees not to assess any taxes or service charges and to completely abate any taxes or service charges for the duration of this chapter [sections 11.17 through 11.27] as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.25. - Contractual effect of ordinance. 
    Notwithstanding the provision of section 15(a)(5) or any other provisions of the act to the contrary, a contract between the city and sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary thereunder to provide tax and service charge exemption as hereinabove set forth, is effected and implemented by enactment of this chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27]. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.26. - Duration. 
    This chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27] shall remain in effect and shall not terminate or be repealed so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property; provided, that construction of the housing development commences within one (1) year from the effective date of this chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27]. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
Sec. 11.27. - Severability. 
    The various sections and provisions of this chapter [sections 11.19 through 11.27] shall be deemed to be severable, and should any section or provisions of this chapter be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the chapter as a whole or any section or provision hereof other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 12-11-89) 
CHAPTER 141. - NEIGHBORHOOD ENTERPRISE ZONES 

Sec. 11.50. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to preserve Southfield neighborhoods and to further the maintenance, preservation, improvement and development of housing for all persons regardless of income level; to provide that the city, by resolution, may designate one (1) or more neighborhood enterprise zones pursuant to the Michigan Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act, Public Act 147 of 1992, as amended, being MCL 207.771 et seq.; and to encourage, through ad valorem property tax benefits established by said Act, the construction of new structures that have as their primary purpose owner-occupied one (1) or two (2) unit residential housing and the rehabilitation of existing structures having as their primary purpose residential housing consisting of one (1) to eight (8) units, and under specific circumstances for newly constructed market rate rental residential projects, by bringing them into conformity with minimum building and housing code standards and improving the livability of the units. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.51. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
(1)  Certificate of compliance means a certificate issued by the building official, or his or her designee, attesting to the fact that a new, rehabilitated or market rate rental facility for which an enterprise zone certificate is in effect is in compliance with the construction or safety codes of the city. 
(2)  Neighborhood enterprise zone means any zone designated by the city council by resolution from time to time as a neighborhood enterprise zone pursuant to the requirements of the Michigan Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act, Public Act 147 of 1992, as amended, being MCL 207.771 et seq., (the Act). 
(3)  Neighborhood enterprise zone certificate means a certificate as defined and issued pursuant to the Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act. 
(4)  New facility means one (1) or both of the following: 
(i)  A new structure of a portion of a new structure that has as its primary purpose residential housing consisting of one (1) or two (2) units, one (1) of which is or will be occupied by an owner as his or her principal residence. New facility includes a model home or a model condominium unit. New facility includes a new individual condominium unit, in a structure with one (1) or more condominium units that has as its primary purpose residential housing and that is or will be occupied by an owner as his or her principal residence. 
(ii)  A new structure or a portion of a new structure that meets all of the following: 
(A)  Is rented or leased or is available for rent or lease. 
(B)  Is a mixed use building or located in a mixed use building that contains retail business space on the street level floor. 
(C)  Is located in a qualified downtown revitalization district. 
(5)  Owner means the record title holder of, or the vendee of the original land contract pertaining to a new facility or a rehabilitated facility for which a neighborhood enterprise zone certificate is applied for or issued. 
(6)  Rehabilitated facility means an existing structure or a portion of an existing structure with a current true cash value of eighty thousand dollars ($80,000.00) or less per unit that has or will have as its primary purpose residential housing, consisting of one (1) to eight (8) units, the owner of which proposes improvements that if done by a licensed contractor would cost in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per owner-occupied unit or fifty (50) percent of the true cash value, whichever is less, or seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per nonowner-occupied unit or fifty (50) percent of the true cash value, whichever is less, or the owner proposes improvements that would be done by the owner and not a licensed contractor and the cost of the materials would be in excess of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) per owner-occupied unit or four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00) per nonowner-occupied unit and will bring the structure into conformance with minimum Southfield Housing Code standards for occupancy or improve the livability of the units while meeting minimum Southfield Housing Code standards. Rehabilitated facility also includes an individual condominium unit, in a structure with one (1) or more condominium units that has as its primary purpose residential housing, the owner of which proposes the above described improvements. Rehabilitated facility also includes existing or proposed condominium units in a qualified historic building with one (1) or more existing or proposed condominium units. Rehabilitated facility does not include a facility rehabilitated with the proceeds of an insurance policy for property or casualty loss. A qualified historic building may contain multiple rehabilitated facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.52. - Designation of zones. 
    The city council, by resolution, may designate from time to time one (1) or more neighborhood enterprise zones. 
(1)  A neighborhood enterprise zone for rehabilitation and new construction shall contain not less than ten (10) platted parcels of land. A neighborhood enterprise zone located in a qualified downtown revitalization district may contain less than ten (10) platted parcels if the platted parcels together contain ten (10) or more facilities. All the land within a neighborhood enterprise zone shall also be compact and contiguous. Contiguity is not broken by a road, right-of-way, or property purchased or taken under condemnation. 
(2)  The total acreage of the neighborhood enterprise zones designated under this section shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the total acreage contained within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.53. - Application for certificate. 
    Once a neighborhood enterprise zone is established in the manner provided in section 11.52 and the Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act, any person who proposes to construct a new facility or to rehabilitate property located in a neighborhood enterprise zone, and who intends to seek the tax benefits provided in the Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act, may file an application for a neighborhood enterprise zone certificate with the city assessor. The application must be filed before a building permit is issued for the work proposed and shall be filed in the form and manner prescribed for in said Act. The city shall charge a non-refundable application fee set by city council resolution from time to time to be paid with the filing of the application. The application for a certificate shall be subject to the requirements, approvals and conditions of the Neighborhood Enterprise Zone Act and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.54. - Inspections. 
(1)  Before the sale of a new facility, rehabilitated or rental facility for which a neighborhood enterprise zone certificate is in effect, an inspection by the city shall be requested and made to determine compliance with the building and housing codes of the city, chapters 100 and 102 of the City Code. 
(2)  No sale of any new, rehabilitated, or rental facility for which a neighborhood enterprise zone certificate is in effect may be finalized until there is compliance with the building and housing codes of the city, chapters 100 and 102 of the City Code, and a certificate of compliance attesting to the fact is issued by the city administrator or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.55. - Issuance of certificate of compliance. 
(1)  A certificate of compliance shall be issued only after the new, rehabilitated, or market rate rental facility has been inspected and meets the requirements or the construction or safety codes of the city. An inspection report shall be completed by the inspector after the inspection is completed. The report shall note all violations found in the facility. Before a certificate of compliance is issued, all violations must be corrected and the required inspection fee paid. 
(2)  After issuance, a certificate of compliance shall only be valid for one (1) sale of a new, rehabilitated, or market rate rental facility. A new inspection and certificate of approval shall be required each time a new or rehabilitated facility is sold. 
(3)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in the Act, the duration of the neighborhood enterprise certificate shall be not less than six (6) years or more than fifteen (15) years in accordance with section 12 of the Act, and shall be determined in accordance with the schedule adopted by the city council by resolution from time to time which fixes the number of years beyond the minimum to additional investment levels in the rehabilitated facility beyond the base investment set forth in the Act. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Sec. 11.56. - Inspection fee. 
    The city shall charge a non-refundable inspection fee which shall be set by city council resolution from time to time, which shall be paid in advance of the certificate of approval inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1695 , § 1, 6-7-18) 
Title XII - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Utilities, franchises, permits, § 10.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Utilities and services, tit. II. 

CHAPTER 145. - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1457, enacted Sept. 25, 2000, amended ch. 145 in its entirety to read as herein set out. See Code Comparative Table for amendatory history. 

Sec. 12.1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "The Southfield Cable Communications Procedure Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.2. - Declaration of purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the regulation of cable communications service in the city in the interest of the public; to promote and encourage adequate economical and efficient cable communications service to the residents of the city; to provide for the furnishing of a cable communications system service to the residents of the city without unjust discrimination, undue preference, or advantages; to provide oversight of community programming on public, education and government (PEG) channels, and to promote viewership. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, when used in this chapter, shall have the following meanings, unless otherwise clearly apparent from the context: 
(a)  Access cablecasting shall mean services provided by a cable television system on its public, education, local government, leased or other channels. 
(b)  Cable communications system, cable system, CATV or system shall mean a system of coaxial cables, fiber optics or other equipment used to receive signals off the air or otherwise, and to transmit them via cable to subscribers, including the origination, receipt, transmission, and distribution of voice, sound signals, pictures, visual images, digital signals, telemetry, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical impulses, whether or not directed to originating signals or receiving signals off the air. Such definition does not include: 
(i)  Any system which offers service to fewer than fifty (50) dwelling units. 
(ii)  Any master antenna system distributing only local broadcast stations or security channels. 
(c)  Cable communications service shall mean the business, in whole or in part, of receiving directly or indirectly over the air, and amplifying or otherwise modifying signals transmitting programs broadcast by one (1) or more signals, sound signals, pictures, visual images, digital signals, telemetry, or any other type of closed circuit transmission by means of electrical or light impulses, whether or not directed to originating signals or receiving signals off the air, and redistributing such signals by wire, cable or other means to members of the public located in the city. 
(d)  Cable manager shall mean the manager of the City of Southfield cable television department. 
(e)  City shall mean the City of Southfield, Michigan, and all the territory within its territorial corporate limits. 
(f)  City administrator shall mean the administrator of the City of Southfield or his/her designee. 
(g)  Council is the city council of Southfield, Michigan. 
(h)  Franchise or franchise agreement shall mean the separate agreement by which a franchise is granted to the grantee, as authorized by this chapter. 
There shall be two (2) types of franchises: A city-wide franchise to operate a cable communications system which encompasses a major portion of the geographic area of the city; and a limited franchise for a cable communications system restricted to a specific geographic area for private multiple dwelling units or cable communications system connecting private multiple dwelling units operating under the same ownership. 
(i)  Grantee shall mean any person or company and parent company thereof granted a franchise in accordance with this chapter. 
(j)  Pay TV shall mean an arrangement under which a charge is made to a television receiver for receiving a particular television program. 
(k)  Person or company means and includes one (1) or more individuals, firms, corporations, associations, partnerships or organizations of any kind, and any combination thereof. 
(l)  Street shall mean the surface of or the space above and below any public street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, public way or place, alley, court, sidewalk, boulevard, parkway, drive or other easement now or hereafter held by the city for the purpose of public travel, and shall include such other easements and rights-of-way as shall be now held or hereafter held by the city which shall, within their proper use and meaning, entitle the city and its grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing or transmitting signals over poles, wires, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments and other property as may be ordinarily necessary and pertinent to a cable television system. 
(m)  Subscriber shall mean a person or organization whose premises are physically wired to receive any transmission from the system. 
ARTICLE I. - FRANCHISE PROCEDURE 

Sec. 12.4. - Franchise required. 
(a)  No person shall construct, install, maintain or operate a cable communications system in the city whether or not it is deemed to use, occupy or traverse the city streets or rights-of-way, nor shall any person provide a cable communications service or acquire ownership or control of a cable communications company in the city whether or not it is deemed to use, occupy or traverse the city streets or rights-of-way without such person having first obtained a franchise therefor from the city in the form of a franchise agreement between the city and the grantee. 
(b)  No person shall use, occupy or traverse the city streets, alleys, lanes, avenues, boulevards, sidewalks, bridges, viaducts, rights-of-way or any other public place or public way in the city or any extensions thereof or additions thereto, whether on, above, or under the surface of the ground, for the purposes of installing, constructing, maintaining or operating a cable communications system or facilities therefor or for the purpose of furnishing a cable communications franchise therefor for the city in the form of a franchise agreement between the city and the grantee. 
(c)  Any franchise agreement shall contain specifications, including, but not limited to, the following terms: duration of franchise; transfer of franchise; renewal of franchise; forfeiting of franchise, fees, reporting, and records; penalties and procedures; insurance; construction, performance and other bonds; construction schedule and standards; access, local origination, data, pay, and other programming; privacy; system maintenance; employment practices; funding of access, local origination, and other community programming; and any other operating practices. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.5. - Application. 
(a)  A person wishing to secure a city-wide or limited franchise to furnish, install, construct, maintain or operate a cable communications system or service shall file a written application with the city clerk's office (with copies to the city attorney and the city administrator) in such form and containing such information and supportive documentation as the city may require. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee set by the city council which shall be used to cover expenses, direct or indirect, incurred by the city in processing said application. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.6. - Application process. 
(a)  Upon receiving the application and the fee, the cable manager shall investigate and review the application. 
(b)  The cable manager shall recommend approval of the application unless he/she finds that (a) the applicant, (b) the proposed cable communications system, or (c) the proposed franchise does not conform to the standards embodied in the regulations promulgated by the commission or that the proposed franchise would be in violation of any other regulation, ordinance, law or not be in the public interest. 
(c)  The cable manager shall make a recommendation to the city council to approve or disapprove the application and set forth in writing the reasons for its decision. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.7. - Council action. 
(a)  The city council may hold a public hearing on the recommendation of the cable manager to review the findings of the cable manager. Council may request additional information it may deem necessary to establish the legal, financial, technical and other qualifications of the applicant to provide a cable communications system or service in the city. 
(b)  If the council determines that the applicant possesses the necessary qualifications, legal, financial, technical, and otherwise, reasonably to assure applicant's ability satisfactorily to install, construct, maintain, and operate a cable communications system in the city, the council may approve the franchise application contingent upon compliance with standards, terms or conditions set by the city council and direct its staff and/or agents to negotiate a franchise agreement with such successful applicant. Upon approval of such franchise agreement, council may issue the applicant a non-exclusive franchise therefor in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.8. - Current cable franchises. 
    Any cable communications system or service which, pursuant to an existing franchise agreement, (i) was lawfully engaged in actual operations, or (ii) had commenced substantial construction of a cable communications system or service with the approval of city council at the date of the execution of this chapter, may continue to exercise said franchise pursuant to the terms thereof provided such company files with the city within sixty (60) days from the execution hereof, such additional information and supporting documentation as the city may require of other applicants. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.9. - Franchise: transfer, renewal, amendment. 
(a)  No transfer, renewal or amendment of any franchise or any transfer of control of a franchise or of facilities constituting a significant part of any cable communication system shall be effective without prior review and approval of the city council. 
(b)  A person wishing to transfer, renew or amend a franchise, or to transfer control of a franchise or a substantial part of the facilities thereto shall file with the city clerk an application for approval of such change, in such form and containing such information and supportive documents as the city may require. The application shall be accompanied by such fee as the city council may set. 
(c)  The cable manager shall recommend approval of the application unless it finds that the applicant, the proposed transfers or cable television system does not conform to the standards embodied in the regulations, promulgated by the cable manager, the terms of its franchise agreement, or that approval would be in violation of any other regulation, ordinance, law, standard, or the public interest, provided, that such noncompliance is not without reason and approval would be in the public interest. 
(d)  The cable manager shall make his/her recommendations of approval or denial to city council setting forth in writing the reasons for his/her decision. 
(e)  The city council may hold a public hearing to review the recommendation of the cable manager. It may approve the application contingent upon compliance with standards, terms or conditions which serve the interest of the public. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.10. - Civil penalties. 
    If the grantee fails to perform any obligation under the franchise agreement, the cable manager may assess a monetary penalty. 
    The following monetary penalties shall apply, and liability therefore shall accrue from the date of mailing of notice: 
Failure to render payment of the reimbursement of the city's expenses within the specified time, per day, from time due until paid ..... $500.00 
Failure to make timely application, registration, or any other filing with the FCC, per day, from time due until filed ..... $300.00 
Failure to deliver timely evidence of company insurance, per day, from time due until delivered ..... $100.00 
Failure to timely obtain and file with the city the construction bond, per day, from time of lapse until restored ..... $300.00 
Failure to make timely any payment in respect to the security fund or to deposit or restore the letter of credit in a timely fashion, per day, from time due until paid, deposited or restored ..... $200.00 
Failure to render timely payment of the franchise fee, per day, from time due until paid ..... $1,000.00 
Failure of the grantee to perform its obligations in the event of a major public emergency or disaster condition in accordance with the franchise agreement, per occurrence ..... $10,000.00 
Failure to restore damaged property timely, per day until restored ..... $50.00 
Failure to apply for utility company agreements within the specified thirty (30) days, per day, from time due until application is made ..... $500.00 
Failure to commence construction in a timely fashion, per day, from time due until begun ..... $500.00 
Failure to complete construction in a timely fashion, per day, from due until completed ..... $500.00 
Failure to respond to a request for repair or adjustment by the next business day, per day, per subscriber, until response made ..... $100.00 
Failure to commence service to a subscriber within the specified time limits, per day, per subscriber, until service begun ..... $100.00 
Failure to pay a timely refund due a subscriber, per day, per subscriber, from due until paid ..... $50.00 
Failure to provide a subscriber at least the specified notice prior to disconnection, per subscriber, per occurrence ..... $50.00 
Failure to respond in a timely fashion to a billing complaint, per day, per subscriber, until response made ..... $50.00 
Failure to file timely any report required by this agreement, per day, per report, from time due until filed ..... $100.00 
Violation of privacy restrictions of section 4.18, per violation, per subscriber ..... $100.00 
Failure to maintain availability of fixed studio or mobile facility, and all required equipment for access programming use, per day, from 24 hours after interruption of availability, beyond a reasonable period of time for maintenance or repairs, as determined by custom and usage in the U.S. cable television industry, until restored to service ..... $200.00 
Failure to submit a timely original or revised system description, per day, from time due until submitted ..... $20.00 
Failure to submit a timely construction status report, per day, from time due until submitted ..... $100.00 
Failure to comply with any other franchise requirement and/or FCC customer service standards, per day, until default is remedied ..... $100.00 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.11. - Hearing procedures. 
    Before the commencement of proceedings that may result in the imposition of a penalty, the cable manager shall give notice, by certified mail, to the grantee of facts or conduct which warrant this intended action. The grantee shall then be given reasonable opportunity to show compliance with franchise or previous order of the city. If upon review it appears to the cable manager that the grantee continues to be in violation of the franchise or previous order of the city, the cable manager may assess a penalty. 
(a)  Upon the cable manager, assessing a penalty, written notice of such assessment shall be sent to the grantee by certified mail, return receipt requested, with a concise statement of the reasons therefor. 
(b)  Within ten (10) days after mailing of a notice, the grantee may request an appeal of the cable manager's decision to the city administrator, in a proceeding affording due process. The pendency of a hearing shall suspend payment of the penalty until ten (10) days after mailing to the grantee by first class mail of the decision of the city administrator confirming said penalty in whole or in part. 
(c)  The decision of the city administrator shall be in writing and shall contain statement of findings made by the city administrator. 
(d)  The grantee shall pay the full amount of any penalty to the city within ten (10) days after mailing of a notice. 
(e)  Amounts received by the city as penalties assessed against the grantee, may be used by the city for any purpose it deems fit. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE COMMISSION 

Sec. 12.12. - Establishment of commission. 
    The Southfield Cable Communications Commission is hereby created, hereinafter referred to as the "commission." 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.13. - Membership. 
    The commission shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be residents of the city, shall be subscribers, and appointed by the city council. No person shall be appointed as a member, and any member shall vacate his or her chair who, simultaneously holds any position at any level of government as an elected or appointed officer, or department head, whether elected or appointed, or as a member of any board, commission or committee of any political subdivision, or any position specified in section 5.1 of the Southfield City Charter except an "employee" at any level of government and who is not otherwise disqualified. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.14. - Removal as a member. 
    A member may be removed at any time with or without cause by a majority vote of the city council having appointed such member. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.15. - Term of office. 
(a)  The original members of the commission shall be appointed for the following terms: 
1.  Three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of (3) years, their terms expiring on October 1, 2003. 
2.  Two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years, their term expiring on October 1, 2002. 
3.  Two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of (1) year, their terms expiring on October 1, 2001. 
(b)  Upon expiration of the original terms, subsequent appointments by the original appointing body will be for a term of three (3) years. 
(c)  A commissioner, whose term of office has expired, shall continue to hold office until a successor has been appointed, as herein provided. 
(d)  Should a vacancy occur on the commission, a replacement shall be named by city council to fill the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.16. - Rules of procedure. 
    Within ninety (90) days of its original formation, the commission shall adopt by-laws for the conduct of its business and elect a chairperson and a vice chairperson. Annually thereafter, elections for a chairperson and vice chairperson shall occur. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.17. - Powers of the commission. 
    The commission shall have the following specified purposes only: 
(1)  Conduct periodic survey of cable subscribers and other residents to determine interests and suggestions for public-education and government (PEG) programs. 
(2)  Evaluate each of the three (3) PEG channels for strengths and weaknesses, assist in establishing goals for each. 
(3)  Become familiar with any city marketing plan and assist in incorporating themes into programs, promotions and so forth. 
(4)  Complete training at public access facility and have option to volunteer to work on community shows. 
(5)  Assist with public relations for access channels (booths at special events, contests, video festivals, etc.). 
(6)  Review candidates and recommend person to be considered for annual scholarship to high school students planning to pursue degree in telecommunications. 
(7)  Research and discuss various programming including diverse cultural features to be included on access channels. 
(8)  Establish rules for use of public access channel and facilities. 
(9)  Settle disputes with public access users related to rules or studio procedures. 
(10)  Periodically review level of customer service with cable manager. 
(11)  Complete annual evaluation of access programming and report to mayor and council through the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.19. - Staff liaison. 
    A staff liaison person shall be named from time to time by the city administrator, whose duties shall be to act as secretary to the commission and to provide administrative support to the commission in the fulfillment of its duties and responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 12.20. - Conduct of meetings. 
    Meetings of the cable communications commission, and meetings of any committees created thereby, shall be conducted in accordance with the Open Meetings Act; PA 267 of 1976, as may be amended. 
(Ord. No. 1457, § 1, 9-25-00) 
CHAPTER 147. - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS FRANCHISE[4] 

Footnotes:
